d questions, as well as a few that

The recommended experience is network
plus and security plus, they'll tell

you like a lot of these CompTIA exams

you don't have to have your security plus
for example to go in and take this exam.

29

But this is designed to or

they're going to assume that you
already have that knowledge.

31
00:02:05.020 --> 00:02:07.320
So you've either taken
that certification or

00:02:07.320 --> 00:02:12.143
you've got the real world experience to

33
00:02:12.143 --> 00:02:16.720
All right, $230 here in the US currently,

00:02:16.720 --> 00:02:21.517
make sure you go check out CompTIA's
websites before you sign up for the exam,

35
00:02:21.517 --> 00:02:24.714
find out what the actual
price is in your country, or

36

if they've changed it

37

Next, let's look at
some of the objectives,

00:02:30.500 --> 00:02:34.140
things we will be covering in
this particular video series.

39

All right, there you break
this down into four domains.

40
00:02:38.460 --> 00:02:42.447
We've got domain 1 which is
threat management, all right.

41
00:02:42.447 --> 00:02:45.175
27% of that exam,

42
00:02:45.175 --> 00:02:49.925
Domain 2 is gonna be vulnerability
management, another 26% of our exam.

43
00:02:49.925 --> 00:02:54.985
We got the Cyber Incident Response,

44
00:02:54.985 --> 00:02:57.995
And then, the Security Architecture and
Tool Sets, Domain 4.

45
00:02:57.995 --> 00:03:02.335
It's gonna worth 21% of the exam.

46
00:03:02.335 --> 00:03:06.083
Now, if we scroll down and take a look
at what those domains break that into,

47
00:03:06.083 --> 00:03:08.325
Domain 1 is gonna cover threat management.

48
00:03:08.325 --> 00:03:12.527
So things like, topology discovery,
pack a captured,

49
00:03:12.527 --> 00:03:17.702
DNS harvest thing, different variables,
that we have to deal with.

50
00:03:17.702 --> 00:03:20.863
Wired versus wireless networks,
virtual versus physical.

51
00:03:20.863 --> 00:03:25.913
We'll take a look at some of the tools
that we can use to do network discovery,

52
00:03:25.913 --> 00:03:29.875
mapping out our network,
locating devices on our network,

53
00:03:29.875 --> 00:03:33.320
then we'll go into analyzing the results,
right?

54
00:03:33.320 --> 00:03:36.250
Once we've gathered that information,
what do we do with it?

55
00:03:36.250 --> 00:03:37.280
That's a very important part.

56
00:03:37.280 --> 00:03:38.740
How do we filter it down?

57
00:03:38.740 --> 00:03:40.420
Find the important information.

58
00:03:40.420 --> 00:03:43.930
Correlate logs or cross multiple devices.

59
00:03:43.930 --> 00:03:48.180
We'll continue on, taking a look
at the appropriate responses and

60
00:03:48.180 --> 00:03:52.960
counter measures depending on the threats
that we have discovered on our network.

61
00:03:52.960 --> 00:03:55.480
And we'll take a look at the purpose and

62
00:03:55.480 --> 00:03:58.870
practices used to secure
a corporate environment.

63
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:02.760
Domain 2, we'll get into
Vulnerability Management, right?

64
00:04:02.760 --> 00:04:06.660
We'll learn what tools are best to use,
vulnerability scans.

65
00:04:06.660 --> 00:04:09.540
How often should we do these, and
then what do we do with the results that

66
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:12.510
we've obtained from those
vulnerability scans?

67
00:04:12.510 --> 00:04:16.990
So analyzing the output,
comparing and contrasting different

68
00:04:16.990 --> 00:04:22.190
vulnerabilities found on different types
of targets within our organisation.

69
00:04:22.190 --> 00:04:26.500
Domain 3 is where we're gonna dive into
the world of cyber incident response.

70
00:04:26.500 --> 00:04:31.780
What do we do when we've discovered a
vulnerability has been taken advantage of?

71
00:04:31.780 --> 00:04:35.133
Somebody's launched an attack
against our systems.

72
00:04:35.133 --> 00:04:38.928
How do we deal with that,
how do we go about gathering the evidence,

73
00:04:38.928 --> 00:04:43.591
isolating the system from the rest of the
network, trying to mitigate the impact of

74
00:04:43.591 --> 00:04:48.340
that particular exposure, try to keep it
from spreading to the rest of the network?

75
00:04:50.020 --> 00:04:52.900
As well as how to collect
evidence in a way that's

76
00:04:52.900 --> 00:04:57.430
gonna be able to be used in possibly court
of law, right, if you wanna prosecute.

77
00:04:57.430 --> 00:05:00.610
And as we look down here
forensic investigation,

78
00:05:00.610 --> 00:05:04.542
this is all about going to the scene
of the crime, if you will,

79
00:05:04.542 --> 00:05:09.689
gathering that evidence, bagging and
tagging it, and making sure that it can be

80
00:05:09.689 --> 00:05:14.860
used later on if we do tend to prosecute
whoever launched the attack, all right.

81
00:05:14.860 --> 00:05:17.950
The importance of the communication
process during incident response,

82
00:05:17.950 --> 00:05:22.330
making sure that we're not panicking, that
we have plans in place for what to do,

83
00:05:22.330 --> 00:05:26.940
that we're trained up on that and ready
to proceed with our incident response.

84
00:05:28.830 --> 00:05:32.470
Summarize the incident recovery in
the post-incident response process.

85
00:05:32.470 --> 00:05:36.640
Now that we've dealt with incident,
we've got things back to normal,

86
00:05:36.640 --> 00:05:39.425
do we just go about our
business like we do everyday?

87
00:05:39.425 --> 00:05:42.305
Or do we try to learn
from what we discover,

88
00:05:42.305 --> 00:05:45.885
the way we handle the incident,
the way we process the evidence,

89
00:05:45.885 --> 00:05:50.135
the way it went in the court systems,
what we can do better next time, right?

90
00:05:50.135 --> 00:05:51.950
We're always trying to improve.

91
00:05:51.950 --> 00:05:56.250
And then we get down into Domain 4 where
we start taking a look at a security

92
00:05:56.250 --> 00:06:01.330
architecture and the tool sets that
we'll need to use or have at our

93
00:06:01.330 --> 00:06:06.510
ready when we're performing this cyber
security analyst roles within an incident.

94
00:06:06.510 --> 00:06:09.720
So we'll talk about the different
frameworks that are available,

95
00:06:09.720 --> 00:06:14.660
different policies, how to write these
policies, how to use policies to make

96
00:06:14.660 --> 00:06:19.272
sure we are implementing our
companies security policies and

97
00:06:19.272 --> 00:06:23.270
what our best practices and
procedures, all right.

98
00:06:23.270 --> 00:06:26.970
Security issues related incident,
and access management.

99
00:06:26.970 --> 00:06:31.870
Taking their recommendations to implement,
compensate, and controls.

100
00:06:31.870 --> 00:06:35.070
And where do we put these controls,
what controls do we put in place?

101
00:06:35.070 --> 00:06:38.190
How do we side,
which one's we wanna put in place first?

102
00:06:38.190 --> 00:06:42.560
How do we prioritize amongst those
different controls that are available?

103
00:06:42.560 --> 00:06:45.840
We're also going to talk a little bit
about the software development life-cycle

104
00:06:45.840 --> 00:06:50.170
and how important it is to make sure
that we've got security included

105
00:06:50.170 --> 00:06:52.630
from step one in that SDLC.

106
00:06:52.630 --> 00:06:59.380
And then lastly we'll take a look at
the myriad of tools that are available for

107
00:06:59.380 --> 00:07:03.450
us to use when we're doing our
role as a cyber security analyst,

108
00:07:03.450 --> 00:07:08.840
there are as you can see from the list
here there is no shortage of tools.

109
00:07:08.840 --> 00:07:10.860
And for this example, pick a few or for

110
00:07:10.860 --> 00:07:14.570
this video series anyway, we'll pick
a few and we'll demonstrate them.

111
00:07:14.570 --> 00:07:20.000
So, that when you go into the exam,
we don't have to know every single tool,

112
00:07:20.000 --> 00:07:24.310
but we should know what an IPS is
capable of and is not capable of.

113
00:07:24.310 --> 00:07:28.480
What tools do I have available
if I need to do packet capture.

114
00:07:28.480 --> 00:07:31.430
Is there just one or
are there others that I can choose from?

115
00:07:31.430 --> 00:07:34.060
So we'll go through the list here and
talk about the pros and

116
00:07:34.060 --> 00:07:36.730
cons of choosing some of these tools.

117
00:07:36.730 --> 00:07:38.418
But don't panic when you
see these lists of tools.

118
00:07:38.418 --> 00:07:43.290
CompTIA will tell you, this is not to
test specific vendor feature sets.

119
00:07:43.290 --> 00:07:47.140
What they wanna do is give us an idea
of the possibilities that we have.

120
00:07:47.140 --> 00:07:50.960
There's typically many different
tools that can do the same job and

121
00:07:50.960 --> 00:07:52.520
we just need to know that
they're available and

122
00:07:52.520 --> 00:07:56.770
what their benefits, or pros and cons are
so we can pick the right ones for the job.

123
00:07:56.770 --> 00:07:59.310
So we'll look at different
preventative type tools.

124
00:07:59.310 --> 00:08:05.010
We'll take a look at collecting type
tools, analytical tools, exploit tools,

125
00:08:05.010 --> 00:08:09.520
as well as some forensic tools that we can
use if we need to take this, and again,

126
00:08:09.520 --> 00:08:12.470
go prosecute or
take it into the court of law.

127
00:08:12.470 --> 00:08:15.540
So, if these are some of the skills
that you wanna develop, or

128
00:08:15.540 --> 00:08:18.870
if you're looking at taking your
certification to the next step, and

129
00:08:18.870 --> 00:08:23.060
passing the CompTIA, Cyber Security
Analyst Plus, this is the series for

130
00:08:23.060 --> 00:08:24.935
you, and
I look forward to seeing you there.

131

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike look at concepts and utilities used to gain information on a network through environmental reconnaissance. They will talk about techniques like topology discovery, os fingerprinting, host scanning, network mapping, port scanning and more.

22
00:01:01.900 --> 00:01:04.770
And when it comes to doing

23
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:06.840

24
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:10.540

get an idea of what protocols,

what kinda traffic is

00:01:12.970 --> 00:01:14.147

45
00:02:13.680 --> 00:02:18.950
And I didn't know we had any devices using

46
00:02:18.950 --> 00:02:20.470

47
00:02:21.770 --> 00:02:26.230
So this is a way to discover
maybe what services are running,

48
00:02:26.230 --> 00:02:29.060
who's communicating with whom,

49
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:32.370
Basically just looking at the traffic
that's going across the network.

50
00:02:32.370 --> 00:02:36.210
One thing you do have to keep in mind when
you're going to do packet capture like

51
00:02:36.210 --> 00:02:40.910
this, is where you're at,
what traffic you're gonna be able to see.

52
00:02:40.910 --> 00:02:45.190
Remember that most organizations nowadays

53
00:02:45.190 --> 00:02:48.700
are doing their networks with
what we call switched ethernet.

54
00:02:48.700 --> 00:02:51.760
Meaning that every device is
patched down to the wall and

55
00:02:51.760 --> 00:02:55.660
it goes back to a switch, and
that's giving that device a one to one or

56
00:02:55.660 --> 00:02:57.890
a point to point connection
with the switch.

57
00:02:57.890 --> 00:03:00.720
And the switch,
using its content addressable memory,

58
00:03:00.720 --> 00:03:03.550
is keeping track of who is out what port.

59
00:03:03.550 --> 00:03:06.000
And so,
if my computer's plugged into Port 10,

60
00:03:06.000 --> 00:03:10.130
and there's traffic that this switch
is supposed to be handling, if

61
00:03:10.130 --> 00:03:14.550
it's not destined for me, for my computer,
it's not gonna send it out Port 10.

62
00:03:14.550 --> 00:03:16.830
So I'll never see that traffic,
cuz it wasn't destined for me.

63
00:03:16.830 --> 00:03:22.240
The only thing I'd be capturing would be
traffic that I'm already gonna see anyway,

64
00:03:22.240 --> 00:03:24.020
because it's coming to my device.

65
00:03:24.020 --> 00:03:28.590
So we have to try to figure out
how we can see the traffic,

66
00:03:28.590 --> 00:03:30.030
the majority of the traffic.

67
00:03:30.030 --> 00:03:32.480
Either getting on a mirrored
port on a switch or

68
00:03:32.480 --> 00:03:35.530

sent to the appropriate port.

69
00:03:35.530 --> 00:03:39.420
Plus the monitoring port or the mirrored
port, there's different terms for it.

70
00:03:39.420 --> 00:03:43.130
Or you slip a HUB in front of the switch
and you plug a device into that.

71
00:03:43.130 --> 00:03:44.490
And you do packet capture from there.

72
00:03:44.490 --> 00:03:45.470
I've seen that done.

73
00:03:45.470 --> 00:03:47.630
We've done that in a couple

74
00:03:47.630 --> 00:03:52.010
Trying to monitor some employees and

75
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:55.940
Well, I had to be in front of the switch,

76
00:03:55.940 --> 00:03:58.370
sort out the traffic and
send it out to the appropriate port.

77
00:03:58.370 --> 00:04:00.370
So a couple things to think about.

78
00:04:00.370 --> 00:04:03.290

79
00:04:03.290 --> 00:04:07.780
Because your network adapter is looking at

80
00:04:07.780 --> 00:04:10.290
and it's only going to accept data

81
00:04:10.290 --> 00:04:12.941
if the destination address
is your devices address.

82
00:04:12.941 --> 00:04:15.290
All right, the rest of it silently drops.

83
00:04:15.290 --> 00:04:18.810
If you go into promiscuous mode,
you can now start capturing traffic or

84
00:04:18.810 --> 00:04:20.910
seeing traffic that wasn't destined for
you.

85
00:04:20.910 --> 00:04:24.710
It doesn't just ignore it if it doesn't
have you as a destination address.

86
00:04:24.710 --> 00:04:27.110
Most modern network adapters do this.

87
00:04:27.110 --> 00:04:28.690
But it is something to consider.

88
00:04:28.690 --> 00:04:31.120
Also, you have to think
about wireless traffic and

89
00:04:31.120 --> 00:04:35.354
the fact that your packet capture

00:04:35.354 --> 00:04:36.741

91
00:04:36.741 --> 00:04:41.130

92
00:04:41.130 --> 00:04:43.660
But it's something that
we've gotta consider.

93
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:46.030

00:04:46.030 --> 00:04:50.330
USB traffic, because we're seeing

00:04:50.330 --> 00:04:51.150
Especially with USB.

96
00:04:52.700 --> 00:04:54.390
Wes, you're the more with the protocols.

00:04:54.390 --> 00:04:56.320
What, USB3 or USBC, I guess it is?

98
00:04:56.320 --> 00:04:57.250
>> It's USB3, and

99
00:04:57.250 --> 00:05:01.810
we're going to start seeing more and more
adoption of the USBC adapters and stuff.

100
00:05:01.810 --> 00:05:02.320
Absolutely.

101
00:05:02.320 --> 00:05:05.570
>> And USBC is a high, high bandwidth and

102
00:05:05.570 --> 00:05:10.330
is going to be doing a lot more than
just what we're used to doing with USB.

103
00:05:10.330 --> 00:05:15.890
So you'll see networking go across it,
file transfers going across it,

104
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:17.970
video signals being sent across it.

105
00:05:17.970 --> 00:05:20.490
So it's important that I can
capture traffic on there as well.

106
00:05:20.490 --> 00:05:24.820
Something to consider, in the future it
might be something that I have to do.

107
00:05:24.820 --> 00:05:26.815

let's talk about packet capture.

108
00:05:26.815 --> 00:05:29.370
Now I'm going to use

109
00:05:29.370 --> 00:05:33.390
It's probably If you've been doing this

00:05:33.390 --> 00:05:36.380
It's been around for a long time as well.

00:05:36.380 --> 00:05:40.110
It actually comes from an older

00:05:41.220 --> 00:05:42.480
Gentlemen that developed it, or

00:05:42.480 --> 00:05:46.040

00:05:46.040 --> 00:05:48.800
Long story short,
one of the gentlemen kept the program but

00:05:48.800 --> 00:05:50.920
couldn't keep the name,

116
00:05:50.920 --> 00:05:52.170
If I got my story straight.

117
00:05:52.170 --> 00:05:55.430
Anyway, the point is Wireshark

00:05:55.430 --> 00:05:58.440
And so that means that it's trusted.

00:05:58.440 --> 00:06:01.290

00:06:09.960 --> 00:06:14.190
>> There's dozens of other programs

00:06:22.160 --> 00:06:23.830

00:06:23.830 --> 00:06:24.660

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take a look at the concepts and practice of Network Reconnaissance. They explain what point-in-time data analysis is and how to use different analyzing tools to gather and interpret that information. They also discuss Data Analytics, data output from logs, captures, and scans, and finally cover common tools to that end.

We need to be doing this periodically.

393
00:20:28.860 --> 00:20:32.485
We're looking for where the service
got turned on accidentally.

394
00:20:32.485 --> 00:20:35.801
And now that server's sitting there
listening on ports 20 and 21 or

395
00:20:35.801 --> 00:20:37.024
whatever the case may be.

396
00:20:37.024 --> 00:20:41.826
Or somebody installed some
VMWare on their workstation,

397
00:20:41.826 --> 00:20:44.475
and it's now offering up DHCP.

398
00:20:44.475 --> 00:20:46.951
Or somebody installed
a rogue access point.

399
00:20:46.951 --> 00:20:50.094
Not only looking for
services that shouldn't be there,

400
00:20:50.094 --> 00:20:51.870
ports that shouldn't be open.

401
00:20:51.870 --> 00:20:55.326
Or ports that should be open that aren't,
but also looking for new devices, right?

402
00:20:55.326 --> 00:20:56.867
Like rogue access points,

403
00:20:56.867 --> 00:21:01.425
terminals that have plugged into the
network that shouldn't be there, right?

404
00:21:01.425 --> 00:21:06.228
These are the things I can find using
a program like Nmap to do just ping sweeps

405
00:21:06.228 --> 00:21:07.290
periodically.

406
00:21:07.290 --> 00:21:10.330
Let me look for
all the active hosts on the network and

407
00:21:10.330 --> 00:21:12.450
see what's going on out there.

408
00:21:12.450 --> 00:21:15.680
>> Yeah, Mike, then there's the awesome
built in tools that you have already in

409
00:21:15.680 --> 00:21:16.400
your operating system.

410
00:21:16.400 --> 00:21:17.942
Things like the event logs.

411
00:21:17.942 --> 00:21:22.353
>> Yeah, absolutely, event log,
Windows event logs are fantastic.

412
00:21:22.353 --> 00:21:25.141
And all operating systems have logs.

413
00:21:25.141 --> 00:21:28.159
You look at your Linux boxes,
your Mac OSX,

414
00:21:28.159 --> 00:21:31.680
all of these are gonna
have logging capabilities.

415
00:21:31.680 --> 00:21:36.377
And depending on what OSs you're running

416
00:21:36.377 --> 00:21:38.560
on your network you need
to be familiar with those.

417
00:21:38.560 --> 00:21:41.975
Are you running a syslog system to
collect all the logs from your different

418
00:21:41.975 --> 00:21:43.440
Linux servers?

419
00:21:43.440 --> 00:21:46.700
Are you doing event log
subscriptions in Windows

420
00:21:46.700 --> 00:21:49.290
to pull all those to a central location?

421
00:21:49.290 --> 00:21:51.130
How did we go about filtering those?

422
00:21:51.130 --> 00:21:54.650
Cuz they have great filtering
capabilities built in with Windows.

423
00:21:54.650 --> 00:21:59.105
You've got applications
you can use in Linux.

424
00:21:59.105 --> 00:22:03.711
Daniel's been guiding me through
a lot of my Linux stuff.

425
00:22:03.711 --> 00:22:06.073
And getting good with grep and

426
00:22:06.073 --> 00:22:10.555
being able to find the pertinent
information in there.

427
00:22:10.555 --> 00:22:14.636
Syslogs as I mentioned is
the Cisco side of things.

428
00:22:14.636 --> 00:22:15.444
Did I say Cisco?

429
00:22:15.444 --> 00:22:18.436
>> [LAUGH]
>> Linux side of things, where we have,

430
00:22:18.436 --> 00:22:21.988
it's just log server is where
all the logs get sent to.

431
00:22:21.988 --> 00:22:23.890
>> Well Cisco will connect
to a syslog server.

432
00:22:23.890 --> 00:22:26.090
So it's not out of
the realm of possibilities.

433
00:22:26.090 --> 00:22:27.152
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, that's what I was talking about.

434
00:22:27.152 --> 00:22:28.982
And then there's even a Windows client.

435
00:22:28.982 --> 00:22:33.180
If you wanted to talk to a syslog server,
you can get a client for Windows.

436
00:22:33.180 --> 00:22:38.260
I haven't tried that, see how well that
one works, but they say it can be done.

437
00:22:38.260 --> 00:22:42.140
And then IDS reports, right,
your intrusion detection systems.

438
00:22:42.140 --> 00:22:47.980
Especially intrusion detection, IPSs,
intrusion prevention is just as important.

439
00:22:47.980 --> 00:22:51.600
But remember intrusion detection
doesn't do anything about it,

440
00:22:51.600 --> 00:22:53.205
it just logs the fact that it happened.

441
00:22:53.205 --> 00:22:56.680
So you've got to make sure
you're reviewing those logs.

442
00:22:56.680 --> 00:23:00.890
Those might be network based
intrusions detection systems or NIDSs.

443
00:23:00.890 --> 00:23:05.320
They might be host based intrusion
detection systems, HIDSs.

444
00:23:05.320 --> 00:23:07.688
Need to make sure you're analyzing that.

445
00:23:07.688 --> 00:23:10.755
And then lastly we'll talk about some
of the tools that they call out here.

446
00:23:10.755 --> 00:23:18.370
SIEM in general, S-I-E-M, is a way
to centralize your log management.

447
00:23:18.370 --> 00:23:22.452
It pulls in information from
everywhere on your network.

448
00:23:22.452 --> 00:23:25.660
There are several out there
that you can gain access to.

449
00:23:25.660 --> 00:23:29.512
A lot of them have free trials.

450
00:23:29.512 --> 00:23:30.662
Alien Vault, for example, is a big one.

451
00:23:30.662 --> 00:23:34.380
>> Yeah, it's super nice cuz they
get all those cool graphics.

452
00:23:34.380 --> 00:23:37.810
You get pie charts and graphs and bars and

453
00:23:37.810 --> 00:23:39.680
the whole nine yards and
it looks really pretty.

454
00:23:39.680 --> 00:23:41.797
It's a really easy interface to work with.

455
00:23:41.797 --> 00:23:44.301
I played around with
Alien Vault a little bit and

456
00:23:44.301 --> 00:23:46.866
it just makes that daily
grind of checking logs,

457
00:23:46.866 --> 00:23:50.638
looking at IDS stuff A whole lot easier,
and a little more manageable.

458
00:23:50.638 --> 00:23:54.280
>> Absolutely, and
we've talked several times about big data.

459
00:23:54.280 --> 00:23:56.300
And this would be an example of big data.

460
00:23:56.300 --> 00:24:00.440
When you start pulling all the data
back from all of your network devices,

461
00:24:00.440 --> 00:24:02.200
your switches and your routers.

462
00:24:02.200 --> 00:24:04.890
Your firewalls,
your intrusion detection systems.

463
00:24:04.890 --> 00:24:07.030
All of that stuff starts coming back.

464
00:24:07.030 --> 00:24:09.040
Log files from your servers.

465
00:24:09.040 --> 00:24:12.060
That's a huge amount of data.

466
00:24:12.060 --> 00:24:15.390
And having some way to work with that.

467
00:24:15.390 --> 00:24:17.750
To be able to work with
that in a meaningful way.

468
00:24:17.750 --> 00:24:19.770
Being able to do big data analytics.

469
00:24:19.770 --> 00:24:22.770
That's what SIEM allows you to do.

470
00:24:22.770 --> 00:24:25.000
There's free ones, OSSIM.

471
00:24:26.110 --> 00:24:28.840
I'm trying to think of another one.

472
00:24:28.840 --> 00:24:31.880
There's many out there that
you can get access to.

473
00:24:31.880 --> 00:24:35.780
Packet analyzers,
Wireshark is my favorite one.

474
00:24:35.780 --> 00:24:38.610
Definitely not the only one.

475
00:24:38.610 --> 00:24:43.361
Intrusion detection systems,
intrusion prevention systems.

476
00:24:43.361 --> 00:24:44.180
What else?

477
00:24:44.180 --> 00:24:46.250
Resource monitoring tools.

478
00:24:46.250 --> 00:24:49.060
Yeah, some of the good resource
monitors I've worked with.

479
00:24:49.060 --> 00:24:52.380
Obviously, things like Solar Lens, Orion.

480
00:24:52.380 --> 00:24:53.350
That thing is amazing.

481
00:24:53.350 --> 00:24:56.340
It costs a little bit of money but
it is totally worth it.

482
00:24:56.340 --> 00:24:57.790
And then there's the built in stuff.

483
00:24:57.790 --> 00:24:59.370
You think Windows has.

484
00:24:59.370 --> 00:25:01.180
I think it's called the resource
monitor if I'm not mistaken.

485
00:25:01.180 --> 00:25:03.457
[LAUGH].
So aptly named Microsoft, good job.

486
00:25:03.457 --> 00:25:05.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm assuming that's what

487
00:25:05.280 --> 00:25:06.050
they're talking about.

488
00:25:06.050 --> 00:25:06.604
>> Yeah, yeah.

489
00:25:06.604 --> 00:25:08.449
And I think you mentioned TOP, as well.

490
00:25:08.449 --> 00:25:09.828
Right.
In a Linux environment,

491
00:25:09.828 --> 00:25:11.810
trying to see what's going on.

492
00:25:11.810 --> 00:25:15.490
So we're talking about
resources on a single machine.

493
00:25:15.490 --> 00:25:17.020
Obviously very important.

494
00:25:17.020 --> 00:25:19.930
Monitoring your virtualization servers,
for example.

495
00:25:19.930 --> 00:25:23.750
Because if I run low on resources, I could
end up bringing down multiple servers.

496
00:25:23.750 --> 00:25:26.150
Not just one.

497
00:25:26.150 --> 00:25:29.220
Resource monitors,
as far as your entire network.

498
00:25:29.220 --> 00:25:32.200
Making sure that
the resources are available.

499
00:25:32.200 --> 00:25:36.195
Making sure that your, I don't know.

500
00:25:36.195 --> 00:25:38.645
Seeing what's out there, just discovering.

501
00:25:38.645 --> 00:25:42.265
Yeah, SolarWinds is great when it makes
that nice graphical map of your network.

502
00:25:42.265 --> 00:25:44.345
>> It's amazing.
>> Again, costs you money, but hey.

503
00:25:44.345 --> 00:25:46.235
You get what you pay for.

504
00:25:46.235 --> 00:25:47.855
NetFlow Analyzer is another one.

505
00:25:47.855 --> 00:25:49.701
Cisco makes NetFlow Analyzer.

506
00:25:49.701 --> 00:25:53.375
We talked about that.

507
00:25:53.375 --> 00:25:58.460
SolarWinds, I'm sorry, actually makes
a NetFlow Analyzer that is free of charge.

508
00:25:58.460 --> 00:25:59.910
They've got a free one and a paid one.

509
00:25:59.910 --> 00:26:00.940
>> Yeah.
Fluke works I think.

510
00:26:00.940 --> 00:26:02.425
You can buy the Fluke devices.

511
00:26:02.425 --> 00:26:03.581
Those things are really cool.

512
00:26:03.581 --> 00:26:05.990
[LAUGH]
>> Those are some cash too, right?

513
00:26:05.990 --> 00:26:06.946
Yeah, a little bit.

514
00:26:06.946 --> 00:26:10.679
Who doesn't want to walk around with
some flukes hanging off their sides?

515
00:26:10.679 --> 00:26:14.380
[LAUGH] But, I completely forget
where I was even going with that.

516
00:26:14.380 --> 00:26:15.240
Yeah, resource monitors.

517
00:26:15.240 --> 00:26:17.770
Things like SolarWinds,
plus our built-in ones.

518
00:26:17.770 --> 00:26:19.890
NetFlow Analyzer,
I think I was getting there.

519
00:26:19.890 --> 00:26:24.460
This is where we're pulling again that
data from our switches and our routers.

520
00:26:24.460 --> 00:26:28.770
And it reminds me a lot like SNMP,
your simple network management protocol.

521
00:26:28.770 --> 00:26:29.780
But that's what you're doing.

522
00:26:29.780 --> 00:26:32.810
You're pulling back information that's
being provided by these switches

523
00:26:32.810 --> 00:26:33.830
and routers.

524
00:26:33.830 --> 00:26:35.780
Bringing it in for analysis.

525
00:26:35.780 --> 00:26:38.620
Some way to summarize it, correlate it.

526
00:26:38.620 --> 00:26:40.010
And then view it in a report.

527
00:26:40.010 --> 00:26:41.110
So, like I said,

528
00:26:41.110 --> 00:26:44.650
you can get some trial versions of
some of those NetFlow organizers.

529
00:26:44.650 --> 00:26:47.794
There are some free ones out there.

530
00:26:47.794 --> 00:26:50.450
But either way you go.

531
00:26:50.450 --> 00:26:51.170
>> Awesome stuff.

532
00:26:51.170 --> 00:26:51.730
All right, Mike.

533
00:26:51.730 --> 00:26:54.750
I think that about does it for
network reconnaissance.

534
00:26:54.750 --> 00:26:58.890
And by the way, if you just want to have
a good time, try to spell reconnaissance.

535
00:26:58.890 --> 00:26:59.840
[LAUGH] Without messing up.

536
00:26:59.840 --> 00:27:02.475
Bet your friends ten bucks they
can't do it on the first try.

537
00:27:02.475 --> 00:27:05.220
Because there's a lot of n's and
c's and stuff going on there.

538
00:27:05.220 --> 00:27:06.890
Yeah.
[LAUGH] It's an interesting word.

539
00:27:06.890 --> 00:27:09.090
That being said, it looks like we've
run out of time for this episode.

540
00:27:09.090 --> 00:27:10.860
We do thank you guys for joining us.

541
00:27:10.860 --> 00:27:13.050
We will be back with more CSA.

542
00:27:13.050 --> 00:27:14.890
Hopefully, you will join us there,
as well.

543
00:27:14.890 --> 00:27:16.330
As for this one though, we're signing off.

544
00:27:16.330 --> 00:27:18.900
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

545
00:27:18.900 --> 00:27:19.660
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

546
00:27:19.660 --> 00:27:22.174
>> And we'll see you next time.

547
00:27:22.174 --> 00:27:28.246
[MUSIC]

548
00:27:28.246 --> 00:27:32.499
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common responses and countermeasures to address network-based threats. Specifically discussed countermeasures include Network segmentation, Honeypots, Endpoint security, ACLs, System Hardening, and Network Access Control(NAC) systems.
episodes.title: Response and Countermeasures
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.301
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.301 --> 00:00:02.854
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.854 --> 00:00:05.274
>> Coming to you live from San Francisco.

4
00:00:05.274 --> 00:00:12.570
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.570 --> 00:00:14.150
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6
00:00:14.150 --> 00:00:16.430
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.430 --> 00:00:18.280
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:18.280 --> 00:00:22.310
And in today's episode we are coming
back with more of our CSA+ series.

9
00:00:22.310 --> 00:00:25.810
And, of course,
joining us in the studio Is the man that's

10
00:00:25.810 --> 00:00:29.400
trying to guide us down this,
what is it, a pedagogue, as it were.

11
00:00:29.400 --> 00:00:30.860
Our good friend, Mr. Mike Rodrick.

12
00:00:30.860 --> 00:00:31.650
Mike, welcome back sir.

13
00:00:31.650 --> 00:00:32.170
How goes it?

14
00:00:32.170 --> 00:00:33.110
>> Well it's going great.

15
00:00:33.110 --> 00:00:36.092
Word of the day, I'm gonna have to write
that one down and look it up later.

16
00:00:36.092 --> 00:00:37.800
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Awesome.

17
00:00:37.800 --> 00:00:38.440
>> Great to be back.

18
00:00:38.440 --> 00:00:40.090
I know, thanks for having me here.

19
00:00:40.090 --> 00:00:44.010
Continuing on with our good old CSA,
in this one,

20
00:00:44.010 --> 00:00:48.210
we wanna take a look at some of the
different counter-measures that we have

21
00:00:48.210 --> 00:00:53.370
available to mitigate some of the risks
that we have been talking about.

22
00:00:53.370 --> 00:00:58.160
And the first one they call out on our set
of objectives is network segmentation.

23
00:00:58.160 --> 00:00:59.850
A couple of different ways
we can go about this,

24
00:00:59.850 --> 00:01:03.210
you know when we talk about
segmenting out of network, right?

25
00:01:03.210 --> 00:01:06.680
We're throwing in routers.

26
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:13.500
We're taking our network and breaking it
down into smaller chunks doing subnetting.

27
00:01:14.795 --> 00:01:16.345
Borrowing bits, that kind of thing.

28
00:01:16.345 --> 00:01:17.565
We don't want to get back into network.

29
00:01:17.565 --> 00:01:20.985
Plus, but I know you guys are familiar
with that concept of subnetting.

30
00:01:20.985 --> 00:01:25.505
And the idea is that it does
make it a little more difficult.

31
00:01:25.505 --> 00:01:27.955
If there's a router between two networks,

32
00:01:27.955 --> 00:01:32.195
that gives me the chance to do several
things, monitor at the minimum.

33
00:01:32.195 --> 00:01:35.085
I can set rules that allow or deny so

34
00:01:35.085 --> 00:01:39.240
I can control the traffic that's flowing,
In between those two networks.

35
00:01:39.240 --> 00:01:43.770
So beyond what we learned in Network+
about segmenting a network for

36
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:46.010
broadcast traffic and things like that.

37
00:01:46.010 --> 00:01:49.540
Network segmentation has a real
security value, because again.

38
00:01:51.670 --> 00:01:54.080
We segment it by using routers,

39
00:01:54.080 --> 00:01:59.030
and routers give me that control over
that traffic that's flowing through them.

40
00:01:59.030 --> 00:02:02.740
And so system isolation, basically,
is what we're talking about.

41
00:02:02.740 --> 00:02:08.260
We can have a subnet of just our
backbone servers, where we can

42
00:02:08.260 --> 00:02:13.100
really control what traffic is allowed to
come in and out of that particular subnet.

43
00:02:13.100 --> 00:02:17.010
Our DMZ is another example of
segmenting out our network.

44
00:02:17.010 --> 00:02:19.050
Because I've got different requirements,
right.

45
00:02:19.050 --> 00:02:23.410
That DMZ has of resources that need
to be made available to the public.

46
00:02:23.410 --> 00:02:27.510
I need anonymous access coming in to my
website so people can buy my product.

47
00:02:27.510 --> 00:02:30.080
I don't need anonymous access
in my corporate network.

48
00:02:30.080 --> 00:02:34.100
And those web servers that
host my corporate calendars or

49
00:02:34.100 --> 00:02:35.930
whatever the case may be there.

50
00:02:35.930 --> 00:02:40.470
So by segregating that out, by putting
those out in that DMZ, I can now have

51
00:02:40.470 --> 00:02:45.180
different rules and different levels
of access and divide that up.

52
00:02:45.180 --> 00:02:48.340
And try to put things that have
the same security requirements in

53
00:02:48.340 --> 00:02:49.260
the same segments.

54
00:02:49.260 --> 00:02:52.210
>> Yeah Mike even if let's say
the worst did happen as well,

55
00:02:52.210 --> 00:02:55.220
it can also be a reactive
thing that we do.

56
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:59.030
All of a sudden,
somebody's computer gets a virus in HR,

57
00:02:59.030 --> 00:03:04.560
well now I can segment HR's traffic
down to maybe even just that one node,

58
00:03:04.560 --> 00:03:08.130
if not, just their subnet so it doesn't
spread to the rest of my networks.

59
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:10.680
I can just block that
off using segmentation.

60
00:03:10.680 --> 00:03:12.460
>> Exactly right that is a great point.

61
00:03:12.460 --> 00:03:15.122
We look at remediation
servers where if we're using

62
00:03:15.122 --> 00:03:17.851
some technology that does
a health check on a system.

63
00:03:17.851 --> 00:03:21.075
If it fails at health check it kicks
it out to that remediation portion of

64
00:03:21.075 --> 00:03:24.732
the network which is segregated off and
not allowed to access anything other than

65
00:03:24.732 --> 00:03:28.650
the remediation servers, so several
places you'll see that technique used.

66
00:03:28.650 --> 00:03:30.970
Another one, a term we need jump box.

67
00:03:30.970 --> 00:03:34.530
CompTIA says jump box,
usually you'll hear jump server,

68
00:03:34.530 --> 00:03:37.490
but either way, it's just a six of one,
half a dozen of another.

69
00:03:38.930 --> 00:03:43.888
Is typically a machine that is in
a trusted network that is gonna be

70
00:03:43.888 --> 00:03:47.595
used to manage devices
In an untrusted network.

71
00:03:47.595 --> 00:03:52.397
Like when I need to remotely manage
those web services out there in my DMZ,

72
00:03:52.397 --> 00:03:55.572
the server that I set up
to do that is the jump box,

73
00:03:55.572 --> 00:04:00.298
it might be the only one that is actually
allowed to go from the inside into

74
00:04:00.298 --> 00:04:03.192
that network to do those management tasks.

75
00:04:03.192 --> 00:04:05.010
It could be a physical machine.

76
00:04:05.010 --> 00:04:09.140
It could be a virtual machine
depending on what we're trying to do.

77
00:04:09.140 --> 00:04:14.460
If it's a physical box, very few people

of defense, so that, yeah,

303
00:16:06.340 --> 00:16:08.250
it doesn't stop everything,
but it stops some stuff.

304
00:16:08.250 --> 00:16:13.120
And that leaves us with a much
less of a job to try to

305
00:16:13.120 --> 00:16:17.120
clean up when things do go awry, so a lot
of things get pushed to the wayside and

306
00:16:17.120 --> 00:16:21.010
now I can focus in on the more difficult
tasks, find some software or hardware or

307
00:16:21.010 --> 00:16:24.110
whatever to try to mitigate
those types of threats.

308
00:16:24.110 --> 00:16:26.080
All right Mike, what else is next?

309
00:16:26.080 --> 00:16:27.940
>> Another term that
we've been hearing for

310
00:16:27.940 --> 00:16:30.750
a long time, A+, Net+,
I think we've talked about all of that.

311
00:16:30.750 --> 00:16:33.630
Security+ and now here as well,
is hardening.

312
00:16:33.630 --> 00:16:35.500
And that's just something we
always have to talk about.

313
00:16:35.500 --> 00:16:37.750
When we talk about hardening a machine.

314
00:16:37.750 --> 00:16:39.510
And it can be a server,
it can be a client,

315
00:16:39.510 --> 00:16:41.990
it can be a router, any type of device.

316
00:16:41.990 --> 00:16:44.860
Hardening just means we're going

317
00:16:44.860 --> 00:16:47.320
All right, we're going to

we're going to apply all known patches.

Security updates, firmware updates, and

00:17:00.590 --> 00:17:03.160
That's the idea behind hardening a system.

322
00:17:04.290 --> 00:17:05.535
So, goes to,

there's no great surprise that we're

But again,

if I'm gonna harden a server,

I'm gonna make sure that it's up to

00:17:17.482 --> 00:17:21.922
I'm gonna make sure that the only

328

All other ports and
services are closed and turned off.

329
00:17:25.192 --> 00:17:29.482
I'm gonna make sure that,
what was I gonna say.

00:17:30.562 --> 00:17:32.762
Yeah, so basic just general hardening.

331
00:17:32.762 --> 00:17:37.352
Making sure we're good, using good strong
authentication methods, all right.

332
00:17:37.352 --> 00:17:41.410
Now going beyond that a little bit, let's
talk about, then again these are things

333
00:17:41.410 --> 00:17:45.200
that I think we walked about security+

334
00:17:45.200 --> 00:17:48.870
Important concept we have to understand
when we talk about mandatory access

335
00:17:48.870 --> 00:17:54.250
control, we're talking about using
a data classification system and

336
00:17:54.250 --> 00:17:55.770
assigning labels, all right.

337
00:17:55.770 --> 00:17:59.260
So we have data that has labels and

338
00:17:59.260 --> 00:18:03.720
we have users that have labels and

339
00:18:03.720 --> 00:18:09.240
in order to access the data your label
has to match the data label or be higher.

340
00:18:09.240 --> 00:18:12.340
Again you see this in the military
a lot is where you always see it.

341
00:18:12.340 --> 00:18:18.460
Top secret, secret, confidential, whatever
the classification system you want to use

342
00:18:18.460 --> 00:18:24.170
is, but it usually involves some
type of classification of the data.

343
00:18:24.170 --> 00:18:26.340
Or I should say,
it does have to be classified.

344
00:18:26.340 --> 00:18:30.470
Because once the data is classified,
we apply those labels, now I can say Mike,

345
00:18:30.470 --> 00:18:33.010
you have a general clearance, but

346
00:18:33.010 --> 00:18:36.030
this document you're trying
to access is top secret.

347
00:18:36.030 --> 00:18:39.170
You don't have enough clearance, you're
not gonna be able to access that document.

348
00:18:39.170 --> 00:18:42.090
All right, so mandatory access control.

349
00:18:42.090 --> 00:18:46.700
You have to have the appropriate
label to get access to that data.

350
00:18:46.700 --> 00:18:49.130
We've talked about
compensating controls before.

351
00:18:49.130 --> 00:18:54.930
I said that there were, what's a good
way to put this, a way to implement

352
00:18:56.200 --> 00:19:02.210
a control when trying to think,
a certain control is not available.

353
00:19:04.130 --> 00:19:08.500
Temporary or in permanent type controls
that you might put into place.

354
00:19:08.500 --> 00:19:13.020
One of the examples,
when I talk about compensating controls.

355
00:19:13.020 --> 00:19:20.760
Let say that, what would be a good
example, separation of duties, right?

356
00:19:20.760 --> 00:19:23.770
We know that we should have
different people responsible for

357
00:19:23.770 --> 00:19:26.360
different portions of
the responsibilities,

358
00:19:26.360 --> 00:19:30.080
make sure one person can do it all
as a good control to put it place.

359
00:19:30.080 --> 00:19:33.190
But we can't because
there's only two of us.

360
00:19:33.190 --> 00:19:37.680
We all have to do everything so
I can't do a segregation of duty.

361
00:19:37.680 --> 00:19:41.368
Now what would I do, I gonna put control
in a place to make sure that one person

362
00:19:41.368 --> 00:19:46.180
isn't, using those permissions to
do more than it should be doing.

363
00:19:46.180 --> 00:19:47.450
Well, we could audit.

364
00:19:47.450 --> 00:19:49.470
Right now we're gonna have to
audit a little bit stronger.

365
00:19:49.470 --> 00:19:53.120
We're gonna make sure we pay attention
to those log files a little more closely

366
00:19:53.120 --> 00:19:57.330
because we know that we can't separate
the duties, so we're compensating,

367
00:19:57.330 --> 00:19:58.330
does that make sense?

368
00:19:58.330 --> 00:20:02.550
We're putting in place
a compensation control.

369
00:20:06.450 --> 00:20:07.440
What else?

370
00:20:07.440 --> 00:20:10.010
Blocking unused ports and
services, we've talk about that.

371
00:20:10.010 --> 00:20:11.100
I don't know what else to say.

372
00:20:11.100 --> 00:20:14.170
Hopefully yeah,
if you're not using a service,

373
00:20:14.170 --> 00:20:17.090
you should turn it off,
because it's just an attack vector.

374
00:20:17.090 --> 00:20:19.690
It's sitting there waiting for
somebody to come in.

375
00:20:19.690 --> 00:20:23.110
Way back in the day, this is before back,

376
00:20:23.110 --> 00:20:27.900
I guess this was Windows 2000,
Server 2000, was it Server 2003?

377
00:20:27.900 --> 00:20:28.760
No, Server 2000.

378
00:20:28.760 --> 00:20:36.155
When you installed IIS,
you also got FTP, SMTP.

379
00:20:37.480 --> 00:20:41.020
You got FTP and you got network new,
or you got the network time protocol.

380
00:20:41.020 --> 00:20:42.660
You got several different services.

381
00:20:42.660 --> 00:20:47.590
All I did was go in and install IIS and if
I didn't know better, I'd be running IIS,

382
00:20:47.590 --> 00:20:49.400
and I'd have my web page up and running.

383
00:20:49.400 --> 00:20:53.330
But unbeknownst to me, my server was also
listening on several other ports, right,

384
00:20:53.330 --> 00:20:55.310
that I don't plan on using,
I'm not securing,

385
00:20:55.310 --> 00:20:58.060
I'm not changing the defaults for.

386
00:20:58.060 --> 00:21:03.290
So important part of hardening a machine
is blocking unused ports and services.

387
00:21:03.290 --> 00:21:07.010
We've seen how we can use
End Map to scan a machine and

388
00:21:07.010 --> 00:21:08.640
determine what ports are open.

389
00:21:08.640 --> 00:21:12.690
Not only that, we can use that information
to fingerprint the operating system,

390
00:21:12.690 --> 00:21:16.140
fingerprint the services that are running
on those ports, gain more and

391
00:21:16.140 --> 00:21:20.030
more information, which is just
another way into your machine, or

392
00:21:20.030 --> 00:21:23.480
it's gonna aid the bad guys
in getting into your systems.

393
00:21:24.630 --> 00:21:28.978
Patching, I think we've
covered that pretty good.

394
00:21:28.978 --> 00:21:33.936
Network access control is another method
we can use, controlling how, when,

395
00:21:33.936 --> 00:21:37.400
why users are allowed to
connect to the network.

396
00:21:37.400 --> 00:21:41.970
Several different ways we can go about
this, it can be time based right?

397
00:21:41.970 --> 00:21:45.910
Let's say I'm a three shift shop,
well if I work the first shift

398
00:21:45.910 --> 00:21:51.000
should I be able to authenticate during
the third shift hours, probably not,

399
00:21:51.000 --> 00:21:55.060
I don't need to be on the system I have no
business being there during third shift.

400
00:21:55.060 --> 00:22:01.510
So maybe we set it up to where my login is
only available during first shift hours.

401
00:22:01.510 --> 00:22:05.918
Rule based, role based,
both of these setting up rules.

402
00:22:05.918 --> 00:22:11.150
Rules typically we look
at this on routers.

403
00:22:11.150 --> 00:22:15.470
When we look at network access control,
routers are rule based.

404
00:22:15.470 --> 00:22:17.690
We set up rules one after the other.

405
00:22:17.690 --> 00:22:19.120
And as a packet comes in,

406
00:22:19.120 --> 00:22:23.450
it gets inspected and it goes through
those list of rules looking for a match.

407
00:22:23.450 --> 00:22:28.020
And then he finds a match,
it's gonna either drop or allow, or

408
00:22:28.020 --> 00:22:30.880
allow secure,
whatever methods we have available.

409
00:22:30.880 --> 00:22:34.930
But it's gotta just run through
those rules until it finds a match.

410
00:22:34.930 --> 00:22:39.740
The key to remember with rule based is
typically the way these systems work

411
00:22:39.740 --> 00:22:44.540
is the first rule that matches is
the rule that's going to apply.

412
00:22:44.540 --> 00:22:49.330
And so we have to be very careful in
how we set up the rules, the order hat

413
00:22:49.330 --> 00:22:53.700
those rules appear in, can make all
the difference in the world, right?

414
00:22:53.700 --> 00:22:58.280
If you start off with allow everything,
and then you say I only wanna allow this

415
00:22:58.280 --> 00:23:00.610
traffic if it's coming from
this IP address range.

416
00:23:00.610 --> 00:23:04.460
And I don't wanna allow this traffic, and
I only wanna allow this traffic if it's

417
00:23:04.460 --> 00:23:06.350
certain times of day, or
whatever the case may be.

418
00:23:07.570 --> 00:23:08.950
Think about the rules, right?

419
00:23:08.950 --> 00:23:12.030
If the first rule says allow everything,
you're never even going

420
00:23:12.030 --> 00:23:15.100
to make it to the other rules to be
analyzed to determine whether it should or

421
00:23:15.100 --> 00:23:17.270
should not allow that.

422
00:23:17.270 --> 00:23:21.410
So you can spend all day long
writing rules and setting it up, but

423
00:23:21.410 --> 00:23:24.840
if your rules aren't in the right order,
you're not going to do any good.

424
00:23:24.840 --> 00:23:26.924
So careful with your rule based systems,

425
00:23:26.924 --> 00:23:29.554
make sure you understand
the way that system works.

426
00:23:29.554 --> 00:23:34.485
I'm not saying all of them do that but
a good majority of rule-based systems do

427
00:23:34.485 --> 00:23:38.985
process rules one at a time,
find a match, stop, no more processing.

428
00:23:38.985 --> 00:23:43.094
Now you look at anything from firewalls,
that's typically the way they work,

429
00:23:43.094 --> 00:23:47.202
you look at I Was thinking of another
example, it's not really even security,

430
00:23:47.202 --> 00:23:50.360
it really are remote access policies for
example.

431
00:23:50.360 --> 00:23:52.305
It's very important the way
we put those rules in.

432
00:23:52.305 --> 00:23:58.010
Role-based is another way we
can do network access control,

433
00:23:58.010 --> 00:24:02.980
where we create roles and
we assign access to the roles.

434
00:24:02.980 --> 00:24:07.010
And then we put people, users,
end users Into the roles.

435
00:24:07.010 --> 00:24:09.210
It makes management a lot easier.

436
00:24:10.780 --> 00:24:15.380
If somebody changes positions,
I can move them from one role to another.

437
00:24:15.380 --> 00:24:17.692
If they no longer need
those access rights,

438
00:24:17.692 --> 00:24:19.819
I pull them out of that particular role.

439
00:24:19.819 --> 00:24:26.420
Cuz nothing was directly assigned to the
identity, it was assigned to the roles.

440
00:24:26.420 --> 00:24:28.210
And then the identities
are added to roles.

441
00:24:28.210 --> 00:24:32.210
Windows right, we use group-based
permissions all the time.

442
00:24:32.210 --> 00:24:35.830
This is an example of role-based security.

443
00:24:35.830 --> 00:24:40.730
And then location-based is another
way we can do network access control.

444
00:24:40.730 --> 00:24:46.340
We want to control access based on
where you're coming from, right?

445
00:24:46.340 --> 00:24:50.020
If you're inside the corporate network,
we'll give you access to these resources.

446
00:24:50.020 --> 00:24:52.050
But if you're VPNing from home,

447
00:24:52.050 --> 00:24:54.370
you're not gonna have access
to those particular resources.

448
00:24:54.370 --> 00:24:55.340
They're too sensitive.

449
00:24:55.340 --> 00:24:58.160
I can't have you downloading
them to your home computer,

450
00:24:58.160 --> 00:25:01.760
taking a chance that there's
a cached copy on your home network.

451
00:25:01.760 --> 00:25:03.991
Cuz I don't know what security is
going on in your home network.

452
00:25:03.991 --> 00:25:08.637
Because that remote user, that sales user,
I don't want you caching this information

453
00:25:08.637 --> 00:25:11.588
on your laptop and
then leaving my secure environment,

454
00:25:11.588 --> 00:25:15.605
where you could lose the laptop,
you could connect to an insecure network,

455
00:25:15.605 --> 00:25:18.540
be compromised that way,
I have no control over that.

456
00:25:18.540 --> 00:25:20.830
I have control when
it's inside my network.

457
00:25:20.830 --> 00:25:24.238
So I'm only gonna allow you access
when you're inside my network.

458
00:25:24.238 --> 00:25:25.735
Right.

459
00:25:25.735 --> 00:25:29.303
Other location-based might be as simple
as, looking at IP address ranges and

460
00:25:29.303 --> 00:25:33.260
you see private IP addresses coming
from the outside of your router.

461
00:25:33.260 --> 00:25:33.891
Shouldn't happen.

462
00:25:33.891 --> 00:25:38.080
We know there's RFCs that should
prevent that, or don't allow that.

463
00:25:38.080 --> 00:25:41.027
And so
somebody's trying to spoof addresses,

464
00:25:41.027 --> 00:25:44.830
looking at where those particular
ranges are coming from.

465
00:25:44.830 --> 00:25:48.340
So a lot of different countermeasures
that we can implement

466
00:25:48.340 --> 00:25:52.300
to help keep our networks, and
our end users, and our endpoints secure.

467
00:25:52.300 --> 00:25:53.820
>> That's right.
Well thank you so much, Mike,

468
00:25:53.820 --> 00:25:55.064
for walking us through the list,

469

the laundry list as it were, of different
countermeasures that we can implement

470
00:25:58.830 --> 00:26:03.170
to try to offset any negativity
coming from the Internet.

471
00:26:03.170 --> 00:26:08.010
Or even some responses that also,
hey we we see a threat is coming at us,

472
00:26:08.010 --> 00:26:10.508

threat in a certain way.

473

You did throw a couple of those in there

474

>> That's right.
>> That being said,

00:26:19.140 --> 00:26:20.920

479
00:26:20.920 --> 00:26:22.670
Mike we thank you for dropping by.

480
00:26:22.670 --> 00:26:24.400

481
00:26:24.400 --> 00:26:26.930
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

A red team is typically

281
00:15:04.323 --> 00:15:07.326

283
00:15:10.130 --> 00:15:13.720

00:15:13.720 --> 00:15:17.052
We're doing penetration tests,
where our red team is coming in and

285
00:15:17.052 --> 00:15:20.695

286
00:15:20.695 --> 00:15:26.333

287
00:15:26.333 --> 00:15:29.398

288
00:15:29.398 --> 00:15:31.980

00:15:31.980 --> 00:15:34.748

00:15:38.614 --> 00:15:41.090

00:24:32.365 --> 00:24:34.238
and you think, what?

445
00:24:34.238 --> 00:24:35.677
Are you kidding me?

446
00:24:35.677 --> 00:24:40.011
Cameras, those IP-based cameras,
are a great doorway in for

447
00:24:40.011 --> 00:24:44.345
an attacker because,
when's the last time you went around and

448
00:24:44.345 --> 00:24:50.830
checked the firmware on the 50 cameras you
have around the outside of your building?

449
00:24:50.830 --> 00:24:51.450
Right?

450
00:24:51.450 --> 00:24:53.030
Have you checked it?

451
00:24:53.030 --> 00:24:54.788
Probably not.
I know I haven't.

452
00:24:54.788 --> 00:24:59.027
But, yeah, I was just getting back from
RSA and that was one of the examples they

453
00:24:59.027 --> 00:25:03.210
were using was how somebody took a,

454
00:25:03.210 --> 00:25:07.100

455
00:25:07.100 --> 00:25:09.842

through the config of the camera.

456
00:25:09.842 --> 00:25:12.105
It can figure out where it
was sending the data, right?

457
00:25:12.105 --> 00:25:14.165
It's not recording the data and
holding it locally,

458
00:25:14.165 --> 00:25:15.715
it's going back to their data center.

459
00:25:15.715 --> 00:25:19.630
How they know where it's going, and they
found a vulnerability in the NAS back in

460
00:25:19.630 --> 00:25:22.290
the data center,
which let them compromise that system.

461
00:25:22.290 --> 00:25:25.640
Which let them get to, I think,
they got into cameras there as well.

462
00:25:25.640 --> 00:25:27.826
I mean,
it was this long string of things, but

463
00:25:27.826 --> 00:25:31.472

initially the entry point to this attack

464
00:25:31.472 --> 00:25:34.915
that took someplace on a completely
different network somewhere else.

465
00:25:34.915 --> 00:25:38.723
So, understanding what you have,
making sure you're keeping that update,

466
00:25:38.723 --> 00:25:39.830
very very important.

467
00:25:41.650 --> 00:25:44.684
All right, Wes, well, that is probably,
let's see what else we got.

468
00:25:44.684 --> 00:25:47.020
I know we're getting short on time here.

469
00:25:47.020 --> 00:25:50.450
I guess the last thing I wanna mention
will be critical versus non-critical, and

470
00:25:50.450 --> 00:25:53.730
this really ties back
into asset inventory and

471
00:25:53.730 --> 00:25:55.740
understanding what we're
talking about there.

472
00:25:55.740 --> 00:25:59.740

are not, cuz this is gonna tie in as we go

473
00:25:59.740 --> 00:26:02.375
through a little bit of more
vulnerability management.

474
00:26:02.375 --> 00:26:07.820
We talking about frequency, how often we
should be doing vulnerability assessments

475
00:26:07.820 --> 00:26:13.820
and scans, prioritizing, we'll talk

476
00:26:13.820 --> 00:26:16.950
but I can't do any of that if I don't

477
00:26:16.950 --> 00:26:22.200
when it comes the time to do disaster
recovery if that ever happens.

478
00:26:22.200 --> 00:26:24.510
Understanding which ones are critical,

479
00:26:24.510 --> 00:26:29.150
knowing which ones I need to bring up
first, it could prove very pertinent.

480
00:26:29.150 --> 00:26:30.912
And it's not what you think, right?

481
00:26:30.912 --> 00:26:31.520
The oldm, well,

00:26:31.520 --> 00:26:36.470
you gotta bring up the mission critical
servers first, actually not, right?

483
00:26:36.470 --> 00:26:39.740
So, we'll talk a little bit more about
that in an upcoming episode though.

484
00:26:39.740 --> 00:26:42.607
>> I was gonna say asset inventory

a little bit more important than the Roku

>> Yep [LAUGH].

00:26:48.541 --> 00:26:50.673
>> Well, Mike,
it does lot of great information, and

00:26:50.673 --> 00:26:52.324
I know we got a lot
more great stuff to go.

00:26:52.324 --> 00:26:55.595
But judging by the clock it does look

00:26:55.595 --> 00:26:56.190

492
00:26:56.190 --> 00:26:59.466
But before we do, Mike, do you have any

00:26:59.466 --> 00:27:02.205
to throw here in part one or

two so make sure you go back and check

15
00:00:43.370 --> 00:00:46.160
So we're just gonna continue on,

16
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:48.350
The next thing I really
want to talk about,

17
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:51.960
when we talk about vulnerability
management and vulnerability scanning

18
00:00:51.960 --> 00:00:56.470
which is a big part of vulnerability
management is frequency, right?

19
00:00:56.470 --> 00:00:58.510
This is something that I get asked a lot.

20
00:00:58.510 --> 00:01:00.390
How often should we do this?

21
00:01:00.390 --> 00:01:05.330
Do we need to do this once a month,
once a week, once a quarter, once an hour?

22
00:01:05.330 --> 00:01:06.840
How often do we do this?

23
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:11.500
And really, there is no right or wrong
answer to that question unfortunately.

24
00:01:11.500 --> 00:01:16.500
I can't say that you should do it
seven times a day at 7 o'clock,

25
00:01:16.500 --> 00:01:19.900
8:15, 9:45, you know, something like that.

26
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:23.530
It really depends on
your organization and,

27
00:01:24.660 --> 00:01:27.730
how you do your vulnerability scan,
It can depend on the tools you use,

28
00:01:27.730 --> 00:01:30.860
that can change the amount
of time that it takes.

29
00:01:30.860 --> 00:01:36.330
But you definitely wanna do it more
frequently than less frequently.

30
00:01:36.330 --> 00:01:41.900
If that's a mushy,
wishy washy kind of answer for you.

31
00:01:41.900 --> 00:01:45.910
So I guess really, there's a few
things that could help determine

32
00:01:45.910 --> 00:01:48.940
your frequency in your organization
because that's what it comes down to is,

33
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:52.790
in my organization, how often do
I really need to be performing

34
00:01:52.790 --> 00:01:56.370
these vulnerability assessments,
vulnerability scans?

35
00:01:56.370 --> 00:02:00.080
And the biggest thing
that'll drive this is your,

36
00:02:00.080 --> 00:02:02.720
what we call a risk appetite, right?

37
00:02:02.720 --> 00:02:06.080
And that just means,
how hungry are for risk?

38
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:09.290
Cuz it's really good with a little
bit of butter, pan fried in salt and

39
00:02:09.290 --> 00:02:10.880
pepper, I'm kidding.

40
00:02:10.880 --> 00:02:13.160
Yeah, that was a pretty lame joke,
wasn't it?

41
00:02:13.160 --> 00:02:14.080
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it was.

42
00:02:14.080 --> 00:02:15.000
Okay, we'll move on.

43
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:17.090
I'm not a comedian, obviously.

44
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:21.030
So risk appetite,
how does your organization handle risk?

45
00:02:21.030 --> 00:02:22.960
How does it deal with risk?

46
00:02:22.960 --> 00:02:26.730
Some organizations, and even within
an organization with some things you might

47
00:02:26.730 --> 00:02:30.200
have more of a risk appetite
than you do with others, right?

48
00:02:30.200 --> 00:02:34.050
My customer information, where I store
all their credit card information,

49
00:02:34.050 --> 00:02:35.945
their personal information,
things like that.

50
00:02:35.945 --> 00:02:38.165
I have very little risk
appetite when it comes to that.

51
00:02:38.165 --> 00:02:42.595
In other words, I will do what I can to
protect that information because I know

52
00:02:42.595 --> 00:02:44.535
that if there is an exploit or

53
00:02:44.535 --> 00:02:47.735
if there's a vulnerability and
somebody does exploit that vulnerability

54
00:02:47.735 --> 00:02:51.635
that the repercussions from that could
be devastating to my organization.

55
00:02:51.635 --> 00:02:53.415
I'm gonna lose customers.

56
00:02:53.415 --> 00:02:55.545
I'm gonna lose customer's trust.

57
00:02:55.545 --> 00:02:58.175
I'm gonna lose other organization's trust.

58
00:02:58.175 --> 00:03:01.640
I'm gonna look bad in the public eye.

59
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:03.030
I'm gonna lose business.

60
00:03:03.030 --> 00:03:04.660
I might not recover from that.

61
00:03:04.660 --> 00:03:09.610
That might put my business out, which
means I have very little risk tolerance,

62
00:03:09.610 --> 00:03:11.715
or risk appetite,
when it comes to that information.

63
00:03:11.715 --> 00:03:13.795
Other systems, though,

64
00:03:13.795 --> 00:03:19.065
like my access to the building,
I've got a little more risk appetite.

65
00:03:19.065 --> 00:03:23.545
I know that ideally I'd have
biometrics and a guard walking

66
00:03:23.545 --> 00:03:28.275
around with a couple of dobermans or
what have you protecting the place.

67
00:03:28.275 --> 00:03:33.195
But the risk of somebody breaking in and
stealing stuff doesn't outweigh the cost

68
00:03:33.195 --> 00:03:36.900
of implementing those systems, maintaining
those systems paying that guard,

69
00:03:36.900 --> 00:03:40.230
paying those dogs, the liability for
the dog, all of that other stuff.

70
00:03:40.230 --> 00:03:41.230
It doesn't add up.

71
00:03:41.230 --> 00:03:44.010
So in that case,
I've got a little more risk appetite.

72
00:03:44.010 --> 00:03:47.040
So that's the kind of thing that
you're gonna be looking at.

73
00:03:47.040 --> 00:03:48.660
>> Well, another scenario I was thinking.

74
00:03:48.660 --> 00:03:50.060
I don't even know if this falls in line.

75
00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:50.635
Help me out Mike.

76
00:03:50.635 --> 00:03:54.050
Cuz maybe I've got mobile devices
cuz we know with BYOD today,

77
00:03:54.050 --> 00:03:57.790
mobile devices are very prevalent inside
of our enterprise level networks.

78
00:03:57.790 --> 00:04:00.920
And I asked a gentleman, one time,
he said he had a series of laptops.

79
00:04:00.920 --> 00:04:04.550
And I'm like do you implement physical
locks, so people can't snag these?

80
00:04:04.550 --> 00:04:07.910
He's like well,
we got remote wipe capabilities,

81
00:04:07.910 --> 00:04:11.090
we've got full disk encryption,
so we looked into that.

82
00:04:11.090 --> 00:04:13.730
It's like $500 per lock.

83
00:04:13.730 --> 00:04:16.350
I mean, the laptop's $800,
so we kinda looked at it and

84
00:04:16.350 --> 00:04:19.040
we said we're not really
getting much benefit out there.

85
00:04:19.040 --> 00:04:20.790
Would that be something you'd
be classifying as well?

86
00:04:20.790 --> 00:04:23.580
>> Yeah, absolutely,
you took a look at what the cost was.

87
00:04:23.580 --> 00:04:26.000
You're basically doing risk
assessment at that point.

88
00:04:26.000 --> 00:04:30.270
And you're looking at the impact
versus the cost to mitigate that.

89
00:04:30.270 --> 00:04:33.650
And you're balancing that, and
you're seeing if it's worth your while.

90
00:04:33.650 --> 00:04:36.910
And when it comes to vulnerability
scanning and frequency, yeah,

91
00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:38.590
that's the kinda thing we're looking at.

92
00:04:38.590 --> 00:04:42.580
My servers that have
a public-facing front end, right?

93
00:04:42.580 --> 00:04:46.440
My web servers,
my email server that sits out on the edge.

94
00:04:46.440 --> 00:04:51.325
Those guys, I scan frequently because
they're facing a lot of risk.

95
00:04:51.325 --> 00:04:53.945
And if they do get compromised,
my viewers,

96
00:04:53.945 --> 00:04:55.635
you guys out there won't
be able to watch it.

97
00:04:55.635 --> 00:05:00.755
Or you'll get some derogatory stuff that
somebody's defaced my web page with.

98
00:05:00.755 --> 00:05:03.502
That would be really bad for
our organization.

99
00:05:03.502 --> 00:05:06.772
And so the frequency of scanning
that I do on those machines,

100
00:05:06.772 --> 00:05:10.582
it's much greater than your
laptop that you use, right.

101
00:05:10.582 --> 00:05:14.152
I don't do the scans on those very often,
and then the same thing yeah,

102
00:05:14.152 --> 00:05:15.012
with mobile devices.

103
00:05:15.012 --> 00:05:21.210
These are the things, another one I
thought about was USB thumb drives, right?

104
00:05:21.210 --> 00:05:24.430
I know some organizations here in
the United States, the military for

105
00:05:24.430 --> 00:05:29.190
example, very few bases if any
allow thumb drives anymore.

106
00:05:29.190 --> 00:05:32.600
Because of the ease of
introducing malware or

107
00:05:32.600 --> 00:05:35.350
exfiltrating data with those thumb drives.

108
00:05:35.350 --> 00:05:38.390
So they just say you know what we're
gonna allow them at all right.

109
00:05:38.390 --> 00:05:43.710
Be another example of doing risk
determining what your risk appetite is.

110
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:46.720
Other organizations they
could do the same thing.

111
00:05:46.720 --> 00:05:48.290
They could block all thumb drives.

112
00:05:48.290 --> 00:05:50.530
They could check you at
the gate when you come in.

113
00:05:50.530 --> 00:05:54.070
But they've decided that it's
the benefit doesn't outweigh the risk

114
00:05:54.070 --> 00:05:57.670
because my users use thumb drives to
move data from one machine to the other,

115
00:05:57.670 --> 00:06:02.040
or take data home to work with, and
maybe that's okay in your organization.

116
00:06:02.040 --> 00:06:06.910
So exactly, those are the kind of things
that we're going to be thinking about.

117
00:06:06.910 --> 00:06:13.230
And what type of risk is your
organization willing to face?

118
00:06:13.230 --> 00:06:18.430
Regulatory requirements might
also be a guiding factor

119
00:06:18.430 --> 00:06:20.530
in the frequency of
vulnerability management, or

120
00:06:20.530 --> 00:06:24.150
vulnerability scans and
doing vulnerability assessments, right?

121
00:06:24.150 --> 00:06:29.120
You might be in an industry that says,
you have to have an outside audit done so

122
00:06:29.120 --> 00:06:33.280
many times a year, like once a quarter or
whatever the case may be.

123
00:06:33.280 --> 00:06:34.450
So it's not up to me now.

124
00:06:34.450 --> 00:06:38.720
If I wanna stay in compliance with these
industry or governmental regulations,

125
00:06:38.720 --> 00:06:42.310
I need to perform these scans
at a certain frequency.

126
00:06:42.310 --> 00:06:44.120
So it might not be my decision at all.

127
00:06:44.120 --> 00:06:47.460
It might be something that's
thrust upon us, or forced upon us.

128
00:06:47.460 --> 00:06:49.130
As a regulatory requirement,

129
00:06:49.130 --> 00:06:53.750
technical restraints can also
influence your frequency, right?

130
00:06:53.750 --> 00:06:56.740
If you've got a large network and
a large system and

131
00:06:56.740 --> 00:07:00.770
it's gonna take you a week to go
through vulnerability scans on

132
00:07:00.770 --> 00:07:04.840
all of your devices then you're
not gonna be doing it once a day.

133
00:07:04.840 --> 00:07:06.550
It would just be a little bit hard.

134
00:07:06.550 --> 00:07:10.950
There's only so many hours in a day and
you can't change that as of now.

135
00:07:10.950 --> 00:07:15.000
That might be a constraint,
where I can't do it in a single day.

136
00:07:15.000 --> 00:07:18.400
So the frequency has to
be at least a week, or

137
00:07:18.400 --> 00:07:20.120
I might have certain machines again,

138
00:07:20.120 --> 00:07:23.360
you don't have to follow the same schedule
for every single system on your network.

139
00:07:23.360 --> 00:07:28.680
You might have your critical systems
are done once a day, but your less

140
00:07:28.680 --> 00:07:32.650
critical systems are done once a week or
once a month, so a lot of different things

141
00:07:32.650 --> 00:07:36.980
that can end up affecting or helping you
decide what that scanning frequency is.

142
00:07:36.980 --> 00:07:39.990
Workflow as well,
we wanna develop a workflow.

143
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:44.578
When we're talking about this, that
information that we get from the scans

144
00:07:44.578 --> 00:07:48.234
doesn't do any good If nobody's
actually looking at it, so

145
00:07:48.234 --> 00:07:50.975
there needs to be
a workflow involved there.

146
00:07:50.975 --> 00:07:56.194
Who's responsible for going through that
information, aggregating it, correlating

147
00:07:56.194 --> 00:08:00.588
it with maybe other log systems if we
gotta seam or For doing that manually.

148
00:08:00.588 --> 00:08:01.238
Who's doing that?

149
00:08:01.238 --> 00:08:02.476
How long does that take?

150
00:08:02.476 --> 00:08:05.832
Because even if I could scan once
a day but if it takes two days to go

151
00:08:05.832 --> 00:08:09.938
through the work flow with the information
that's generated from the scans,

152
00:08:09.938 --> 00:08:12.510
then the scan on Tuesday
doesn't do me any good.

153
00:08:12.510 --> 00:08:17.069
Because they're still trying to correlate
and go through Monday's scan results so

154
00:08:17.069 --> 00:08:20.808
all those factors tie together to
determine what your frequency is.

155
00:08:20.808 --> 00:08:23.910
And there's really no one answer for
everybody.

156
00:08:23.910 --> 00:08:30.020
>> Here's the scenario, Mike, that I think
might effect the frequency of scanning.

157
00:08:30.020 --> 00:08:32.589
How about if I've got
a large storage pole?

158
00:08:32.589 --> 00:08:35.160
And I don't mean storage pole as
any kind of specific technology.

159
00:08:35.160 --> 00:08:38.580
But I've got a collection

160
00:08:38.580 --> 00:08:41.630
of my data that's getting up
to the 64 terabyte range.

161
00:08:41.630 --> 00:08:45.470
I mean, I know that I've scanned
a one terabyte home drive before.

162
00:08:45.470 --> 00:08:48.380
And it's taken a day or
two on an older system.

163
