345
00:17:32.680 --> 00:17:34.720
this is just a configuration.

346
00:17:34.720 --> 00:17:38.030
And the results, you know,
how it came to that conclusion.

347
00:17:38.030 --> 00:17:40.800
Tells me that it sent
a non-recursive query.

348
00:17:40.800 --> 00:17:41.880
And received an answer,

349
00:17:41.880 --> 00:17:45.910
which it's saying it probably shouldn't
have received an answer, right?

350
00:17:45.910 --> 00:17:48.420
So, and again, we're not here to learn
about any particular vulnerability.

351
00:17:48.420 --> 00:17:51.905
I'm not trying to point these out,
because they're common ones, or

352
00:17:51.905 --> 00:17:53.390
ones you should worry about.

353
00:17:53.390 --> 00:17:57.450
I just wanna show you how these
vulnerability scanners work.

354
00:17:57.450 --> 00:18:02.200
And what you should see is that,
you know, basic, they're the same.

355
00:18:02.200 --> 00:18:07.064
What we did with MBSA, versus what we did
with NESSUS, is we gave it an IP address,

356
00:18:07.064 --> 00:18:08.905
we let it go out, do its thing.

357
00:18:08.905 --> 00:18:12.553
We get a report back in the end,
that gives us this information, and

358
00:18:12.553 --> 00:18:16.030
now we have to analyze it and
try to make sense of it.

359
00:18:16.030 --> 00:18:19.540
The differences though you
saw between MBSA, NICE,

360
00:18:19.540 --> 00:18:24.294
free Microsoft only, versus something like
NESSUS, where it's an enterprise solution.

361
00:18:24.294 --> 00:18:26.400
And people are writing plugins, and

362
00:18:26.400 --> 00:18:30.070
this thing will tie in with
reporting capabilities.

363
00:18:30.070 --> 00:18:32.108
It's a much more powerful solution.

364
00:18:32.108 --> 00:18:35.676
You saw that we could tie
in PCI compliance, or

365
00:18:35.676 --> 00:18:39.770
other regulatory boards
that we have to follow.

366
00:18:39.770 --> 00:18:43.535
And we can get plug-ins, or write our own
plug-ins, to look for that kind of thing.

367
00:18:43.535 --> 00:18:46.990
And if we need to stay in compliance, and
we need to prove our compliance, right,

368
00:18:46.990 --> 00:18:48.695
these are the kind of things that we do.

369
00:18:48.695 --> 00:18:52.330
We've run tools like this, we get these
reports, and then when they come in and

370
00:18:52.330 --> 00:18:56.410
then do their audit, we have information
backing up our statement that yes,

371
00:18:56.410 --> 00:18:57.760
we are in compliance.

372
00:18:57.760 --> 00:18:59.730
And typically they don't take my word for
it.

373
00:18:59.730 --> 00:19:00.737
I don't know why.

374
00:19:00.737 --> 00:19:03.591
I have to show them proof,
that we are in compliance, and

375
00:19:03.591 --> 00:19:06.500
this is one of the ways we
would end up doing that.

376
00:19:06.500 --> 00:19:08.610
So NESSUS, very powerful one.

377
00:19:08.610 --> 00:19:10.780
As I said towards the beginning or
the middle of this episode,

378
00:19:10.780 --> 00:19:13.840
I kind of lost track, go out there and
play with a few different ones.

379
00:19:13.840 --> 00:19:18.860
Just familiarize yourself with the basic
capabilities, of vulnerability scanners.

380
00:19:18.860 --> 00:19:24.240
Try scanning individual machines,
scan a Linux box versus a Windows box.

381
00:19:24.240 --> 00:19:26.170
Try to do a network based scan.

382
00:19:26.170 --> 00:19:30.350
See if it does, just kind of test
the capabilities of the different ones.

383
00:19:30.350 --> 00:19:33.550
But don't spend any too much
time on one particular one.

384
00:19:33.550 --> 00:19:38.410
It's gonna be a more general
understanding, of vulnerability scanners.

385
00:19:38.410 --> 00:19:38.960
>> All right, Mike.

386
00:19:38.960 --> 00:19:41.670
Well, that's a lot of great
information on vulnerability scanning.

387
00:19:41.670 --> 00:19:44.262
And thank you for taking the time,
to not only show us the product,

388
00:19:44.262 --> 00:19:47.318
a couple of the products, but actually
interpret what we're seeing here, so

389
00:19:47.318 --> 00:19:48.597
we can make some sense out of it.

390
00:19:48.597 --> 00:19:50.229
Now, I am looking at the clock, and

391
00:19:50.229 --> 00:19:53.290
it does look like we are coming to
the end of another great episode.

392
00:19:53.290 --> 00:19:55.850
But before we do, do you have any parting
words that you might like to tell our

393
00:19:55.850 --> 00:19:57.490
audience, when it comes to
vulnerability scanning?

394
00:19:57.490 --> 00:20:00.075
>> You know there's always something
I forget to talk about, right?

395
00:20:00.075 --> 00:20:02.411
Now, not really.

396
00:20:02.411 --> 00:20:04.115
I don't know if I mentioned the fact,

397
00:20:04.115 --> 00:20:06.180
let's take a look at my
screen one more time.

398
00:20:06.180 --> 00:20:10.270
Just to show, with those scans,
I told you I could rerun this scan.

399
00:20:10.270 --> 00:20:13.216
It keeps all of your scans,
you can put them in folders.

400
00:20:13.216 --> 00:20:18.346
This kinda particular, this one, but a lot
of do this, have the same capability.

401
00:20:18.346 --> 00:20:22.870
To where I can organize my scan results,
and keep them from, again,

402
00:20:22.870 --> 00:20:26.700
reporting services for
going back and doing comparison.

403
00:20:26.700 --> 00:20:29.095
And you can kill the screen share,
I'm not gonna share that anymore.

404
00:20:29.095 --> 00:20:32.747
But yeah, the main thing I wanna point out
is, this is not something you do once, and

405
00:20:32.747 --> 00:20:33.738
then forget about it.

406
00:20:33.738 --> 00:20:36.978
You know, save these scans,
run these scans in the future, and

407
00:20:36.978 --> 00:20:38.790
then do a delta between them.

408
00:20:38.790 --> 00:20:40.230
What's changed?

409
00:20:40.230 --> 00:20:41.090
Why is it changed?

410
00:20:41.090 --> 00:20:42.350
Is this service new?

411
00:20:42.350 --> 00:20:44.220
Is this a misconfiguration?

412
00:20:44.220 --> 00:20:48.650
Those are the kinda things you can get,
by doing vulnerability scans, and

413
00:20:48.650 --> 00:20:52.500
then comparing them and
doing them frequently.

414
00:20:52.500 --> 00:20:53.910
>> All right, great information, Mike.

415
00:20:53.910 --> 00:20:55.120
Wealth of knowledge, as always.

416
00:20:55.120 --> 00:20:56.580
Thanks for being in the studio with us.

417
00:20:56.580 --> 00:20:58.570
And thank you, to you the viewer watching.

418
00:20:58.570 --> 00:21:01.320
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

419
00:21:01.320 --> 00:21:02.080
>> I'm Mike Rodrick.

420
00:21:02.080 --> 00:21:04.293
>> And we'll see you next time.

421
00:21:04.293 --> 00:21:10.246
[MUSIC]

422
00:21:10.246 --> 00:21:16.879
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike take a look at common vulnerabilities to be aware of in networks today. They will look at a few examples as well as looking at some of the components that can be exploited once vulnerabilities have been found such as server, end-points, routers and switches.
episodes.title: Common Vulnerabilities
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:06.474
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.474 --> 00:00:08.081
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.081 --> 00:00:11.769
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:11.769 --> 00:00:15.322
>> Hello and welcome to another great
episode here at ITPro TV, I'm your host,

5
00:00:15.322 --> 00:00:15.877
Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:15.877 --> 00:00:18.040
And what are we coming
back at you with today?

7
00:00:18.040 --> 00:00:21.655
About more of that CompTia Cybersecurity
Analyst+, thank you for joining us.

8
00:00:21.655 --> 00:00:22.825
And speaking of joining us,

9
00:00:22.825 --> 00:00:25.718
back at the studios today with us is
none other than Mr. Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:25.718 --> 00:00:26.840
How are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:26.840 --> 00:00:27.640
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:27.640 --> 00:00:31.220
Thanks for having me back,
excited to be here as always.

13
00:00:31.220 --> 00:00:35.930
So, today we're gonna continue on, we've
been talking a lot about vulnerabilities.

14
00:00:35.930 --> 00:00:43.110
And one of the topics for this exam is to
think about and be able to, Recognize or

15
00:00:43.110 --> 00:00:47.027
understand different vulnerabilities,
the different components on your

16
00:00:47.027 --> 00:00:51.570
network face like servers, end points,
network infrastructure, things like that.

17
00:00:51.570 --> 00:00:53.050
So that's what we want to go over.

18
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:58.120
And I kinda wanted to throw in with
this some real world examples, some of

19
00:00:58.120 --> 00:01:02.480
the breaches that have happened at least
here in the US over the last few years, so

20
00:01:02.480 --> 00:01:05.720
we can get an idea of why this is so
important.

21
00:01:05.720 --> 00:01:07.223
Why doing vulnerability assessments?

22
00:01:07.223 --> 00:01:08.312
Why we spend so much time on it?

23
00:01:08.312 --> 00:01:12.210
Why we want to make sure that we have
a good understanding of its importance?

24
00:01:12.210 --> 00:01:14.380
Why we do it periodically?

25
00:01:14.380 --> 00:01:17.220
And by showing you some of
these real world examples,

26
00:01:17.220 --> 00:01:20.200
I think that will help all of
this sink in as well as realize,

27
00:01:20.200 --> 00:01:24.420
wow dangerous, scary and
it can be expensive if you don't.

28
00:01:24.420 --> 00:01:26.460
So we'll go over a few of those.

29
00:01:26.460 --> 00:01:29.140
And we'll just start
with the one that I know

30
00:01:29.140 --> 00:01:32.380
most of us have heard about unless
you're under a rock somewhere,

31
00:01:32.380 --> 00:01:36.130
at least here in the United States,
is the Target breach.

32
00:01:36.130 --> 00:01:40.990
Target had a data breach back in,
I can check my notes, 2013 December.

33
00:01:40.990 --> 00:01:46.730
And at that point, as of December 2013,
this was the largest breach ever reported.

34
00:01:46.730 --> 00:01:48.733
Make sure we throw that little
clause in there, right?

35
00:01:48.733 --> 00:01:51.420
There might have been others
that weren't actually reported.

36
00:01:51.420 --> 00:01:53.570
But this was the largest
breach ever reported.

37
00:01:53.570 --> 00:01:56.010
And how they got in?

38
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:57.850
There is some great
white papers out there.

39
00:01:57.850 --> 00:02:00.109
If you've ever been to SANS reading room,

40
00:02:00.109 --> 00:02:02.699
I'll show you a peek of
that in just a little bit.

41
00:02:02.699 --> 00:02:05.527
You can get some white papers on
a lot of these different attacks,

42
00:02:05.527 --> 00:02:06.770
where they do case studies.

43
00:02:06.770 --> 00:02:09.476
They go back and look at what happened,
what could have been done to prevent it.

44
00:02:09.476 --> 00:02:11.880
Really great information.

45
00:02:11.880 --> 00:02:15.640
Definitely worth looking up and
taking a peruse of.

46
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:18.290
But they had malware installed
on their systems at the,

47
00:02:18.290 --> 00:02:22.460
well, say, theirs was at the point
of sale systems in their network.

48
00:02:22.460 --> 00:02:24.910
But they had a, what was it?

49
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:29.056
They had third party vendor
credentials were compromised and so

50
00:02:29.056 --> 00:02:33.599
this was, people, I wanna say was HVAC,
but don't quote me on that.

51
00:02:33.599 --> 00:02:37.020
But these were people that had access
to the network, to provide services.

52
00:02:37.020 --> 00:02:40.300
They were compromised, or
that was the way into the system.

53
00:02:40.300 --> 00:02:43.160
And they ended up getting this malware
installed on these point of sale systems,

54
00:02:43.160 --> 00:02:47.520
where they can just do grab
credit card information.

55
00:02:47.520 --> 00:02:51.070
And the way that you end up
doing this a lot of times,

56
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:53.550
and I don't know if this
case worked this exact way.

57
00:02:53.550 --> 00:02:58.710
But the user malware that does what they
call memory scraping or RAM scraping.

58
00:02:58.710 --> 00:03:01.850
And as these POS systems
process this card information,

59
00:03:01.850 --> 00:03:03.420
they load them up into memory.

60
00:03:03.420 --> 00:03:06.361
And that's in plain text and
they can scrape the memory,

61
00:03:06.361 --> 00:03:10.284
retrieve that information, and
send it back to the attacker's servers for

62
00:03:10.284 --> 00:03:12.504
cataloging, to start catching these up.

63
00:03:12.504 --> 00:03:18.620
And they had 40 million payment cards,
debit cards, credit cards, stolen.

64
00:03:18.620 --> 00:03:24.520
Ended up being, for them, they did a $10
million settlement to try to repay

65
00:03:24.520 --> 00:03:28.710
some of the users that were compromised,
the information that was compromised.

66
00:03:28.710 --> 00:03:32.582
And that's just what they did in the
settlement, that's not what they ended up

67
00:03:32.582 --> 00:03:39.195
paying in and cost to fix their network,
and cost as far as reputation goes.

68
00:03:39.195 --> 00:03:42.299
I wanna say that quarter
their sales were down 43%,

69
00:03:42.299 --> 00:03:45.675
the quarter after this
breach was reported.

70
00:03:45.675 --> 00:03:47.524
So you can imagine, I mean,
that's a big chunk of revenue.

71
00:03:47.524 --> 00:03:51.946
If your company all of a sudden
had 50% less profit for

72
00:03:51.946 --> 00:03:55.175
a quarter, could you even survive?

73
00:03:55.175 --> 00:03:57.720
And Target did but it's a lot of dough.

74
00:03:57.720 --> 00:03:59.940
Another big one was Sony.

75
00:03:59.940 --> 00:04:02.460
Sony Pictures was compromised, and

76
00:04:02.460 --> 00:04:07.020
this they believe, was actually
a state sponsored hacking event.

77
00:04:07.020 --> 00:04:11.140
The Federal Bureau of Investigation here
in the US claims it was North Korea.

78
00:04:11.140 --> 00:04:14.210
North Korea obviously denies this,

79
00:04:14.210 --> 00:04:18.440
is not admitting to it,
they say they didn't do it.

80
00:04:18.440 --> 00:04:22.410
Don't know that we'll ever know for sure,
but Sony Pictures was attacked, and

81
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:24.550
they lost all kinds of information.

82
00:04:24.550 --> 00:04:27.860
They had projects that they
were working on, big movies.

83
00:04:27.860 --> 00:04:30.220
At the time, they were getting ready to,
I don't know if you remember this.

84
00:04:30.220 --> 00:04:36.042
There was a movie coming
out called The Interview.

85
00:04:36.042 --> 00:04:37.998
If I remember the plot of the story,

86
00:04:37.998 --> 00:04:42.303
a couple of guys were gonna be going over
to North Korea, and the CIA talked them

87
00:04:42.303 --> 00:04:47.190
into using that mission as a plot to
assassinate the president of North Korea.

88
00:04:47.190 --> 00:04:52.120
And obviously, I think there was some
implications there, maybe or maybe not.

89
00:04:52.120 --> 00:04:53.968
Again, who knows who
actually did the breach?

90
00:04:53.968 --> 00:04:59.350
[COUGH] But anyway, they lost all kinds
of information about all their employees,

91
00:04:59.350 --> 00:05:02.150
actors, salaries, movies, budgets.

92
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:06.710
One of the higher ups in Sony ended
up resigning because a lot of their

93
00:05:06.710 --> 00:05:08.394
emails were leaked out.

94
00:05:08.394 --> 00:05:11.453
And some of those emails were
not that politically correct, so

95
00:05:11.453 --> 00:05:14.234
there were some issues there and
she ended up resigning.

96
00:05:14.234 --> 00:05:17.530
So it just caused a tremendous
amount of damage.

97
00:05:17.530 --> 00:05:20.570
They estimate that they wiped out over,

98
00:05:20.570 --> 00:05:22.550
I forget how many terabytes
they said of data.

99
00:05:22.550 --> 00:05:24.375
Just wiped the servers clean.

100
00:05:24.375 --> 00:05:28.151
Cuz at first, they went in and
breached and stole information.

101
00:05:28.151 --> 00:05:31.052
And then not long after that,
they actually went back in and

102
00:05:31.052 --> 00:05:32.795
started wiping their servers, and

103
00:05:32.795 --> 00:05:36.990
then posting a lot of the stolen data
out online and making that available.

104
00:05:36.990 --> 00:05:44.380
And then, not too long after that,
I think it was, Yahoo was another big one.

105
00:05:44.380 --> 00:05:50.038
Yahoo was compromised, actually attacks
that were occurring back in 2013,

106
00:05:50.038 --> 00:05:53.734
2014, and then again in 2015 and 2016.

107
00:05:53.734 --> 00:05:55.750
Have you canceled your Yahoo account yet?

108
00:05:55.750 --> 00:05:57.010
>> No, not yet.
>> I'm kidding, Yahoo.

109
00:05:57.010 --> 00:05:58.687
Hopefully, you have this straightened out.

110
00:05:58.687 --> 00:06:04.050
But 500 million users
information compromised, right?

111
00:06:04.050 --> 00:06:07.260
They don't know if it was
state sponsored or not.

112
00:06:07.260 --> 00:06:09.450
Then that was in the one in 2014.

113
00:06:09.450 --> 00:06:16.714
In 2013, 1 billion users, almost their
entire user database was compromised.

114
00:06:16.714 --> 00:06:18.750
What else was I gonna say about that?

115
00:06:18.750 --> 00:06:22.625
Ended up costing them,Yahoo!,
is trying to be sold to Verizon,

116
00:06:22.625 --> 00:06:24.992
or Verizon was attempting to buy Yahoo!

117
00:06:24.992 --> 00:06:31.170
And they ended up knocking $350 million
off of the price due to these attacks.

118
00:06:31.170 --> 00:06:35.802
Yahoo!, is also under investigation
by the SEC because of the delay.

119
00:06:35.802 --> 00:06:39.254
They didn't report some of
these attacks until 2016.

120
00:06:39.254 --> 00:06:42.640
We're talking about years
after the events occurred.

121
00:06:44.695 --> 00:06:48.035
They have 23 punitive
class action lawsuits.

122
00:06:48.035 --> 00:06:51.755
They waited, again,
a long time to notify breach victims.

123
00:06:51.755 --> 00:06:54.955
They didn't give any information
to the SEC about the breach.

124
00:06:54.955 --> 00:06:58.171
So they were in big trouble for that.

125
00:06:58.171 --> 00:06:58.724
Scary, scary stuff.

126
00:06:58.724 --> 00:07:03.985
And then, 2014, Home Depot turns around,
they've got a big data breach.

127
00:07:03.985 --> 00:07:07.630
They had, remember Target was one
of the largest ones, at 40 million?

128
00:07:07.630 --> 00:07:09.120
Until Home Depot comes along and
says, hey,

129
00:07:09.120 --> 00:07:13.770
we just lost 56 million user's
payment card information.

130
00:07:13.770 --> 00:07:18.780
They had some custom-built malware
that was introduced into their system.

131
00:07:18.780 --> 00:07:22.360
Again, they're pretty sure
it was a third-party vendor

132
00:07:22.360 --> 00:07:25.440
that put this custom malware
on their POS systems.

133
00:07:25.440 --> 00:07:29.840
Was able to steal or
exfiltrate the data that way.

134
00:07:29.840 --> 00:07:34.286
So it ended up costing Home Depot
somewhere around $62 million,

135
00:07:34.286 --> 00:07:36.590
once it was all set and done.

136
00:07:36.590 --> 00:07:38.901
And then the other one I wanna
mention was the Memorial Healthcare.

137
00:07:38.901 --> 00:07:43.880
We had talked about HIPAA the other day
in one of our previous episodes, and

138
00:07:43.880 --> 00:07:46.105
the fines associated with that.

139
00:07:46.105 --> 00:07:51.939
Memorial Healthcare Systems ended
up paying a $5.5 million settlement

140
00:07:51.939 --> 00:07:56.872
to HIPAA or whomever collects that money,
I guess it's HIPAA.

141
00:07:56.872 --> 00:07:59.463
$5.5 million for their breaches.

142
00:07:59.463 --> 00:08:00.543
They had internal users.

143
00:08:00.543 --> 00:08:04.590
And users working out of affiliated
physicians offices that had access to

144
00:08:04.590 --> 00:08:09.800
personal information and they were taking
that information and selling it out there.

145
00:08:09.800 --> 00:08:13.192
Over 100,000 individuals,
there was a former employee,

146
00:08:13.192 --> 00:08:16.650
somebody that didn't even work there,
their credentials were being used for

147
00:08:16.650 --> 00:08:20.160
over a year after the employee
was terminated, right?

148
00:08:20.160 --> 00:08:24.530
Think about that, and

00:31:44.525 --> 00:31:45.875
those wireless access points.

601
00:31:45.875 --> 00:31:47.355
>> Mike,
that's a lot of great information.

602
00:31:47.355 --> 00:31:50.275
We certainly hope you're starting
to realize that even the smallest

603
00:31:50.275 --> 00:31:54.140
vulnerability can lead up to lots of
dollars in cost for your company.

604
00:31:54.140 --> 00:31:55.630
Now, I'm looking at the time clock here.

605
00:31:55.630 --> 00:31:57.869
It does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode, but

606
00:31:57.869 --> 00:32:00.530
I'm also looking at this list of bullet
points and it looks like we have more.

607
00:32:00.530 --> 00:32:02.440
So we might have to go into a part two.

608
00:32:02.440 --> 00:32:04.260
So what do you say, Mike?

609
00:32:04.260 --> 00:32:06.597
We go ahead and
bring this one into a part two, but

610
00:32:06.597 --> 00:32:08.976
before we do do you
have any parting words?

611
00:32:08.976 --> 00:32:10.432
>> No.
I'll save them for part two.

612
00:32:10.432 --> 00:32:13.094
>> All right, that sounds like a great
place then to end this one, as always

613
00:32:13.094 --> 00:32:16.210
Mike, we appreciate having you here and
we appreciate having you the viewers here.

614
00:32:16.210 --> 00:32:18.790
Signing out for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host, West Bryan.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.011 --> 00:00:05.724
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host,

2
00:00:05.724 --> 00:00:11.940
[CROSSTALK] [SOUND]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.940 --> 00:00:15.785
>> Hello and welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV, I'm your host,

4
00:00:15.785 --> 00:00:16.455
Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:16.455 --> 00:00:17.335
And in today's episode,

6
00:00:17.335 --> 00:00:21.545
we are continuing through our series in
CompTIA's cyber security analyst plus.

7
00:00:21.545 --> 00:00:24.545
And joining us back in the studios
is none other than Mr. Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:24.545 --> 00:00:25.491
Mike, how you doing, sir?

9
00:00:25.491 --> 00:00:29.679
>> Doing great, Wes thanks for having me
back, excited to be here as always, and

10
00:00:29.679 --> 00:00:33.303
we are continuing our thought
process on common vulnerabilities.

11
00:00:33.303 --> 00:00:35.832
And looking at
vulnerabilities of different

12
00:00:35.832 --> 00:00:37.967
systems on our network face, right?

13
00:00:37.967 --> 00:00:43.440
We've talked a little bit about servers
and endpoints, we've also talked

14
00:00:43.440 --> 00:00:48.340
about the network infrastructure, routers,
switches, wireless access points.

15
00:00:48.340 --> 00:00:52.896
They're all with their vulnerabilities
that they're susceptible to network

16
00:00:52.896 --> 00:00:55.820
appliances would be next
on our list from CompTIA.

17
00:00:55.820 --> 00:00:58.294
When we talk about our network appliance,
it is weird,

18
00:00:58.294 --> 00:01:00.305
it depends on who you talk to and
everything.

19
00:01:00.305 --> 00:01:03.309
I mean, some people will say that
a router is a network appliance,

20
00:01:03.309 --> 00:01:06.250
I typically think of it as
network infrastructure.

21
00:01:06.250 --> 00:01:09.400
But it is still an appliance
on my network, so it could be,

22
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:10.220
it could fall under these.

23
00:01:10.220 --> 00:01:15.400
But when I think of network appliances,
I typically think of boxes designed for

24
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:18.340
a specific purpose which
again defines a router,

25
00:01:18.340 --> 00:01:22.250
so I'm not doing much good
from my own definition here.

26
00:01:22.250 --> 00:01:26.026
But in this case, with CompTIA,
our network appliances,

27
00:01:26.026 --> 00:01:30.332
we're gonna be talking about
things like proxies, spam filters,

28
00:01:30.332 --> 00:01:36.395
network intrusion prevention systems,
network-based intrusion detection systems.

29
00:01:36.395 --> 00:01:40.225
These are just devices, specific built
devices that kind of plug into our network

30
00:01:40.225 --> 00:01:41.675
and they do some job, right?

31
00:01:41.675 --> 00:01:44.042
That's a network appliance and

32
00:01:44.042 --> 00:01:48.780
these are definitely points of
entry into our network, right?

33
00:01:48.780 --> 00:01:53.773
When we look at proxies, a proxy server,
if you're unfamiliar with that.

34
00:01:53.773 --> 00:01:58.789
We filter all of our outbound web
traffic through a proxy because that

35
00:01:58.789 --> 00:02:03.806
gives us a chance as a network
administrator to filter that traffic,

36
00:02:03.806 --> 00:02:07.195
to control what websites
are allowed to go to.

37
00:02:07.195 --> 00:02:09.458
Hide the internal IP address range,

38
00:02:09.458 --> 00:02:13.991
we're typical doing network address
translation at that point as well.

39
00:02:13.991 --> 00:02:18.366
But that definitely becomes a attack
vector that people can use.

40
00:02:18.366 --> 00:02:21.179
A lot of times though,
it's trying to bypass the proxy,

41
00:02:21.179 --> 00:02:24.030
it's what the internal
users are trying to do.

42
00:02:24.030 --> 00:02:25.920
And that's something that,
this is a little,

43
00:02:25.920 --> 00:02:28.480
quick detour,
something I haven't mentioned yet.

44
00:02:28.480 --> 00:02:33.030
I keep talking about bad actors or
threat actors and hackers.

45
00:02:33.030 --> 00:02:36.320
I don't want us to forget that

46
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:41.200
insiders are also a potential threat
against our network, all right?

47
00:02:41.200 --> 00:02:46.544
In fact, insiders are probably
a bigger threat than what you think.

48
00:02:46.544 --> 00:02:50.691
They're probably a bigger threat than
some of your external threats that you

49
00:02:50.691 --> 00:02:53.450
are spending a lot of money to protect and
keep out.

50
00:02:53.450 --> 00:02:56.970
And then not spending a lot of
time on the insiders, right?

51
00:02:56.970 --> 00:03:00.170
Because a person inside your network,
that's what the bad guys are trying to do.

52
00:03:00.170 --> 00:03:04.940
They're trying to get into your network,
the disgruntled employee is

53
00:03:04.940 --> 00:03:08.700
already in your network as physical access
to the building has a user account and

54
00:03:08.700 --> 00:03:11.210
password they can log
on to the system with.

55
00:03:11.210 --> 00:03:15.010
So there, already halfway there, all they
have to do is escalate their credentials.

56
00:03:15.010 --> 00:03:16.440
And if it's a mismanaged network and

57
00:03:16.440 --> 00:03:21.140
all you users are admins on our own
machines, even worse, so don't forget.

58
00:03:21.140 --> 00:03:23.630
So when we say proxy's
gonna be an attack point,

59
00:03:23.630 --> 00:03:29.760
from the inside as well as
from the outside, what else?

60
00:03:29.760 --> 00:03:33.700
So for network appliances, one of
the issues you have trying to protect

61
00:03:33.700 --> 00:03:36.800
network appliances is they're
typically not open source.

62
00:03:36.800 --> 00:03:39.850
You can't get access to the code, how do

63
00:03:39.850 --> 00:03:42.750
you know that that appliance doesn't
have any vulnerabilities of its own?

64
00:03:42.750 --> 00:03:46.760
This is when we've got to buy, we've
got to use our vulnerability scanners.

65
00:03:46.760 --> 00:03:50.560
We look to see if there's any plug ins
from that particular vendor, looking for

66
00:03:50.560 --> 00:03:53.115
their best practices on
how to secure the machine.

67
00:03:53.115 --> 00:03:58.543
Cuz remember vulnerabilities is not
just just a flaw on the software for

68
00:03:58.543 --> 00:04:03.803
example, it can be misconfiguration
it's still a vulnerability.

69
00:04:03.803 --> 00:04:07.413
So if you don't know how to configure that
device, if you don't know what it's all of

70
00:04:07.413 --> 00:04:10.294
its capabilities are and
you just turn all the switches on, right?

71
00:04:10.294 --> 00:04:15.250
All the switches on, and let it go to
town what have you opened up, right?

72
00:04:15.250 --> 00:04:19.290
We've talked about that and when we talk
about hardening servers, we talked about

73
00:04:19.290 --> 00:04:23.809
only running necessary services, disabling
unnecessary ports, unnecessary services.

74
00:04:23.809 --> 00:04:27.118
Same thing with these appliances but
we have to understand them.

75
00:04:27.118 --> 00:04:29.569
All right, we have to make
sure we talk to the vendor,

76
00:04:29.569 --> 00:04:32.737
we know what it's capable of we know
what features we want to enable.

77
00:04:32.737 --> 00:04:35.362
What features we might want to disable and

78
00:04:35.362 --> 00:04:38.850
do they update their firmware regularly,
right?

79
00:04:38.850 --> 00:04:41.610
As usual then that goes
back to the other stuff we

80
00:04:41.610 --> 00:04:44.770
talked about as well with network
infrastructures, routers, switches,

81
00:04:44.770 --> 00:04:49.120
updating the firmware on those is
gonna help keep you less vulnerable.

82
00:04:49.120 --> 00:04:53.440
Because as they discover vulnerabilities
in their equipment, they will release

83
00:04:53.440 --> 00:04:57.180
patches or updated firmware that you can
apply to their systems to keep you safe.

84
00:04:57.180 --> 00:05:00.553
But if you're running an appliance you
haven't updated there for three years,

85
00:05:00.553 --> 00:05:02.895
that could definitely be
considered a vulnerability.

86
00:05:02.895 --> 00:05:06.528
>> And this ties back into something
that you taught up in a previous

87
00:05:06.528 --> 00:05:09.222
episode about things
like asset management and

88
00:05:09.222 --> 00:05:12.334
asset inventory is really
knowing what do I even have.

89
00:05:12.334 --> 00:05:16.400
Cuz I've mentioned too in other episodes
where we had to contract in on this

90
00:05:16.400 --> 00:05:19.655
one network appliance,
it was a storage appliance.

91
00:05:19.655 --> 00:05:23.097
And sure enough, when we let the service
contract go the firmware updates also

92
00:05:23.097 --> 00:05:24.622
went with that service contract.

93
00:05:24.622 --> 00:05:27.081
>> [LAUGH]
>> And, Mike, in your defense too, and

94
00:05:27.081 --> 00:05:29.707
some of the definition of some of these,
I mean, really today.

95
00:05:29.707 --> 00:05:33.166
Aren't we seeing that when we say network
appliance, you know we talk about a proxy,

96
00:05:33.166 --> 00:05:34.233
we talk about a firewall.

97
00:05:34.233 --> 00:05:37.485
A lot of these can be multi-functioning
devices, where all of that role,

98
00:05:37.485 --> 00:05:41.012
even though we're separating them
physically here or logically, if you will.

99
00:05:41.012 --> 00:05:45.176
There still could be all-in-one device,
which means you could be applying

100
00:05:45.176 --> 00:05:49.097
vulnerability scanning on multiple
levels on a single device, right?

101
00:05:49.097 --> 00:05:53.374
>> Yes, absolutely, and there's
controversy there in do you go with

102
00:05:53.374 --> 00:05:57.801
a multifunction device or do you
have individual devices to do their,

103
00:05:57.801 --> 00:06:00.590
what they are specifically designed to do.

104
00:06:00.590 --> 00:06:04.813
The multifunction of devices is fantastic,
because it got one administrative

105
00:06:04.813 --> 00:06:07.090
interface that I can go to and
I can manage.

106
00:06:08.122 --> 00:06:12.480
The downside of that is if there is
a compromise or a vulnerability in there.

107
00:06:12.480 --> 00:06:16.220
It could potentially compromise all of
the services that device is running.

108
00:06:16.220 --> 00:06:19.480
If it gets a deniable of service,
it doesn't take out just one function,

109
00:06:19.480 --> 00:06:22.190
it takes out all the functions typically.

110
00:06:22.190 --> 00:06:27.490
So we gotta weigh the pros and cons of
those multi-function devices as well.

111
00:06:27.490 --> 00:06:30.070
And then we get into the virtual world,
and

112
00:06:30.070 --> 00:06:34.010
we start looking at virtual networks and
virtual infrastructure.

113
00:06:34.010 --> 00:06:38.450
And really, when it comes to
virtualization, we've gotta think,

114
00:06:38.450 --> 00:06:42.440
it kinda depends on how I feel that day.

115
00:06:42.440 --> 00:06:46.460
One side of me says, virtualization,
when I look at a virtual machine, right,

116
00:06:46.460 --> 00:06:48.410
it's no different than
a physical computer,

117
00:06:48.410 --> 00:06:50.120
in the fact that it's
running an operating system.

118
00:06:50.120 --> 00:06:53.440
It's running applications or
services or whatever it's doing and

119
00:06:53.440 --> 00:06:57.160
all those vulnerabilities carry right
over into whether it's physical or

120
00:06:57.160 --> 00:06:57.940
whether it's virtual.

121
00:06:57.940 --> 00:07:02.450
So we really need to protect it,
just like we do physical machines,

122
00:07:02.450 --> 00:07:04.630
back when everything was physical.

123
00:07:04.630 --> 00:07:07.710
We still gotta do the same kind of things,
we have to scan them,

124
00:07:07.710 --> 00:07:11.355
we have to update them, patch them,
configure them properly.

125
00:07:11.355 --> 00:07:13.815
So in that respect,
it's no different than a physical machine.

126
00:07:13.815 --> 00:07:16.735
>> Well, what about the device themselves
that all of those virtual machines

127
00:07:16.735 --> 00:07:17.295
are running on?

128
00:07:17.295 --> 00:07:19.275
That seems like,
what you were just explaining,

129
00:07:19.275 --> 00:07:21.907
that the multi functioning device could
be a single point of failure, Mike.

130
00:07:21.907 --> 00:07:26.022
What if I take the time and I update and
do the server hardening on VM 01, 02,

131
00:07:26.022 --> 00:07:29.602
03, 04, but
then what about what they're running on?

132
00:07:29.602 --> 00:07:33.592
So that could be a single point of failure
or from a vulnerability standpoint, right?

133
00:07:33.592 --> 00:07:34.943
>> Yes, for sure, yeah,

134
00:07:34.943 --> 00:07:39.200
if you're running all of your virtual
servers on a single physical host and

135
00:07:39.200 --> 00:07:43.947
that physical host becomes a single point
of failure, it becomes an attack point.

136
00:07:43.947 --> 00:07:48.691
If I can get into the management
system of your virtualization product,

137
00:07:48.691 --> 00:07:52.908
whether that's Hyper-V or
VM Ware or whatever the case may be.

138
00:07:52.908 --> 00:07:57.666
From there I can most likely get into
your virtual machines At the least,

139
00:07:57.666 --> 00:08:01.890
I can restart them, or shut them down,
or delete them, right?

140
00:08:01.890 --> 00:08:05.080
If I can get into the management system
of your virtualization platform.

141
00:08:05.080 --> 00:08:07.207
So that becomes an added vulnerability.

142
00:08:07.207 --> 00:08:10.879
And as I was just saying, one side of me
says virtual machines are no different

143
00:08:10.879 --> 00:08:12.530
than the other physical machine.

144
00:08:12.530 --> 00:08:15.080
As far as how we have to protect them and
look at them.

145
00:08:15.080 --> 00:08:20.560
But there is added vulnerabilities
because they are virtual.

146
00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:24.240
With virtual servers,
a lot of times we're running,

147
00:08:24.240 --> 00:08:26.970
let's say you're a service provider.

148
00:08:26.970 --> 00:08:30.950
You've got multiple companies
that you're hosting VM's for.

149
00:08:30.950 --> 00:08:32.346
How do you keep that traffic segregated?

150
00:08:32.346 --> 00:08:36.520
I got to make sure company a, there's no
way that they can get access to company

151
00:08:36.520 --> 00:08:40.510
b's network and data that's traveling
across that network, right?

152
00:08:40.510 --> 00:08:43.910
It's all the same physical cabling,
but somehow we've gotta VLAN this,

153
00:08:43.910 --> 00:08:45.095
we've got it segregated out.

154
00:08:45.095 --> 00:08:48.750
Software-defined networking is the big,
big thing right now so

155
00:08:48.750 --> 00:08:49.780
that we can do things like that.

156
00:08:49.780 --> 00:08:52.090
Because we see that
vulnerability there that,

157
00:08:52.090 --> 00:08:55.960
if I can compromise one VM,
now that becomes my pivot point.

158
00:08:55.960 --> 00:08:59.951
I can start to attempt to work my
way to other virtual machines,

159
00:08:59.951 --> 00:09:03.957
potentially crossing organizational
boundaries with that.

160
00:09:03.957 --> 00:09:07.910
>> Mike, earlier, in the first part we had
talked about things like access points.

161
00:09:07.910 --> 00:09:11.640
And the fact that with bring your own
device mobility is becoming a big thing.

162
00:09:11.640 --> 00:09:14.520
But we were really only talking about it
from the perspective of the device that

163
00:09:14.520 --> 00:09:17.060
gives those other devices access.

164
00:09:17.060 --> 00:09:18.970
Help me out with the mobile devices.

165
00:09:18.970 --> 00:09:22.390
That has to be something that's
just an ever growing concern.

166
00:09:22.390 --> 00:09:24.610
Just because, it's the fact
that I can reach out here and

167
00:09:24.610 --> 00:09:26.050
I can grab my cellphone out.

168
00:09:26.050 --> 00:09:27.890
It's mine, but you, as an administrator,

169
00:09:27.890 --> 00:09:30.950
do you know if I've got
a firewall running on there?

170
00:09:30.950 --> 00:09:33.060
Do I got the current antivirus software?

171
00:09:33.060 --> 00:09:34.000
So I can only imagine that

172
00:09:34.000 --> 00:09:35.959
mobility is going to be something
we have to worry about as well.

173
00:09:37.550 --> 00:09:40.220
>> I mean, it makes me shudder,
it really does.

174
00:09:40.220 --> 00:09:43.060
Because it's difficult, right?

175
00:09:43.060 --> 00:09:46.920
BYOD, the whole bring your own device
that I think you mentioned in an earlier

176
00:09:46.920 --> 00:09:49.400
episode, everybody has mobile devices.

177
00:09:49.400 --> 00:09:51.840
In fact, Wes,
how many do you have with you today?

178
00:09:51.840 --> 00:09:52.890
>> Three.

179
00:09:52.890 --> 00:09:54.480
>> Right, and that's a light day for Wes.

180
00:09:54.480 --> 00:09:56.760
He's only got one backpack
on his shoulder today.

181
00:09:56.760 --> 00:09:59.580
And this is the way most
of our users are nowadays.

182
00:09:59.580 --> 00:10:02.410
You've got your your phone,
you've got a tablet.

183
00:10:02.410 --> 00:10:07.400
You've got your laptop, so
there's typically three with every person.

184
00:10:07.400 --> 00:10:09.563
And, yes, as you said,
how do we manage those?

185
00:10:09.563 --> 00:10:13.120
How do I make sure that
your device is secure?

186
00:10:13.120 --> 00:10:16.163
Can I tell you not to install
this application on your phone,

187
00:10:16.163 --> 00:10:19.336
because it's got known
vulnerabilities associated with it?

188
00:10:19.336 --> 00:10:21.449
Is it a company-provided device, or

189
00:10:21.449 --> 00:10:25.390
is it your own personal device
that you also use for company?

190
00:10:25.390 --> 00:10:29.480
There's legal battles that are dealing
with this, trying to figure out

191
00:10:29.480 --> 00:10:34.750
where the liability lies for some of
this when it comes to mobile devices.

192
00:10:34.750 --> 00:10:38.060
I wrote down some facts that I dug
up right before the show here.

193
00:10:38.060 --> 00:10:42.045
8% percent of companies
enforce OS updates, 8%.

194
00:10:42.045 --> 00:10:46.078
That means there's,
if I do my math right [LAUGH] 92% of

195
00:10:46.078 --> 00:10:51.380
the companies do not enforce OS
updates on their mobile devices.

196
00:10:51.380 --> 00:10:56.010
So Wes might be running a phone
that's five versions old.

197
00:10:56.010 --> 00:10:58.920
That has many, many,
many known vulnerabilities.

198
00:10:58.920 --> 00:11:01.800
And it's connecting to my
network here at work, right?

199
00:11:01.800 --> 00:11:05.880
That's an entry point, that's an access
way or an attack vector for the bad guys.

200
00:11:05.880 --> 00:11:11.280
40% of companies have missing devices,
they're just gone, right?

201
00:11:11.280 --> 00:11:14.090
Don't know what happened to them, somebody
left them somewhere, they got stolen,

202
00:11:14.090 --> 00:11:15.470
they got lost.

203

me here,
if I'm gonna try to secure this network.

651
00:36:26.590 --> 00:36:30.091
We started listing all the
vulnerabilities, and it becomes tough as

652
00:36:30.091 --> 00:36:33.665
a system admin because as a bad actor
I've got to get good at one thing.

653
00:36:33.665 --> 00:36:36.885
I'm gonna pick my favorite method
of attack, my attack vector, and

654
00:36:36.885 --> 00:36:38.060
I'm gonna work on that.

655
00:36:38.060 --> 00:36:40.899
And I'm gonna bounce around from
target to target until I find somebody

656
00:36:40.899 --> 00:36:42.460
that's susceptible to that.

657
00:36:42.460 --> 00:36:47.249
I've got it a lot easier than the system
admin that has to protect one network from

658
00:36:47.249 --> 00:36:49.091
every type of attack, right?

659
00:36:49.091 --> 00:36:53.144
So, don't get depressed,
don't get frustrated.

660
00:36:53.144 --> 00:36:54.750
You just have to do it one step at a time.

661
00:36:54.750 --> 00:36:58.030
Do your vulnerability scans,
take those results,

662
00:36:58.030 --> 00:37:02.100
prioritize, identify your critical
systems, your non-critical systems.

663
00:37:02.100 --> 00:37:06.010
Identify the vulnerabilities
with the biggest impact.

664
00:37:06.010 --> 00:37:08.210
Do you risk analysis on those?

665
00:37:08.210 --> 00:37:12.460
And work your way down, start with those,
one thing at a time, and

666
00:37:12.460 --> 00:37:15.590
just work your way down, and
you will be able to secure your network.

667
00:37:15.590 --> 00:37:17.610
>> All right, Mike,
that's a lot of great information.

668
00:37:17.610 --> 00:37:20.590
And I think I'm gonna extend
my tinfoil hat now to my car,

669
00:37:20.590 --> 00:37:22.520
put a tempest shield in
before that book arrives.

670
00:37:22.520 --> 00:37:23.490
Thank you for the carrier for

671
00:37:23.490 --> 00:37:26.290
the delay, it does give me a little
chance to install it beforehand.

672
00:37:26.290 --> 00:37:30.065
But signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

673
00:37:30.065 --> 00:37:30.972
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

674
00:37:30.972 --> 00:37:33.713
>> And we'll see you next time.

675
00:37:33.713 --> 00:37:39.772
[MUSIC]

676
00:37:39.772 --> 00:37:45.359
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike talk about the concepts to helping to determine the impact incidents has on an organization. They explore threat classification by determining known threats vs. unknown threats, zero day, severity and prioritization, downtime as well as recovery time. They will also discuss PII, PHI, intellectual property, accounting data and mergers and acquisitions.
episodes.title: Incident Impact
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.055 --> 00:00:02.376
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.376 --> 00:00:08.228
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.228 --> 00:00:11.595
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.595 --> 00:00:15.510
>> Hello, and welcome to another great
episode here in the ITProTV studios.

5
00:00:15.510 --> 00:00:16.810
I'm your host, Wes Brian.

6
00:00:16.810 --> 00:00:20.540
And in today's episode we're continuing
through in more security centric

7
00:00:20.540 --> 00:00:21.450
certifications.

8
00:00:21.450 --> 00:00:23.640
That's right,
CompTIA's Cybersecurity Analyst+.

9
00:00:23.640 --> 00:00:26.870
And joining us back in the studios
is none other than Mr. Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:26.870 --> 00:00:27.940
Mike, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:27.940 --> 00:00:28.705
>> Doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:28.705 --> 00:00:29.540
Thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:29.540 --> 00:00:31.140
Excited to be here as always.

14
00:00:31.140 --> 00:00:33.305
All right, so in this episode,

15
00:00:33.305 --> 00:00:37.409
we wanna take a look at what we
call incident impact, right.

16
00:00:37.409 --> 00:00:43.002
And I wanna go over things
like threat classification.

17
00:00:43.002 --> 00:00:46.620
Some of the things that
contribute to incident severity.

18
00:00:46.620 --> 00:00:51.047
And talk about prioritizing when we
look at responding to incidents.

19
00:00:51.047 --> 00:00:54.470
So let's start with talking
about threat classifications.

20
00:00:55.610 --> 00:01:00.035
We can roughly kind of divide threats
into at least two classifications.

21
00:01:00.035 --> 00:01:01.745
I know they're different
depending on who you talk to.

22
00:01:01.745 --> 00:01:05.005
There's many different
classifications we can use.

23
00:01:05.005 --> 00:01:07.465
But in this scenario and for this exam,

24
00:01:07.465 --> 00:01:13.255
I want to talk about known versus
unknown and zero-day attacks, right.

25
00:01:13.255 --> 00:01:15.795
And it's an interesting
concept when you look at

26
00:01:15.795 --> 00:01:18.245
known versus unknown, first of all.

27
00:01:18.245 --> 00:01:23.470
Because if you really stop and think about
it, known versus unknown has nothing to

28
00:01:23.470 --> 00:01:26.260
do with the object itself,
right, with the vulnerability.

29
00:01:26.260 --> 00:01:28.250
With the exploit, I should say.

30
00:01:29.380 --> 00:01:31.980
It doesn't know whether it's known or
unknown.

31
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:36.202
It's the examiner that either knows
about it or doesn't know about it.

32
00:01:36.202 --> 00:01:40.540
Or it's the vulnerability scanner that
knows about it or doesn't know about it.

33
00:01:40.540 --> 00:01:41.409
It's not the object itself.

34
00:01:41.409 --> 00:01:43.560
Which I always thought was interesting.

35
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:47.210
But they're either known or
unknown, but it's very subjective.

36
00:01:47.210 --> 00:01:49.180
It depends on your point of view, right.

37
00:01:49.180 --> 00:01:52.350
Everything starts out as unknown.

38
00:01:52.350 --> 00:01:55.500
It has to be discovered by someone or
something.

39
00:01:55.500 --> 00:02:00.340
Some algorithm is doing research, or
some human that's doing research,

40
00:02:00.340 --> 00:02:03.410
discovers this new exploit
that's being used.

41
00:02:03.410 --> 00:02:05.872
Well, before that person did that,
it was unknown.

42
00:02:05.872 --> 00:02:10.140
And now it's known, but only known by
that one person and that one system.

43
00:02:10.140 --> 00:02:15.720
And that is gonna slowly propagate to
more and more systems and information.

44
00:02:15.720 --> 00:02:18.070
That fact that it's known, right.

45
00:02:18.070 --> 00:02:20.950
Once, say, one of those big
companies gets ahold of it

46
00:02:20.950 --> 00:02:24.190
they can maybe write some patch or
some way to protect against it.

47
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:28.030
It becomes known to them, they patch
systems, now the systems know about it.

48
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:30.200
Or with the case of a virus or a worm,

49
00:02:30.200 --> 00:02:35.240
once your antivirus vendors write
definitions for it, it's now known.

50
00:02:35.240 --> 00:02:38.250
And so we can try to protect
our systems from that.

51
00:02:38.250 --> 00:02:41.740
But everything really
started out as unknown.

52
00:02:41.740 --> 00:02:44.850
>> Mike, is this something that we can see
in things like those threat analysis maps?

53
00:02:44.850 --> 00:02:47.530
I know Intel/McAfee has
them from time to time.

54
00:02:47.530 --> 00:02:48.340
They find them, right?

55
00:02:48.340 --> 00:02:51.180
And they'll show you a map of the world,
and almost like a heat map, right?

56
00:02:51.180 --> 00:02:54.110
And you can see areas of the world
where they know about it,

57
00:02:54.110 --> 00:02:57.030
but maybe I'm in an area of the world
that they don't know about it.

58
00:02:57.030 --> 00:03:00.970
So to me, it's still unknown, where to you
and your company, maybe in that red zone,

59
00:03:00.970 --> 00:03:03.640
hopefully not [LAUGH],
know about that already.

60
00:03:03.640 --> 00:03:05.260
>> Yeah,
I can see you looking at it that way.

61
00:03:05.260 --> 00:03:08.132
Really, if the heat map, whatever
you're using for that knows about it,

62
00:03:08.132 --> 00:03:09.097
then it's It's known.

63
00:03:09.097 --> 00:03:12.010
It might not be known by you,
but it's known to somebody, so

64
00:03:12.010 --> 00:03:13.280
it's considered known.

65
00:03:13.280 --> 00:03:16.180
It's just that you haven't
gained the knowledge yet,

66
00:03:16.180 --> 00:03:17.530
I guess is a way to look at it.

67
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:18.462
But yeah, absolutely.

68
00:03:18.462 --> 00:03:20.680
So, and
I always just thought that was funny.

69
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:24.000
But anyway, so everything starts
out as known, very subjective.

70
00:03:24.000 --> 00:03:25.320
Becomes known.

71
00:03:25.320 --> 00:03:30.300
Nowadays we look at trying to, a lot of
software vendors out there are claiming

72
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:37.110
that their software or their devices can
protect you against unknown attacks.

73
00:03:37.110 --> 00:03:38.260
How the heck are you gonna do that?

74
00:03:38.260 --> 00:03:41.030
You don't know about it,
how are you gonna detect it?

75
00:03:41.030 --> 00:03:45.913
Dynamic analysis, they've got algorithms
that can examine payloads and look for

76
00:03:45.913 --> 00:03:49.972
what could potentially be malicious
behavior, it's pretty neat.

77
00:03:49.972 --> 00:03:53.475
So they really can help protect
against unknown attacks.

78
00:03:53.475 --> 00:03:57.076
That's another one, when you first think
about it, it's like, how can you possibly

79
00:03:57.076 --> 00:03:59.754
sell me something that's gonna
protect me from unknown stuff?

80
00:03:59.754 --> 00:04:03.095
Well, there's incredible
algorithms they use.

81
00:04:03.095 --> 00:04:06.500
Doing dynamic analysis,
doing static analysis.

82
00:04:06.500 --> 00:04:09.780
They can actually attempt,
they're not gonna stop everything,

83
00:04:09.780 --> 00:04:14.240
but they can definitely cut down
on the number of unknown or

84
00:04:14.240 --> 00:04:17.430
what we might call zero-day attacks.

85
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:19.770
Mike, I wonder if this
falls in line with that.

86
00:04:19.770 --> 00:04:22.890
I've seen like for instance the Windows
Defender platform that's inside of your

87
00:04:22.890 --> 00:04:24.340
Windows operating systems today.

88
00:04:24.340 --> 00:04:26.571
They have things like sample submissions,
and

89
00:04:26.571 --> 00:04:29.805
you can combine that with things
like the cloud-based solutions and

90
00:04:29.805 --> 00:04:33.162
stuff where maybe another company
has already kinda learned about it.

91
00:04:33.162 --> 00:04:36.490
And it's, like you said, it's dynamic.

92
00:04:36.490 --> 00:04:39.424
It's the fact that we can
constantly check these avenues and

93
00:04:39.424 --> 00:04:41.599
see if they're updating in real time.

94
00:04:41.599 --> 00:04:42.409
>> Absolutely.

95
00:04:42.409 --> 00:04:46.670
When I was at the, you go to some of these
security conferences and things like that.

96
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:48.668
You see some of the products
that are getting rolled out.

97
00:04:48.668 --> 00:04:50.746
And they're just amazing
at what they can do.

98
00:04:50.746 --> 00:04:53.170
They just get better and
better every year.

99
00:04:53.170 --> 00:04:54.685
The cloud has definitely
changed a lot of things.

100
00:04:54.685 --> 00:04:59.020
A lot of our antivirus solutions,
as you were saying, is now cloud-based.

101
00:04:59.020 --> 00:05:01.666
It's a service that we subscribe to.

102
00:05:01.666 --> 00:05:05.004
I was looking at some software that's
supposed to protect from ransomware, and

103
00:05:05.004 --> 00:05:07.320
I think, wow,
that's going to be difficult, right?

104
00:05:07.320 --> 00:05:10.995
And it's not that it can really stop
it completely, but they do backups,

105
00:05:10.995 --> 00:05:13.603
several backups, and
they compare backup states,

106
00:05:13.603 --> 00:05:16.171
and they're looking at the metadata,
the files.

107
00:05:16.171 --> 00:05:19.394
And they can detect immediately
when something is changed, and

108
00:05:19.394 --> 00:05:21.542
at least get that system
off the network and

109
00:05:21.542 --> 00:05:24.760
maybe prevent that ransomware
from spreading out.

110
00:05:24.760 --> 00:05:27.750
>> Mike, you mentioned a term here,
and help me out with it.

111
00:05:27.750 --> 00:05:30.440
You mentioned zero day,
what does zero day really mean?

112
00:05:30.440 --> 00:05:33.060
For our viewers out there,
I'm kinda wondering.

113
00:05:33.060 --> 00:05:39.950
>> It's what we call an undisclosed avenue
of attack or an undisclosed vulnerability.

114
00:05:39.950 --> 00:05:44.610
And if you are unfortunate enough
to be the first one that this,

115
00:05:44.610 --> 00:05:49.070
let's say I write some malware,
and I release that out there.

116
00:05:50.260 --> 00:05:51.430
It's unknown, right?

117
00:05:51.430 --> 00:05:52.462
Nobody knows about it yet.

118
00:05:52.462 --> 00:05:54.299
And if you are my first target,

119
00:05:54.299 --> 00:05:58.760
you are going to be the victim of
what's called a zero-day attack.

120
00:05:58.760 --> 00:06:02.030
Because you're getting attacked by
something that nobody has ever seen.

121
00:06:02.030 --> 00:06:06.050
And what these bad actors are doing is,
that's what they're trying to do,

122
00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:09.550
they want to write unknown exploits.

123
00:06:09.550 --> 00:06:14.370
They don't want known exploits,
because they're gonna get caught.

124
00:06:14.370 --> 00:06:17.750
The attack is not gonna work nearly
as well, because it's known.

125
00:06:17.750 --> 00:06:19.260
There's software that can stop them.

126
00:06:20.610 --> 00:06:25.240
So how does one bad actor,
if you were, go about creating

127
00:06:25.240 --> 00:06:29.540
an unknown vulnerability that's capable
of launching a zero-day attack?

128
00:06:29.540 --> 00:06:35.080
You run your own malware through those
engines, and see if they light up.

129
00:06:35.080 --> 00:06:39.514
And if they don't, now you know you've
got something that they don't know about,

130
00:06:39.514 --> 00:06:42.709
that even their dynamic analysis
maybe does not detect yet.

131
00:06:42.709 --> 00:06:46.924
And you've, if I can say this,
as a bad actor, you've done a good job,

132
00:06:46.924 --> 00:06:49.540
because you've written something now.

133
00:06:49.540 --> 00:06:54.370
But they do, they test their own stuff
against these different engines to try and

134
00:06:54.370 --> 00:06:59.034
come up with a way to slip this malware
in without being detected, and without

135
00:06:59.034 --> 00:07:02.990
setting off all the IDSs and without
setting off your antivirus solutions and

136
00:07:02.990 --> 00:07:04.840
your alarms and things like that.

137
00:07:04.840 --> 00:07:06.060
That's their goal.

138
00:07:06.060 --> 00:07:09.020
>> And Mike, we're not always dealing
with things like script kiddies, right?

139
00:07:09.020 --> 00:07:12.580
Just little programs somebody else
wrote out there, very easy to detect.

140
00:07:12.580 --> 00:07:16.040
Sometimes, I mean, these hackers,
they really know what they're doing.

141
00:07:16.040 --> 00:07:19.399
When we have things that go beyond just
the, I can identify it quickly and

142
00:07:19.399 --> 00:07:20.441
easily, right.

143
00:07:20.441 --> 00:07:21.072
>> Absolutely.

144
00:07:21.072 --> 00:07:25.532
And one more thing before we can move on
from zero day, I wanted to mention too,

145
00:07:25.532 --> 00:07:27.572
active before publicly reported.

146
00:07:27.572 --> 00:07:30.890
And there's kind of a weird
little catch with that one.

147
00:07:30.890 --> 00:07:33.370
Because if it hasn't
been publicly reported,

148
00:07:33.370 --> 00:07:36.170
doesn't mean that somebody
doesn't know about it.

149
00:07:36.170 --> 00:07:40.110
So a zero-day doesn't necessarily
have to be unknown, right?

150
00:07:40.110 --> 00:07:46.685
If a vendor finds a vulnerability in their
software or whatever the product is.

151
00:07:46.685 --> 00:07:51.108
They’re going to try to create a patch for
it so that they can release that.

152
00:07:51.108 --> 00:07:53.938
And their idea is that We're not gonna

153
00:07:53.938 --> 00:07:58.189
release information about
what this vulnerability is.

154
00:07:58.189 --> 00:08:01.439
We're gonna give ourselves some
time to create a fix for it,

155
00:08:01.439 --> 00:08:03.360
before we tell everybody about it.

156
00:08:03.360 --> 00:08:06.690
That way we can say, hey look,
here's the problem, here's the patch.

157
00:08:06.690 --> 00:08:09.630
So as soon as you know about it,
there's a patch available for it, and

158
00:08:09.630 --> 00:08:10.590
you can protect your system.

159
00:08:10.590 --> 00:08:13.640
Cuz if I come out and say,
hey here's the problem we have,

160
00:08:13.640 --> 00:08:15.396
we don't have a patch for it yet.

161
00:08:15.396 --> 00:08:18.840
Well the bad actors are gonna be
on those same bug tracked threads.

162
00:08:18.840 --> 00:08:20.300
They're gonna see that vulnerability.

163
00:08:20.300 --> 00:08:21.460
They're gonna write exploits for

164
00:08:21.460 --> 00:08:23.870
it to take advantage of it before
they get the patch out, right?

165
00:08:23.870 --> 00:08:27.660
So that's the cat and mouse game
that the vendors will try to play.

166
00:08:27.660 --> 00:08:32.418
So I just want you to understand too,
zero day means it's active before

167
00:08:32.418 --> 00:08:36.078
it's publicly reported,
not necessarily unknown.

168
00:08:36.078 --> 00:08:41.580
All right and then to your point, Wes,
yes, one of the things that we see now.

169
00:08:41.580 --> 00:08:44.200
And I think we've mentioned
this in a previous episode.

170
00:08:44.200 --> 00:08:47.440
Is something known as
advanced persistent threat.

171
00:08:47.440 --> 00:08:53.630
This is becoming a more common attack
methodology that we're seeing.

172
00:08:53.630 --> 00:08:56.070
It's no longer just a smash and grab.

173
00:08:57.390 --> 00:09:01.120
By the time you've realized,
once you've realized you've had a breach.

174
00:09:01.120 --> 00:09:02.757
You go and start doing your research and

175
00:09:02.757 --> 00:09:05.198
you find out the breach actually
occurred six months ago.

176
00:09:05.198 --> 00:09:08.475
And that they've been in your system and
doing gosh knows what and

177
00:09:08.475 --> 00:09:10.025
got access to who knows what for

178
00:09:10.025 --> 00:09:13.600
the last six months before you
finally detected their activity.

179
00:09:13.600 --> 00:09:16.486
This is what we call
an advanced persistent threat.

180
00:09:16.486 --> 00:09:21.222
And it is basically that the bad
actors are picking a specific target

181
00:09:21.222 --> 00:09:25.890
that they want to compromise or
information that they want to get.

182
00:09:25.890 --> 00:09:28.934
They are not just going in and
seeing what's quickly available,

183
00:09:28.934 --> 00:09:31.930
easily accessible and going for
the low hanging fruit.

184
00:09:31.930 --> 00:09:34.470
They're like, we know we can get
into your organizations network.

185
00:09:34.470 --> 00:09:35.540
We're already in.

186
00:09:35.540 --> 00:09:36.850
We've got our back door setup.

187
00:09:36.850 --> 00:09:40.010
We're hidden, we've got accounts
created that we can use.

188
00:09:40.010 --> 00:09:43.340
Now we just gotta figure out how we can
escalate these accounts to get access to

189
00:09:43.340 --> 00:09:44.230
the data we need.

190
00:09:44.230 --> 00:09:48.710
Or wait for somebody to move that
data across the network so we can or

191
00:09:48.710 --> 00:09:50.470
whatever the case may be.

192
00:09:50.470 --> 00:09:54.622
They're just sitting there and they're
continuously monitoring and looking and

193
00:09:54.622 --> 00:09:58.700
seeing what they can get and
these are typically highly trained people.

194
00:09:58.700 --> 00:10:02.973
In fact, a lot of this is state sponsored
when you look at advance persistent threat

195
00:10:02.973 --> 00:10:05.855
because it takes almost
a management team to manage it.

196
00:10:05.855 --> 00:10:09.584
You've got a lot of different moving
parts and trying to remain undetected and

197
00:10:09.584 --> 00:10:10.670
keep the access open.

198
00:10:11.960 --> 00:10:17.050
There are occurences, I've read
about these where there was a whole

199
00:10:17.050 --> 00:10:21.790
team of people involved that had
management, and they had schedules

200
