That's a problem.

488
00:26:55.780 --> 00:26:59.280
People get excited,
people make knee jerk reactions.

489
00:26:59.280 --> 00:27:05.165
And things don't go as smoothly as
they would have, if we had a plan,

490
00:27:05.165 --> 00:27:10.340
if we had practiced that plan over and
over until we had it down pat.

491
00:27:10.340 --> 00:27:13.650
Knew what our role was within the plan,
knew what our responsibilities,

492
00:27:13.650 --> 00:27:16.540
expectations were, knew who we were
supposed to report to, notify,

493
00:27:16.540 --> 00:27:20.050
what we were supposed to collect,
all of that information goes in there.

494
00:27:20.050 --> 00:27:22.800
>> Mike, that sounds a lot like I'm
hearing some similarities between

495
00:27:22.800 --> 00:27:25.220
things like disaster recovery policies and
plans, right.

496
00:27:25.220 --> 00:27:28.434
We wanna know what has to go on first,
rather than waiting for it to happen and

497
00:27:28.434 --> 00:27:30.357
then trying to figure
it out the last second.

498
00:27:30.357 --> 00:27:33.510
So it sounds like this was really,
really running close to in line.

499
00:27:33.510 --> 00:27:36.540
You wanna know where everything is,
and have everything in place.

500
00:27:36.540 --> 00:27:39.040
So that when things do go hectic,

501
00:27:39.040 --> 00:27:40.740
you don't have to think
about it ahead of time.

502
00:27:40.740 --> 00:27:42.820
>> Absolutely,
it's exactly the same thing.

503
00:27:42.820 --> 00:27:43.650
That's a great point.

504
00:27:43.650 --> 00:27:46.830
When you do your disaster recovery plans,
you do them ahead of time.

505
00:27:46.830 --> 00:27:49.396
You test them, and
you repeatedly test them, right?

506
00:27:49.396 --> 00:27:50.770
You don't do it just once.

507
00:27:50.770 --> 00:27:54.610
Periodically go back and test it,
revise it, because things change.

508
00:27:54.610 --> 00:27:57.590
Contact points change, and I need to know.

509
00:27:57.590 --> 00:28:01.800
If I don't ever test it, I'm not going to
know if I missed anything in my policy,

510
00:28:01.800 --> 00:28:03.500
in my incident response plan.

511
00:28:03.500 --> 00:28:06.920
Hey look,
we forgot to notify the CEO, whoops.

512
00:28:06.920 --> 00:28:08.600
That's probably not gonna be good.

513
00:28:08.600 --> 00:28:14.090
Or we forgot to include the phone numbers
for the cyber crime task force for

514
00:28:14.090 --> 00:28:16.570
the local police, things like that.

515
00:28:16.570 --> 00:28:19.934
So by testing it, it gives you a chances
to go through and work out any kinks.

516
00:28:19.934 --> 00:28:23.310
Kinda iron it out a little bit,
update it if necessary,

517
00:28:23.310 --> 00:28:27.000
modify it as our systems and
our needs change.

518
00:28:27.000 --> 00:28:28.490
>> Mike,
that's a lot of great information.

519
00:28:28.490 --> 00:28:29.260
I'll tell you what though,

520
00:28:29.260 --> 00:28:32.870
I'm looking a list of bullet points
here and I know he is not done yet.

521
00:28:32.870 --> 00:28:35.530
But we're gonna have to be done for
this episode unfortunately,

522
00:28:35.530 --> 00:28:37.280
because it looks like we
are running out of time.

523
00:28:37.280 --> 00:28:39.245
Mike, do you got anything else
you'd like to throw in this one?

524
00:28:39.245 --> 00:28:40.774
Are we gonna give them
the Mike cliffhanger, or

525
00:28:40.774 --> 00:28:42.170
maybe save it for a part two?

526
00:28:42.170 --> 00:28:44.870
>> Well, I tell you, Wes,
we don't have that much more.

527
00:28:44.870 --> 00:28:47.580
>> Let's go ahead and
run a little long, that's okay.

528
00:28:47.580 --> 00:28:48.215
>> Okay.
>> Yeah, let's do that.

529
00:28:48.215 --> 00:28:50.615
>> [CROSSTALK] Because again,
I'm not gonna demo anything just yet.

530
00:28:50.615 --> 00:28:53.890
I'm gonna save that towards the end
when we get into the last part of

531
00:28:53.890 --> 00:28:54.780
the objectives.

532
00:28:54.780 --> 00:28:57.483
When we start calling out
the individual tools, I'll go back and

533
00:28:57.483 --> 00:28:59.850
tie it back in to what
we're talking about here.

534
00:28:59.850 --> 00:29:03.400
Cuz really, the only thing we have left
to talk about, I know my list looks long.

535
00:29:03.400 --> 00:29:07.190
But call list, escalation list,
these are going to be important.

536
00:29:07.190 --> 00:29:11.870
This is who you notify, should be
part of our incident response plan.

537
00:29:11.870 --> 00:29:14.640
Should be part of our
forensics kit as well.

538
00:29:14.640 --> 00:29:19.150
Who do I notify when I
suspect an incident occurs?

539
00:29:19.150 --> 00:29:20.310
I was teasing about the CEO,

540
00:29:20.310 --> 00:29:25.030
the CEO is probably not going
to be on that initial call list.

541
00:29:25.030 --> 00:29:28.676
Because until we know there has
been a breach or an incident, and

542
00:29:28.676 --> 00:29:32.795
that it's not just spam, or
something broke, or something like that,

543
00:29:32.795 --> 00:29:35.244
we're probably not going to notify them.

544
00:29:35.244 --> 00:29:38.170
But we do have our incident response
team that we need to notify.

545
00:29:38.170 --> 00:29:42.880
We probably notify our CISO,
our chief information security officer.

546
00:29:42.880 --> 00:29:46.220
Or maybe we don't,
maybe we notify somebody under him or her.

547
00:29:46.220 --> 00:29:49.441
And then if they determine necessary,
they notify that person.

548
00:29:49.441 --> 00:29:53.502
So the call list is all the numbers and
the priorities of things I need to,

549
00:29:53.502 --> 00:29:55.040
people I need to notify.

550
00:29:55.040 --> 00:30:01.665
It can also be vendor information as well,
when we talk about that call list.

551
00:30:01.665 --> 00:30:06.447
Because if there is an incident and
I don't have access to my own information,

552
00:30:06.447 --> 00:30:11.155
how do I know the numbers for where our
backup data is stored if I can't get into

553
00:30:11.155 --> 00:30:14.965
the office,
if I can't get access to my information?

554
00:30:14.965 --> 00:30:17.415
They don't have Rolodexes
that much anymore.

555
00:30:17.415 --> 00:30:19.195
I know some of you are like,
what the heck's a Rolodex?

556
00:30:20.760 --> 00:30:21.988
Use your search engine, find out.

557
00:30:21.988 --> 00:30:24.640
And you go, wow he really is old!

558
00:30:24.640 --> 00:30:27.300
But everything, we might not have access.

559
00:30:27.300 --> 00:30:30.830
I don't have my contacts in my phone and
how do I have that number?

560
00:30:30.830 --> 00:30:34.450
So making sure you have got
that information somewhere.

561
00:30:34.450 --> 00:30:38.297
When they talk about a forensics
investigation suite, again,

562
00:30:38.297 --> 00:30:41.590
we'll talk about some
specific tools later on.

563
00:30:41.590 --> 00:30:45.050
But we're gonna need imaging utilities,
because I need to duplicate media.

564
00:30:45.050 --> 00:30:47.850
So as I talked about earlier,
we need to duplicate that so

565
00:30:47.850 --> 00:30:49.050
we can do our analysis on it.

566
00:30:49.050 --> 00:30:51.480
We never work with the original media.

567
00:30:51.480 --> 00:30:53.410
You need analysis utilities.

568
00:30:53.410 --> 00:30:56.990
Once I've done that memory scrape,
it's not human-readable, right?

569
00:30:56.990 --> 00:30:59.300
I've gotta somehow work
with that information.

570
00:30:59.300 --> 00:31:03.720
So we'll need analysis tools to
decode that information for us.

571
00:31:03.720 --> 00:31:05.300
Unless you're like the Matrix, and

572
00:31:05.300 --> 00:31:08.600
you can read the hex as it's
flowing across your screen.

573
00:31:08.600 --> 00:31:10.250
A chain of custody, we talked about that.

574
00:31:10.250 --> 00:31:11.970
That needs to be in there.

575
00:31:11.970 --> 00:31:17.156
Hashing utilities, when I make those
duplications of the media, I run both

576
00:31:17.156 --> 00:31:22.356
of them through a hashing algorithm
to verify they're identical, right.

577
00:31:22.356 --> 00:31:25.540
I'm sure you know about hashing
algorithms at this point.

578
00:31:25.540 --> 00:31:27.160
If you don't, a quick rehash.

579
00:31:27.160 --> 00:31:30.680
A hashing algorithm is a one-way

580
00:31:30.680 --> 00:31:34.210
encryption that generates a hash
value when you run data through it.

581
00:31:34.210 --> 00:31:37.250
So you run that hard drive
through a hashing algorithm and

582
00:31:37.250 --> 00:31:38.780
it generates an output.

583
00:31:38.780 --> 00:31:41.761
Every time you run that hard drive
through that hashing algorithm,

584
00:31:41.761 --> 00:31:44.859
it should generate the exact same
output if it hasn't been modified.

585
00:31:44.859 --> 00:31:48.777
Modify one little thing, and it's
gonna generate a different hash value.

586
00:31:48.777 --> 00:31:52.118
So when I take my copy, and
I run it through the hashing algorithm,

587
00:31:52.118 --> 00:31:55.718
They'd better make identical hash values,
or something went wrong.

588
00:31:55.718 --> 00:31:58.836
So we need those kind of things to do,
to verify hard drives or

589
00:31:58.836 --> 00:32:03.280
verify individual files integrity,
that we haven't modified those.

590
00:32:03.280 --> 00:32:06.810
OS and process analysis,
we can go through and see what's running.

591
00:32:06.810 --> 00:32:11.799
What hidden things are running that might
are showing up in your nice little GUI

592
00:32:11.799 --> 00:32:12.790
task manager?

593
00:32:12.790 --> 00:32:14.523
And we need mobile device forensics.

594
00:32:14.523 --> 00:32:19.500
There's a whole, not brand new but
a big expanding area of doing forensics

595
00:32:19.500 --> 00:32:23.687
on mobile devices where we're
gonna need a little bit of that,

596
00:32:23.687 --> 00:32:27.953
especially if we have company
issued phones or mobile devices.

597
00:32:27.953 --> 00:32:30.680
You need to be able to investigate those.

598
00:32:30.680 --> 00:32:36.363
Password crackers, we'll take a look later
on at something like LOphtCrack, or Cain &

599
00:32:36.363 --> 00:32:41.693
Abel, or John the Ripper, several password
crackers, and you should have many.

600
00:32:41.693 --> 00:32:46.555
You should have some to do online password
cracking against maybe websites or

601
00:32:46.555 --> 00:32:51.214
if you dump hashes, how are you're
gonna try and crack those passwords?

602
00:32:51.214 --> 00:32:55.915
I'm trying to get access to a person's
system, trying to get access to encrypted

603
00:32:55.915 --> 00:32:59.267
files, or that are password-protected,
I should say.

604
00:32:59.267 --> 00:33:03.811
And log viewers,
cryptography tools, log viewers,

605
00:33:03.811 --> 00:33:08.967
we'll talk about seam logs,
seam systems in a little while.

606
00:33:08.967 --> 00:33:10.796
But being able to crunch log data,

607
00:33:10.796 --> 00:33:14.394
correlate that data across different
systems so I can see the attack

608
00:33:14.394 --> 00:33:18.071
as it works its way through the network
gonna be very important to us.

609
00:33:18.071 --> 00:33:21.596
So all of those really should be
a part of our kit, and I'll break

610
00:33:21.596 --> 00:33:25.985
down the actual individual tools,
like I said, in some future episodes here.

611
00:33:25.985 --> 00:33:29.440
And that Wes, I think does
finish up our forensics tools.

612
00:33:29.440 --> 00:33:30.420
>> Wow, that was a great job.

613
00:33:30.420 --> 00:33:33.070
I didn't think he was gonna do it,
but man he can managed to do it.

614
00:33:33.070 --> 00:33:34.400
Mike did a real great job.

615
00:33:34.400 --> 00:33:38.730
But it does look like as you guys already
know we've expended our minutes for

616
00:33:38.730 --> 00:33:39.400
this episode.

617
00:33:39.400 --> 00:33:42.969
But before we do, Mike, you got any final
words maybe you'd like to impart to our

618
00:33:42.969 --> 00:33:45.609
viewers when it comes to things
like your forensics tools?

619
00:33:45.609 --> 00:33:49.078
>> No, but I will tell you what a Rolodex
is, just in case you don't know.

620
00:33:49.078 --> 00:33:52.573
It was an old system for keeping phone
numbers and contact information.

621
00:33:52.573 --> 00:33:54.330
It had a little dial on the side.

622
00:33:54.330 --> 00:33:56.000
And it was these little tiny cards, and

623
00:33:56.000 --> 00:33:59.690
as you turned it, the cards flipped
like one of those clocks where

624
00:33:59.690 --> 00:34:03.670
the little numbers in half fold in half
and flip over, that was a Rolodex.

625
00:34:03.670 --> 00:34:04.861
>> Yeah, I don't own a watch.

626
00:34:04.861 --> 00:34:08.100
>> [LAUGH] All right, that being said.

627
00:34:08.100 --> 00:34:12.082
Looks like it is time to sign out for
this one here at ITProTV.

628
00:34:12.082 --> 00:34:15.789
We do appreciate your watching and as
always Mike, we appreciate you being here.

629
00:34:15.789 --> 00:34:18.684
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

630
00:34:18.684 --> 00:34:19.456
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

631
00:34:19.456 --> 00:34:22.157
>> And we'll see you next time.

632
00:34:22.157 --> 00:34:28.225
[MUSIC]

633
00:34:28.225 --> 00:34:31.071
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike take a look at the communication process during during an incident response. They talk about stakeholders such as the CIO, CISO, incident response teams, human relations, public relations, legal advisors and role-based responsibilities.
episodes.title: Communication Process
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.033
Welcome to ITPPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.033 --> 00:00:06.456
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.456 --> 00:00:08.267
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.267 --> 00:00:11.011
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.060 --> 00:00:15.440
>> Hello, and welcome to another great
episode, here in the ITPRO.TV studios.

6
00:00:15.440 --> 00:00:16.640
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.640 --> 00:00:17.861
And in today's episode,

8
00:00:17.861 --> 00:00:21.643
we're continuing through our series
in CompTIA's Cybersecurity Analyst+.

9
00:00:21.643 --> 00:00:24.440
And joining us back in the studios
again is Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:24.440 --> 00:00:25.740
Mike, how are you doing today, sir?

11
00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:27.160
>> I am doing fantastic, Wes.

12
00:00:27.160 --> 00:00:28.020
Thanks for having me back,

13
00:00:28.020 --> 00:00:33.520
excited as always to be continuing on with
our Cybersecurity Analyst+ from CompTIA.

14
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:37.850
This one, we're hitting 3.3,
communication process is our objective.

15
00:00:37.850 --> 00:00:42.819
And we wanna talk about the importance of
communication during the incident response

16
00:00:42.819 --> 00:00:43.447
process.

17
00:00:43.447 --> 00:00:47.030
And I've already hinted at it
a little bit in a previous episode.

18
00:00:47.030 --> 00:00:48.350
But the communication,

19
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:53.110
it is an extremely important part
of the incident response process.

20
00:00:53.110 --> 00:00:56.780
Because we need to make sure that
everybody's aware of what is going on.

21
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:59.000
Well, I shouldn't use the word everybody.

22
00:00:59.000 --> 00:01:00.820
When I say everybody, I know what I mean,

23
00:01:00.820 --> 00:01:03.605
but let me make sure you
guys know what I mean.

24
00:01:03.605 --> 00:01:08.730
Cuz when I say everybody, and everybody
that should be notified has been notified.

25
00:01:08.730 --> 00:01:11.680
And that can change depending
on the type of incident, or

26
00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:14.960
where we're at in
the incident response plan.

27
00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:17.020
But knowing who to contact,

28
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:21.760
who needs to be told, having all of that
laid out ahead of time is very important.

29
00:01:21.760 --> 00:01:25.210
So that during the incident there
is no question, we know exactly who

30
00:01:25.210 --> 00:01:27.979
should be notified, and when, and
what information they need to be given.

31
00:01:29.690 --> 00:01:33.330
So when we look at it, who should
be included in the communication?

32
00:01:33.330 --> 00:01:35.670
And they've go a list, and
we'll kinda talk with each one.

33
00:01:36.920 --> 00:01:40.855
Maybe not in the exact order, but we will
talk about stakeholders in general, right?

34
00:01:40.855 --> 00:01:46.105
Stakeholders, anybody that has
a vested interest in the organization.

35
00:01:46.105 --> 00:01:51.730
So that includes from the CEO all
the way down to the front desk person,

36
00:01:51.730 --> 00:01:53.940
or all your employees.

37
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:57.870
It also includes your customers, right?

38
00:01:57.870 --> 00:02:00.900
They've bought your product, they're
a stakeholder in your organization.

39
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:03.270
So when they say stakeholders,
it doesn't mean that we go out and

40
00:02:03.270 --> 00:02:05.420
notify everybody that's
ever bought our product.

41
00:02:05.420 --> 00:02:07.660
Hey, we had a breach on someone's laptop,
and

42
00:02:07.660 --> 00:02:09.850
some of the data might
have been compromised.

43
00:02:09.850 --> 00:02:11.350
That's not what they mean there.

44
00:02:11.350 --> 00:02:16.450
Certain key stakeholder need to be
notified in the event of an incident,

45
00:02:16.450 --> 00:02:17.080
who are those?

46
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:20.030
Well, again,
depending on your organization,

47
00:02:20.030 --> 00:02:21.660
there is no one answer fits all.

48
00:02:21.660 --> 00:02:23.920
But there are some general guidelines
that we can throw out there,

49
00:02:23.920 --> 00:02:25.740
and that we should be familiar with.

50
00:02:25.740 --> 00:02:28.990
Management in general should be notified.

51
00:02:28.990 --> 00:02:33.030
But I don't like the way
they just say management,

52
00:02:33.030 --> 00:02:37.400
because organizations have
different levels of management.

53
00:02:37.400 --> 00:02:40.307
Sometimes we throw that title around
just to make people feel good.

54
00:02:40.307 --> 00:02:41.341
No, I'm just kidding.

55
00:02:41.341 --> 00:02:44.340
But not everybody in
management needs to know.

56
00:02:44.340 --> 00:02:45.393
So when we look at it,

57
00:02:45.393 --> 00:02:48.793
we really wanna think about the chief
information officer, right?

58
00:02:48.793 --> 00:02:52.641
Whoever that person is, they should
be notified, because this is their

59
00:02:52.641 --> 00:02:56.990
responsibility, in the end,
if they are the chief information officer.

60
00:02:56.990 --> 00:03:01.366
And we've got a data breach and
there is a possible exfiltration, or

61
00:03:01.366 --> 00:03:04.510
modification, or deletion of data, right?

62
00:03:04.510 --> 00:03:07.173
I think the chief information officer
would definitely wanna know, and

63
00:03:07.173 --> 00:03:08.536
that's an important one to notify.

64
00:03:08.536 --> 00:03:11.704
If we have a CISO,
a chief information security officer,

65
00:03:11.704 --> 00:03:13.930
they're gonna be notified.

66
00:03:13.930 --> 00:03:15.576
Your incident response team,

67
00:03:15.576 --> 00:03:18.495
they're probably one of
the first people you notify.

68
00:03:18.495 --> 00:03:22.959
Because if somebody discovers a laptop's
been compromised, see something going on

69
00:03:22.959 --> 00:03:27.240
that shouldn't be going on, they're
gonna notify the incident response team.

70
00:03:27.240 --> 00:03:30.630
So this list is not in any
particular order of notification,

71
00:03:30.630 --> 00:03:32.480
just to be clear on that.

72
00:03:32.480 --> 00:03:34.220
So incident response team,

73
00:03:34.220 --> 00:03:38.330
who are the people that have been
designated to respond to incidents?

74
00:03:38.330 --> 00:03:41.903
That actually go down there physically and
cordon off the area,

75
00:03:41.903 --> 00:03:46.348
and start documenting, and taking
the photos, and collecting the evidence.

76
00:03:46.348 --> 00:03:48.385
Those people are gonna
need to be notified.

77
00:03:48.385 --> 00:03:52.070
And I always talk about it, or
a lot of times I end up talking about it,

78
00:03:52.070 --> 00:03:54.660
like the incident occurred
in the office next door.

>> Yeah, absolutely.

00:21:57.450 --> 00:21:59.650

00:22:03.560 --> 00:22:06.640

433
00:22:06.640 --> 00:22:08.715
>> [LAUGH] Don't leave company name.

434
00:22:08.715 --> 00:22:12.000
>> [LAUGH] May not hold
of well at court of law.

435
00:22:12.000 --> 00:22:17.250
Do and that understand too that these are
templates and it's not one size fits all.

436
00:22:17.250 --> 00:22:18.940
So you needed to read
through the template and

437
00:22:18.940 --> 00:22:23.660
make sure these are things that you
plan to implement in your network.

438
00:22:23.660 --> 00:22:24.500
>> Good advice.

439
00:22:24.500 --> 00:22:27.460
>> But you can see the overview,
as I was saying, the purpose.

440
00:22:27.460 --> 00:22:29.950
The scope, I forgot that part,
that is in most,

00:22:29.950 --> 00:22:32.410
almost all policies should
have a scope as well.

442
00:22:32.410 --> 00:22:36.800
Those three parts overview purpose
scope are in just about every policy.

443
00:22:36.800 --> 00:22:39.380
Scope is, who they supplies to, right?

444
00:22:39.380 --> 00:22:42.060
This might be a password policy only for
upper management.

445
00:22:42.060 --> 00:22:44.560
And so
the scope would inform me of that so

446
00:22:44.560 --> 00:22:48.430
as an end user, I don't have to
comply with this particular policy.

447
00:22:48.430 --> 00:22:49.859
And then the policy itself.

448
00:22:50.870 --> 00:22:55.830
And this is where you're going to go in
and see if these apply, make changes, add,

00:22:55.830 --> 00:22:58.010
remove, unacceptable use.

450
00:23:00.140 --> 00:23:03.720
And again, I'm just, I know you can't
read this, I'm scrolling really fast.

451
00:23:03.720 --> 00:23:07.640
And this test is not on what's

452
00:23:07.640 --> 00:23:10.110
Just wanted to give you an idea of
all the different components and

453
00:23:10.110 --> 00:23:11.570
pieces that are in a policy.

454
00:23:12.650 --> 00:23:14.067
I do like the fact that they have,

455
00:23:14.067 --> 00:23:17.010
we're going to go back up
here just a little bit.

456
00:23:17.010 --> 00:23:21.520
You'll see in their policy they
have unacceptable use, right?

457
00:23:21.520 --> 00:23:23.430
This is an acceptable use policy.

458
00:23:23.430 --> 00:23:25.395
But they've got unacceptable use in here.

459
00:23:25.395 --> 00:23:27.270
Because not only are they
telling you what is acceptable,

460
00:23:27.270 --> 00:23:30.820
but they're going to call out certain
scenarios that are unacceptable.

461
00:23:30.820 --> 00:23:33.790
Under no circumstances is
this going to to be allowed.

462
00:23:33.790 --> 00:23:34.700
So, I like that kind of thing.

463
00:23:34.700 --> 00:23:35.320
>> I like how their angle.

464
00:23:35.320 --> 00:23:36.652
Yeah.
Because also even when

465
00:23:36.652 --> 00:23:41.002
you're talking about scope, sometimes it's
important to not just define what you will

466
00:23:41.002 --> 00:23:44.197
be covering be also what you will
not be covering just to clarify.

467
00:23:44.197 --> 00:23:44.775
>> Yeah, absolutely.

468
00:23:44.775 --> 00:23:46.238
You get that scope creep.

469
00:23:46.238 --> 00:23:48.826
We talk about a little project management.

470
00:23:48.826 --> 00:23:53.127
>> It starts as a tiny little project, but
then it ends up as a really large project.

471
00:23:53.127 --> 00:23:56.428
>> Yeah, pretty soon your
policy is 200 pages long and

472
00:23:56.428 --> 00:23:59.234
you need to A four-inch three-ring binder.

473
00:23:59.234 --> 00:24:03.370
They also talk,
they have related standards and policies.

474
00:24:03.370 --> 00:24:06.890
These are good, especially if your
policy references any other policies.

475
00:24:06.890 --> 00:24:09.300
You wanna make sure that
that's included in there.

476
00:24:09.300 --> 00:24:11.450
Compliance, how are we gonna measure?

477
00:24:11.450 --> 00:24:16.500
It's all well and good to say you need
to use an eight character password,

478
00:24:16.500 --> 00:24:20.510
and it must change every 30 days,
and it must be strong or complex.

479
00:24:20.510 --> 00:24:21.590
But how are we measuring that?

480
00:24:21.590 --> 00:24:23.850
And that needs to be part
of the policy as well.

481
00:24:23.850 --> 00:24:27.410
How we're going about measuring it and
making sure that we are compliant and

482
00:24:27.410 --> 00:24:30.088
what happens if somebody's
in noncompliance, right?

483
00:24:30.088 --> 00:24:32.620
What are the repercussions going to be?

484
00:24:32.620 --> 00:24:33.762
Because without any repercussions,

485
00:24:33.762 --> 00:24:35.264
why follow the policy in the first place,
right?

486
00:24:35.264 --> 00:24:36.146
>> Right.
[LAUGH]

487
00:24:36.146 --> 00:24:37.342
>> [LAUGH] I know my Mom's real-

488
00:24:37.342 --> 00:24:38.389
>> Lead by example, and

489
00:24:38.389 --> 00:24:40.949
that's horrible when you
get to an organization and

490
00:24:40.949 --> 00:24:43.390
their upper management
is not adhering to this.

491
00:24:43.390 --> 00:24:46.490
Because then it kind of just trickles
downward and it sets a bad example.

492
00:24:46.490 --> 00:24:47.702
>> It does, absolutely.

493
00:24:47.702 --> 00:24:52.441
And then you're never gonna get full
support and compliance in that case.

494
00:24:52.441 --> 00:24:55.473
And then terminology is also
an important part of most policies

495
00:24:55.473 --> 00:24:58.111
because in the policy you might,
you gotta remember.

496
00:24:58.111 --> 00:25:00.240
Oops, I don't know what I just clicked on.

497
00:25:00.240 --> 00:25:05.501
But you might use terms that
are specific or IT related.

498
00:25:05.501 --> 00:25:09.231
Remember, these policies are gonna be
read by people other than IT within your

499
00:25:09.231 --> 00:25:10.030
organization.

500
00:25:11.110 --> 00:25:14.457
You really should just stay
away from many of those terms.

501
00:25:14.457 --> 00:25:18.761
Using acronyms and things like that
in a policy is typically a no go,

502
00:25:18.761 --> 00:25:23.100
again, because of the wide audience
that the policy is gonna have.

503
00:25:23.100 --> 00:25:24.966
But if you do have to
use some of those terms,

504
00:25:24.966 --> 00:25:26.590
make sure you put a glossary in there.

505
00:25:26.590 --> 00:25:29.695
That will help make sure everybody's
on the same page, again, and

506
00:25:29.695 --> 00:25:32.540
not able to say, well,
I didn't even know what that meant.

507
00:25:32.540 --> 00:25:33.979
So I just ignored that part.

508
00:25:33.979 --> 00:25:34.823
>> Yeah.
>> Or something like that.

509
00:25:34.823 --> 00:25:37.091
>> But usually you would have someone.

510
00:25:37.091 --> 00:25:41.817
If you're really concerned with that,
like with the HR person, going through and

511
00:25:41.817 --> 00:25:46.060
they're supposed to be explaining these,
if you do have any questions.

512
00:25:46.060 --> 00:25:48.880
And give the person
an opportunity before they sign.

513
00:25:48.880 --> 00:25:52.700
>> Yes, it it really important
to give people a chance to ask.

514
00:25:52.700 --> 00:25:56.640
If you're a prospective employee, right?

515
00:25:56.640 --> 00:25:57.980
Don't just sign things.

516
00:25:57.980 --> 00:26:00.860
Make sure you read them and
understand what's going on.

517
00:26:00.860 --> 00:26:03.024
Although I guess nowadays,
I just want a job.

518
00:26:03.024 --> 00:26:04.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> The economy's not the greatest.

519
00:26:04.800 --> 00:26:07.886
I'll sign whatever you need me to sign,
just give me a job.

520
00:26:07.886 --> 00:26:12.460
But no, it is important that you take the
time to read through there and understand.

521
00:26:12.460 --> 00:26:15.853
Because in the end,
if you're non-compliant,

522
00:26:15.853 --> 00:26:18.048
there could be repercussions.

523
00:26:18.048 --> 00:26:20.880
>> And it's a really good
point that you bring up, Mike,

524
00:26:20.880 --> 00:26:24.092
because I've seen people for
companies sign non-compete.

525
00:26:24.092 --> 00:26:25.578
And then if they left that company,

526
00:26:25.578 --> 00:26:28.120
they would have a hard time
trying to find a new job.

527
00:26:28.120 --> 00:26:31.042
I actually worked for a company and

528
00:26:31.042 --> 00:26:36.197
one of their policies was,
it was for, whats the word here?

529
00:26:36.197 --> 00:26:39.373
Intellectual property,
and so if I had an idea,

530
00:26:39.373 --> 00:26:45.830
six months there after the termination,
regardless of who ended that relationship.

531
00:26:45.830 --> 00:26:48.904
It was the company's idea, so I couldn't
even think for an entire six months.

532
00:26:48.904 --> 00:26:50.687
>> Six months after-
>> Six months after, yeah.

533
00:26:50.687 --> 00:26:54.232
>> Your employment, they still owned your
intellectual property, that's interesting.

534
00:26:54.232 --> 00:26:55.939
I guess if it's signed and

535
00:26:55.939 --> 00:27:01.229
in their contract it would be interesting
to see how that would play out in court.

536
00:27:01.229 --> 00:27:03.790
>> Exactly, yeah.
>> Not that you would wanna be the one to

537
00:27:03.790 --> 00:27:05.200
try it out but.

538
00:27:05.200 --> 00:27:08.040
But to say we own your intellectual
property or any ideas you come up with

539
00:27:08.040 --> 00:27:10.250
the next six months,
even though you don't work for us anymore.

540
00:27:10.250 --> 00:27:14.511
But you do, you see that kind of thing a
lot where people work for universities or

541
00:27:14.511 --> 00:27:16.745
businesses and they come up with an idea.

542
00:27:16.745 --> 00:27:20.191
They leave the university, they were doing
research, they leave the university,

543
00:27:20.191 --> 00:27:21.460
start making money with that.

544
00:27:21.460 --> 00:27:23.587
And then the university comes back and
says, wait a second.

545
00:27:23.587 --> 00:27:27.115
You were a student here or
an employee here when that occurred,

546
00:27:27.115 --> 00:27:30.660
therefore all of that is actually
property of the university.

547
00:27:31.922 --> 00:27:35.000
All right, so frameworks,
policies, a couple checked off.

I know Cherokee's giving me that eye.

00:27:36.043 --> 00:27:37.680
It looks like we're

00:27:37.680 --> 00:27:39.180
We do have a little more to go, but

00:27:39.180 --> 00:27:42.050
probably more than we can squeeze

00:27:42.050 --> 00:27:43.550
>> We won't try to squeeze it, Mike.

CompTIA Cyber Security Analyst + series.

7

10

14

We've talked about frameworks and

how these are our documents that give
us the framework to reuse the term.

16
00:00:45.970 --> 00:00:50.950
The set of guides that we can use
to make sure that our IT solutions

17
00:00:50.950 --> 00:00:55.020
are in align with our business needs,
that they don't start conflicting.

18
00:00:55.020 --> 00:00:58.190
Best practices,
I don't wanna say best practices, but

these are frameworks that
have been developed over

00:01:01.030 --> 00:01:05.271
time that we can use to implement in

how policies are ways to formalize what

00:01:15.507 --> 00:01:19.030
we expect as an organization.

24
00:01:19.030 --> 00:01:22.132
Things like password policies or
acceptable use policies.

25
00:01:22.132 --> 00:01:25.365
In fact I did wanna go back and
mention I know we talked about them kind

26
00:01:25.365 --> 00:01:27.973
of in general,
I showed a couple of places you can go and

27
00:01:27.973 --> 00:01:30.630
to get some templates if you
needed to write policies.

28
00:01:30.630 --> 00:01:33.690
I do wanna mention the ones
they specifically call out

29
00:01:33.690 --> 00:01:35.540
on the exam objectives, just to make sure.

30
00:01:35.540 --> 00:01:39.090
If you're gonna do any research, go look
at these and what you might find in them.

31
00:01:39.090 --> 00:01:42.690
And as we were kinda joking earlier,
they're pretty self explanatory for

32
00:01:42.690 --> 00:01:43.190
the title.

33
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:46.980
But password policies, right,
dealing with our passwords.

34
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:50.020
How long they have to be,
how often we have to change them.

35
00:01:50.020 --> 00:01:52.160
If you're in management you
have to change it more often,

36
00:01:52.160 --> 00:01:54.660
it has to be longer, things like that.

37
00:01:54.660 --> 00:01:57.600
We've got our acceptable use policy so
that I can't go and

38
00:01:57.600 --> 00:02:02.697
use the printer to print off
invitations to my Cinco de Mayo party.

39
00:02:02.697 --> 00:02:03.562
>> [LAUGH] You got me.

40
00:02:03.562 --> 00:02:04.354
>> Yeah.

41
00:02:04.354 --> 00:02:07.195
[LAUGH]
>> Who's using all the colored ink?

42
00:02:07.195 --> 00:02:09.417
>> [LAUGH] I mean, what's
an invitation without colors, right?

43
00:02:09.417 --> 00:02:11.940
So acceptable use.

44
00:02:11.940 --> 00:02:18.860
I can't be at work and doing any kind
of auction sniping on my eBay stuff.

45
00:02:18.860 --> 00:02:21.987
Data ownership policies,
when you create a document,

46
00:02:21.987 --> 00:02:24.390
who's the listed owner of that document?

47
00:02:24.390 --> 00:02:28.154
Did that get transferred to
a kind of a generic account or

48
00:02:28.154 --> 00:02:31.790
does the individual user
maintain ownership?

49
00:02:31.790 --> 00:02:34.000
Data retention,
I think you mentioned that one, Cherokee.

50
00:02:34.000 --> 00:02:38.840
How long, depending on what the documents
are, what organization I'm in,

51
00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:41.960
what industry I'm in,
how long I have to keep documents for.

52
00:02:41.960 --> 00:02:46.040
That includes documents,
backups, things like that.

53
00:02:46.040 --> 00:02:48.790
Account management policy,
how do we deal with accounts?

54
00:02:48.790 --> 00:02:50.110
Who creates them?

55
00:02:50.110 --> 00:02:55.280
Can anybody create an account, or does
it have to be a procedure to go through?

56
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:56.620
Also, the flip side of things.

57
00:02:56.620 --> 00:02:59.610
What about when somebody
leaves the organization?

58
00:02:59.610 --> 00:03:00.710
What happens to that account?

59
00:03:00.710 --> 00:03:03.700
Is there a procedure that
we go through to make sure?

60
00:03:03.700 --> 00:03:05.380
I know I've dealt with an organization

61
00:03:06.960 --> 00:03:12.020
that had some issues with that where
the account was created for this person.

62
00:03:12.020 --> 00:03:16.870
It's tied to several other accounts and
custom software that they use.

63
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:20.710
And while they've disabled
the Active Directory account,

64
00:03:20.710 --> 00:03:23.760
that didn't disable the accounts
in some of this custom software.

65
00:03:23.760 --> 00:03:26.940
And that account was still available
if somebody had wanted to use it,

66
00:03:26.940 --> 00:03:27.490
things like that.

67
00:03:27.490 --> 00:03:30.868
How do we go about dealing with accounts?

68
00:03:30.868 --> 00:03:34.360
>> Especially if you're partnering
with any kind of contractor or

69
00:03:34.360 --> 00:03:36.020
any kind of short term business partner.

70
00:03:36.020 --> 00:03:38.903
You have to think about that
on-boarding and that off-boarding.

71
00:03:38.903 --> 00:03:42.480
And who actually has access to what
parts of your network and what data.

72
00:03:42.480 --> 00:03:44.332
So, definitely something to consider.

73
00:03:44.332 --> 00:03:48.890
>> I think we mentioned in a previous
episode, we had talked about.

74
00:03:48.890 --> 00:03:50.050
I forget the healthcare company now but

75
00:03:50.050 --> 00:03:52.454
we were talking about the five big hacks
that have occurred in the last few years.

76
00:03:52.454 --> 00:03:57.228
And remember one of the reasons they
got that $5.5 million dollar fine was

77
00:03:57.228 --> 00:04:00.533
because there was an account
from an employee that was

78
00:04:00.533 --> 00:04:03.985
no longer with the organization
was still being used for

79
00:04:03.985 --> 00:04:08.340
a year after the employee had left
to access all kinds of information.

80
00:04:08.340 --> 00:04:11.917
And that information was turned around and
being sold or given out, so.

81
00:04:11.917 --> 00:04:16.619
Data classification polices,
another big important part of how we deal

82
00:04:16.619 --> 00:04:21.930
with our data especially nowadays because
not all data is treated the same.

83
00:04:21.930 --> 00:04:25.930
How long do we keep it is determined
by what type of data it is,

84
00:04:25.930 --> 00:04:28.380
how well it's protected,
who has access to it.

85
00:04:28.380 --> 00:04:31.190
So data classification
has to be done as well.

86
00:04:31.190 --> 00:04:34.750
But anyway those are some of the policies
that they specifically call out

87
00:04:34.750 --> 00:04:36.760
on the exam objectives.

88
00:04:36.760 --> 00:04:38.510
Alright, now controls.

89
00:04:38.510 --> 00:04:44.110
So if policies are ways that we
formalize our business plans and

90
00:04:44.110 --> 00:04:47.210
how we want things to work and
how we want things done,

91
00:04:48.330 --> 00:04:51.500
controls are kind of
the way we enforce that.

92
00:04:51.500 --> 00:04:56.860
Or the way we can monitor for
compliance with those policies.

93
00:04:56.860 --> 00:05:00.480
So when we look at
controls there's different

94
00:05:00.480 --> 00:05:02.080
types of controls we can deal with.

95
00:05:02.080 --> 00:05:04.199
We've got physical controls,

96
00:05:04.199 --> 00:05:07.890
we have technical controls
and/or logical controls.

adding to the domain admin's group.

686
00:35:55.880 --> 00:36:00.140
If we can get a reverse show
with administrative credentials,

687
00:36:00.140 --> 00:36:03.040
I can simply add that user account
to the administrative group.

688
00:36:03.040 --> 00:36:04.330
Now I've got administrative access.

689
00:36:04.330 --> 00:36:05.710
Of course, if I've got the reverse shell,

690
00:36:05.710 --> 00:36:07.570
I might already have
administrative access.

691
00:36:07.570 --> 00:36:08.680
But you get the idea.

692
00:36:08.680 --> 00:36:11.790
>> And all these random pieces of software
and applications that are out there,

693
00:36:11.790 --> 00:36:12.960
even on our mobile devices.

694
00:36:12.960 --> 00:36:17.505
You don't know what level they're
accessing certain system components.

695
00:36:17.505 --> 00:36:19.985
And we have these safeguards
in place to prevent that.

696
00:36:19.985 --> 00:36:22.945
But if you look at an extreme secure,
like the Blackphone for

697
00:36:22.945 --> 00:36:26.945
instance, they prohibit those type
of applications for a reason, right?

698
00:36:26.945 --> 00:36:31.165
Because sometimes a arbitrary
code can go ahead and

699
00:36:31.165 --> 00:36:33.285
provide that privilege escalation.

700
00:36:33.285 --> 00:36:37.375
>> Yeah, well you know, even with the
protections that Apple puts into place,

701
00:36:37.375 --> 00:36:38.385
Google puts into place,

702
00:36:38.385 --> 00:36:41.510
Microsoft puts into place, we've seen
bad apps come out and they do just that.

703
00:36:41.510 --> 00:36:44.810
They're sending information off to,
I remember the one was,

704
00:36:44.810 --> 00:36:46.020
actually I can't remember it.

705
00:36:46.020 --> 00:36:50.960
This one might have turned out to be
a false, but there was a flashlight app on

706
00:36:50.960 --> 00:36:57.235
the iPhone that was actually sending
off information to some other site.

707
00:36:57.235 --> 00:37:01.285
It's a harmless flashlight application,
what could it be doing?

708
00:37:01.285 --> 00:37:04.195
And yeah,
it's just siphoning off your data.

709
00:37:04.195 --> 00:37:05.827
Last one is a rootkit.

710
00:37:05.827 --> 00:37:08.995
And rootkits, again,
hopefully we're familiar with that term.

711
00:37:08.995 --> 00:37:10.745
Root kit get down in between,

712
00:37:10.745 --> 00:37:13.725
remember when we're talking about
computer systems now a days, we've got

713
00:37:13.725 --> 00:37:17.195
a ring level security, you've got
the kernel, you got zero, one, two, three.

714
00:37:17.195 --> 00:37:18.970
The kernel's down in ring zero.

715
00:37:18.970 --> 00:37:22.000
Or users, we reside at level three.

716
00:37:22.000 --> 00:37:25.852
And the calls that we make
to the kernel are filtered.

717
00:37:25.852 --> 00:37:29.310
There's a little bit of
a control going there.

718
00:37:29.310 --> 00:37:32.730
We don't get to, as an end user we
don't deal directly with the kernel.

719
00:37:32.730 --> 00:37:35.572
As I said abstraction layer
that goes on in there.

720
00:37:35.572 --> 00:37:37.920
A rootkit slips down even
between the kernel and

721
00:37:37.920 --> 00:37:43.250
user mode, making it very difficult to
detect, basically giving the attacker

722
00:37:43.250 --> 00:37:46.010
full control over the system,
makes it very easy to hide.

723
00:37:46.010 --> 00:37:49.930
Because if I click on Task Manger,
that call's going through, but

724
00:37:49.930 --> 00:37:51.940
the rootkit's in between me and
the kernel.

725
00:37:51.940 --> 00:37:55.070
The rootkit intercepts that call,
and returns Task Manager.

726
00:37:55.070 --> 00:37:57.530
But with only the tasks
that it wants to show.

727
00:37:57.530 --> 00:38:00.050
It's gonna hide itself and
any processes that it's doing.

728
00:38:01.340 --> 00:38:05.430
Very, very dangerous, very hard to detect,
extremely hard to get rid of as well.

729
00:38:05.430 --> 00:38:08.740
Once you have a rootkit on a system and
you've determined that it's

730
00:38:10.060 --> 00:38:13.230
usually blow the system away-
>> That's my opinion on it.

731
00:38:13.230 --> 00:38:16.220
I've tried before very early on and

732
00:38:16.220 --> 00:38:20.670
I would see those symptoms just popping
back up again shortly thereafter.

733
00:38:20.670 --> 00:38:22.560
So It's a waste of time in my opinion.

734
00:38:22.560 --> 00:38:27.360
If you've got all your information backed
up just go ahead and reform at that drive.

735
00:38:27.360 --> 00:38:27.907
>> Get rid of it.

736
00:38:27.907 --> 00:38:28.582
All right, so

737
00:38:28.582 --> 00:38:32.480
again those are some of the exploits they
specifically call out on the objective.

738
00:38:32.480 --> 00:38:35.268
Just wanna make sure we
are familiar with those.

739
00:38:35.268 --> 00:38:40.147
Mike, we've covered several identity and
access issues in this episode.

740
00:38:40.147 --> 00:38:42.853
I know that's a lot for
you guys to think about but

741
00:38:42.853 --> 00:38:47.407
who knows maybe you'll come up with the
next security control for your systems and

742
00:38:47.407 --> 00:38:51.836
end users but that's gonna go ahead and
wrap it up for this particular episode.

743
00:38:51.836 --> 00:38:54.220
I'll sign off as your show host,
Cherokee Boose.

744
00:38:54.220 --> 00:38:54.980
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

745
00:38:54.980 --> 00:38:58.432
>> See next time here at ITProTV.

746
00:38:58.432 --> 00:39:04.480
[MUSIC]

747
00:39:04.480 --> 00:39:07.617
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Cherokee discuss the relevance of analysis techniques. Just about every piece of software or hardware will offer some form of logging capabilities which be a useful to help find trends, correlations, root causes and more.
episodes.title: Security Architecture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:04.042
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:04.042 --> 00:00:08.446
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.446 --> 00:00:12.040
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.040 --> 00:00:16.030
>> Welcome to your
CompTIA Cyber Security Analyst Plus show.

5
00:00:16.030 --> 00:00:18.020
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.020 --> 00:00:21.270
In this episode we will be looking
at security architecture, and

7
00:00:21.270 --> 00:00:23.970
who better to explain that than Mr.
Mike Rodrick himself.

8
00:00:23.970 --> 00:00:25.600
Thank you for joining us today, Mike.

9
00:00:25.600 --> 00:00:26.780
>> Glad to be back, Cherokee.

10
00:00:26.780 --> 00:00:31.292
Thanks for having me and yep,
continuing on with our good old CSA+.

11
00:00:31.292 --> 00:00:32.690
And today we're gonna be looking
at a few different things.

12
00:00:32.690 --> 00:00:35.620
And we're talking about
security architecture.

13
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:39.080
And we wanna just kind of go through
some of these objectives that

14
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:40.750
CompT calls out for us.

15
00:00:40.750 --> 00:00:44.760
And the first one is security
data analytics, right.

16
00:00:44.760 --> 00:00:50.970
And data analytics is a big topic right
now, especially big data data analytics.

17
00:00:50.970 --> 00:00:54.410
Because that's really what we're
seeing a lot of now, is we've, and

18
00:00:54.410 --> 00:00:55.970
we talk about big data, what do we mean?

19
00:00:55.970 --> 00:00:58.800
It's data that's large, right?

20
00:00:58.800 --> 00:01:02.010
Large amounts of data, not necessarily
that the data itself is big.

21
00:01:02.010 --> 00:01:08.620
But getting all this information together,
and getting big data together,

22
00:01:08.620 --> 00:01:11.750
pulling information from all
kinds of different sources.

23
00:01:11.750 --> 00:01:14.780
But then being able to make
sense out of it, right,

24
00:01:14.780 --> 00:01:17.900
being able to correlate that somehow.

25
00:01:17.900 --> 00:01:20.060
Basically do data mining on it,

26
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:24.630
make the information valuable, because you
can gather all kinds of information but

27
00:01:24.630 --> 00:01:27.980
if you do not have any way to
interpret that information,

28
00:01:27.980 --> 00:01:33.000
mine that information, make it relevant,
it's not gonna do you a whole lot of good.

29
00:01:33.000 --> 00:01:36.990
>> So Mike, with this copious amount of
information that we're seeing gathered,

30
00:01:38.460 --> 00:01:42.120
from a human perspective, trying to sift
through all that can be very difficult.

31
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:47.470
So we see a lot of third party utilities
and programs that actually will create

32
00:01:47.470 --> 00:01:51.860
graphical representations and
maybe even kind of extract

33
00:01:51.860 --> 00:01:56.645
relationships between data objects to kind
of bring that to our human attention.

34
00:01:56.645 --> 00:01:59.920
>> Yeah, exactly right, because there's
no way you or I is going to sit here and

35
00:01:59.920 --> 00:02:03.260
sift through this data and make sense out
of it, it's just too much information.

36
00:02:03.260 --> 00:02:06.550
So definitely third party
software that allows you to,

37
00:02:06.550 --> 00:02:09.820
once its indexes the information
it does its correlation.

38
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:12.360
Then we can usually run some
types of queries against it,

39
00:02:12.360 --> 00:02:15.620
filter it down to get
what we're looking for.

40
00:02:15.620 --> 00:02:21.000
And give us some kind of summary of that
information that's actually useful to us.

41
00:02:22.110 --> 00:02:23.920
We're doing it,
the bad guys are doing it too,

42
00:02:23.920 --> 00:02:27.370
unfortunately, as they steal information.

43
00:02:27.370 --> 00:02:30.780
Some information on it's own is not
that valuable, a set of usernames.

44
00:02:30.780 --> 00:02:33.800
But if I can find social
security numbers somewhere else,

45
00:02:33.800 --> 00:02:35.740
start correlating those two together,

46
00:02:35.740 --> 00:02:38.860
now that information becomes much more
valuable if I'm trying to sell that.

47
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:41.660
And that's what the bad
guys are doing as well.

48
00:02:41.660 --> 00:02:44.240
>> And yesterday we spoke about
some regulatory compliances and

49
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:45.450
things like HIPAA.

50
00:02:45.450 --> 00:02:49.220
If we have to deconstruct and
break down that pie, and

51
00:02:49.220 --> 00:02:52.430
put it in separate components,
and encrypt them separately, and

52
00:02:52.430 --> 00:02:54.390
things like that,
that's really what they are looking for

53
00:02:54.390 --> 00:02:57.800
is just those little nuggets that can
help fill in the puzzle pieces, right.

54
00:02:57.800 --> 00:02:59.710
>> Yep, that's exactly right,
exactly right.

55
00:02:59.710 --> 00:03:01.770
So when we talk about data aggregation,
again,

56
00:03:01.770 --> 00:03:04.860
pulling all that information together,
correlating it, and

57
00:03:04.860 --> 00:03:07.830
we're typically gonna be using
some type of software to do this.

58
00:03:07.830 --> 00:03:12.580
And another thing we do with data
analytics is trend analysis, right.

59
00:03:12.580 --> 00:03:16.470
Trend analysis is when we look
at data over periods of time,

60
00:03:16.470 --> 00:03:18.840
kind of like little snapshots.

61
00:03:18.840 --> 00:03:23.060
And we look for a trend, or
a pattern, in that information.

62
00:03:23.060 --> 00:03:25.930
We might look at,
just as a simple example,

63
00:03:25.930 --> 00:03:29.630
I don't know,
number of visitors to our website, right.

64
00:03:29.630 --> 00:03:32.700
We might see that, overtime,
it's slowly going up.

65
00:03:32.700 --> 00:03:35.680
Or after our latest update,
we see that the numbers going up.

66
00:03:35.680 --> 00:03:37.390
That would be trend analysis.

67
00:03:37.390 --> 00:03:42.370
We're saying, okay, if this continues on,
this is where we should be in the next

68
00:03:42.370 --> 00:03:47.490
week or the next month so
we can use that data to identify patterns.

69
00:03:47.490 --> 00:03:50.540
One of the issues that you can run
into though with trend analysis is not

70
00:03:50.540 --> 00:03:52.390
having a good baseline, right.

71
00:03:52.390 --> 00:03:56.270
And when we talk about security,
let's put it more into context what we're

72
00:03:56.270 --> 00:03:59.300
doing here, I'm talking about security
when we look at trend analysis.

73
00:03:59.300 --> 00:04:02.449
We might be looking at
behaviors on our network.

74
00:04:02.449 --> 00:04:07.080
Like a mound of a certain protocol
that normally occurs on our network.

75
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:10.830
And we see spikes in that activity
every day around the same time,

76
00:04:10.830 --> 00:04:13.360
or once a week around the same time.

77
00:04:13.360 --> 00:04:14.780
We start to see that trend, right.

78
00:04:14.780 --> 00:04:15.840
That's trend analysis.

79
00:04:15.840 --> 00:04:18.520
We like, okay,
what's going on here that's causing this?

80
00:04:18.520 --> 00:04:23.800
Or just unusual amounts of data being
sent out of our network, right.

81
00:04:23.800 --> 00:04:29.020
Normally we see so much megabytes or
gigabytes of data leaving our network,

82
00:04:29.020 --> 00:04:32.440
and all of a sudden it's spiking
way up more than normal.

83
00:04:32.440 --> 00:04:35.000
That would be, again,
looking at big data and

84
00:04:35.000 --> 00:04:37.570
using trend analysis to
notice those things.

85
00:04:37.570 --> 00:04:41.460
The issue that you run into, though,
is not having a good baseline.

86
00:04:41.460 --> 00:04:45.480
If you don't know what your network
normally spits out, for example.

87
00:04:45.480 --> 00:04:48.100
What is the normal amount of
data that's leaving my network?

88
00:04:48.100 --> 00:04:51.050
What is the normal amount
of logon attempts that I

89
00:04:51.050 --> 00:04:53.350
have between the hours of nine and ten?

90
00:04:53.350 --> 00:04:56.540
If I don't know what my baseline is
it's gonna be extremely hard for

91
00:04:56.540 --> 00:05:01.230
me to get any information, useful
information, or do any trend analysis.

92
00:05:01.230 --> 00:05:03.936
>> Sure, you have to be able to
spot that anomaly in order to,

93
00:05:03.936 --> 00:05:06.811
you need to know what's normal
in order to spot that anomaly or

94
00:05:06.811 --> 00:05:08.690
anything that's different there.

95
00:05:08.690 --> 00:05:09.580
>> Exactly.

96
00:05:09.580 --> 00:05:13.040
>> And even if you are running some kind
of continuous monitoring you can see,

97
00:05:13.040 --> 00:05:18.350
look, last year Mike used two
gigs of a shared storage.

98
00:05:18.350 --> 00:05:21.290
This year, Mike's using four
gigs of his shared storage.

99
00:05:21.290 --> 00:05:26.230
And you can kind of anticipate, even for
budgeting purposes, what your company or

100
00:05:26.230 --> 00:05:30.230
organization might need as far as growing
room and things of that nature as well.

101
00:05:30.230 --> 00:05:31.830
>> That's exactly right, Cherokee.

102
00:05:31.830 --> 00:05:36.480
And another issue we have with trend
analysis is that usually when we're taking

103
00:05:36.480 --> 00:05:42.770
those snapshots they're points in time of
a continuously changing metric, right.

104
00:05:42.770 --> 00:05:47.701
So we might not capture
the information when we chose to do

105
00:05:47.701 --> 00:05:51.515
that particular snapshot of time, right.

106
00:05:51.515 --> 00:05:54.460
There was a big spike in activity but
it was right in between, say,

107
00:05:54.460 --> 00:05:56.090
two snapshots that we took.

108
00:05:56.090 --> 00:05:59.620
So we don't see that in our
analysis because it is typically

109
00:05:59.620 --> 00:06:00.860
points in time snapshots.

110
00:06:00.860 --> 00:06:04.660
There's a period of time in between where
we're not capturing that information.

111
00:06:04.660 --> 00:06:08.160
Other things we might do as far as
when it comes to data analytics,

112
00:06:08.160 --> 00:06:09.679
historical analysis.

113
00:06:11.370 --> 00:06:12.700
The biggest problem we have here,

114
00:06:12.700 --> 00:06:15.430
historical analysis is just
looking back at past data.

115
00:06:15.430 --> 00:06:18.750
We can always learn from our past, right.

116
00:06:18.750 --> 00:06:23.500
We can take a look at what happened, and
we can try to, again, see patterns in it.

117
00:06:23.500 --> 00:06:28.830
But we're looking at actual
historical data, and it allows us to

118
00:06:28.830 --> 00:06:33.800
maybe see where we're going, or
learn from past experience, and being able

119
00:06:33.800 --> 00:06:38.300
to apply that towards future projects,
or whatever it is that we're doing.

120
00:06:38.300 --> 00:06:41.210
The biggest problems you have with
historical analysis is usually just

121
00:06:41.210 --> 00:06:44.680
collecting the data,
because it is a large amount of data.

122
00:06:44.680 --> 00:06:46.080
Do we still have that information?

123
00:06:46.080 --> 00:06:47.520
How long did we keep it?

124
00:06:47.520 --> 00:06:51.290
And interpreting that
information sometimes,

125
00:06:51.290 --> 00:06:54.940
especially if systems
have changed over time.

126
00:06:54.940 --> 00:06:59.290
And then having people,
the analysts, if I can say that,

127
00:06:59.290 --> 00:07:05.320
that sit down, that are trained
to look at that information and

128
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:08.310
get relative or
pertinent information out of that.

129
00:07:08.310 --> 00:07:10.000
So that can be challenging as well.

130
00:07:11.370 --> 00:07:17.020
Other places that we want to look for
information, manual reviews,

131
00:07:17.020 --> 00:07:20.890
and they say manual reviews
on the exam objectives.

132
00:07:20.890 --> 00:07:23.910
And I will tell you that manual
reviews means I'm doing it manually.

133
00:07:23.910 --> 00:07:27.871
But a lot of this I see being automated,
honestly.

134
00:07:27.871 --> 00:07:28.450
>> [LAUGH] Well,

135
00:07:28.450 --> 00:07:32.790
that's what a lot of people in the IT
industry like to do, to simplify things.

136
00:07:32.790 --> 00:07:34.452
Work a little smarter, not harder, right.

137
00:07:34.452 --> 00:07:36.330
>> Yes.
>> [LAUGH]

138
00:07:36.330 --> 00:07:37.972
>> If I've got, I don't know,

139
00:07:37.972 --> 00:07:42.115
hundreds of servers, I don't wanna go
read all those log files manually,

140
00:07:42.115 --> 00:07:44.049
looking at them one line at a time.

141
00:07:44.049 --> 00:07:49.384
I wanna be able to try to automate that
and make it a little bit easier on myself.

142
00:07:49.384 --> 00:07:54.096
But things we're gonna wanna look for
when we're talking about Security,

143
00:07:54.096 --> 00:07:57.335
where are the best places to check for
information,

144
00:07:57.335 --> 00:08:02.250
to try to detect any type of breaches or
anomalies that might be occurring.

145
00:08:02.250 --> 00:08:04.990
The firewall logs have to be
one of your first thoughts,

146
00:08:04.990 --> 00:08:07.930
because if we think about it,
if our network is set up properly,

147
00:08:07.930 --> 00:08:10.860
all traffic is going to be
passing through that firewall.

148
00:08:10.860 --> 00:08:14.470
Especially all inbound traffic should
definitely be coming through the firewall.

149
00:08:14.470 --> 00:08:19.373
So by looking at those logs, I have
a record of all the data, all the packets,

150
00:08:19.373 --> 00:08:20.580
all the protocol,

151
00:08:20.580 --> 00:08:25.120
all the different connections that
are coming through that firewall.

152
00:08:25.120 --> 00:08:29.021
>> And now it's really important too,
Mike, because you're gonna get a call if

153
00:08:29.021 --> 00:08:32.036
an application or
service isn't working on your network and

154
00:08:32.036 --> 00:08:34.790
it might be a misconfigured
firewall setting.

155
00:08:34.790 --> 00:08:36.680
But it's not like the attacker's
gonna call you and

156
00:08:36.680 --> 00:08:38.160
say hey, I just got in to your network,

157
00:08:38.160 --> 00:08:41.090
they're not gonna let you know about
those kind of malconfigurations.

158
00:08:41.090 --> 00:08:43.810
So it's kind of something you
really should be checking, right?

159
00:08:43.810 --> 00:08:44.640
>> Typically not, yeah.

160
00:08:44.640 --> 00:08:46.195
I don't know too many that do.

161
00:08:46.195 --> 00:08:47.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> Although all of us

162
00:08:47.660 --> 00:08:48.991
here are ethical hackers, and

163
00:08:48.991 --> 00:08:53.138

00:30:13.450 --> 00:30:15.160

00:30:18.110 --> 00:30:21.550
If somebody does do,
I break somebody's password and now,

00:31:32.610 --> 00:31:35.350

00:31:35.350 --> 00:31:39.950

Entropy?

00:30:32.321 --> 00:30:34.292
We're talking about
baseline in this respect,

575

we're saying that these are the baseline
settings that need to be configured on

00:30:37.511 --> 00:30:39.480
all of our Windows 10 clients.

577
00:30:39.480 --> 00:30:42.880
These are the baseline settings that must
be configured on all new servers that we

578
00:30:42.880 --> 00:30:44.190
roll out.

579
00:30:44.190 --> 00:30:45.909
We can try to come up
with those on our own.

580
00:30:45.909 --> 00:30:50.367
But there are organizations like
this that have the experience,

581

And then basically give you almost like

So a really good resource to help you

584

So a lot of information there.

585

We talked about application security and
just making sure that security

00:31:13.760 --> 00:31:17.710

587
00:31:17.710 --> 00:31:20.984
>> Well, Mike, and
now I can take all my great ideas and

00:31:20.984 --> 00:31:25.908
see them through application fruition,
or at least I know where to start now.

589
00:31:25.908 --> 00:31:27.950
So thank you, I appreciate that.

590
00:31:27.950 --> 00:31:31.961
And thank you ladies and gentlemen for
tuning in today, but that does go ahead

591
00:31:31.961 --> 00:31:35.678
and meet the end of our show here, so
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

592
00:31:35.678 --> 00:31:37.997
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike take you through a litany of Cybersecurity Tools that you will need to be familiar with for the CSA+ exam. They start by exploring preventative tools like IPS/IDS, Firewalls, Antivirus/Anti-malware, Web proxy, and Web Application Firewalls.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.622
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.622 --> 00:00:06.324
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.324 --> 00:00:08.288
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.288 --> 00:00:08.788
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.240 --> 00:00:13.690
>> All right
>> Hi, greetings everyone.

6
00:00:13.690 --> 00:00:16.660
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.660 --> 00:00:17.890
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:17.890 --> 00:00:21.700
And in today's episode we're back
with more on our CSA+ series.

9
00:00:21.700 --> 00:00:25.060
And, of course, joining us in the studio
yet again to lend his expertise on that

10
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:28.130
topic our good friend,
our mentor, Mr Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:28.130 --> 00:00:29.820
Mike welcome back sir,
how's it going today?

12
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:31.440
>> It's going great,
thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:31.440 --> 00:00:34.280
Glad to be here, excited as always.

14
00:00:34.280 --> 00:00:37.260
So in this episode we're gonna to be
looking at some of the different tools

15
00:00:37.260 --> 00:00:41.540
that we have available for
us as cyber security professionals.

16
00:00:41.540 --> 00:00:44.770
And I wanna read you the CompTia
objective here for this one.

17
00:00:44.770 --> 00:00:47.020
Compare and contrast the general purpose.

18
00:00:47.020 --> 00:00:51.670
And reason for using various cyber
security tools and technologies.

And then the objectives proceed

20

00:01:00.500 --> 00:01:05.010

22
00:01:05.010 --> 00:01:09.990
And really talk about where I would I use
these, why I would want to go out and

23
00:01:09.990 --> 00:01:13.040
get one of these, where I would end up,

24
00:01:13.040 --> 00:01:15.290
what is the reason for
wanting one of these tools.

25
00:01:15.290 --> 00:01:19.840
And then compare a couple of tools within
that category although what you'll see

26
00:01:19.840 --> 00:01:24.480
is that most of them within a category,
that's why they're in a category together,

27
00:01:24.480 --> 00:01:28.010
because they do the same thing, or
they have the same general purpose.

28
00:01:28.010 --> 00:01:30.630
One's going to have a few more bells and
whistles than the other.

29
00:01:30.630 --> 00:01:32.250
One might be free, one is not.

30
00:01:32.250 --> 00:01:36.720
So there's differences there, but in
general, they're gonna do the same thing.

31
00:01:36.720 --> 00:01:42.850
So let's start out by, let's see,
our first category is preventative.

32
00:01:42.850 --> 00:01:48.020
So, types of tools that we can use in
cyber security as preventative measures.

33
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:51.210
And what do we mean by preventative tools?

34
00:01:51.210 --> 00:01:56.230
These are tools that I would
use before we're compromised,

35
00:01:56.230 --> 00:01:58.880
right, before anything bad happens.

36
00:01:58.880 --> 00:02:01.580
These are tools that I'm
gonna try to use to prevent

37
00:02:01.580 --> 00:02:02.890
things like that from happening.

38
00:02:02.890 --> 00:02:07.140
So these are proactive tools
rather than reacted right.

39
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:09.370
These are things that when
I'm setting up my network or

40
00:02:09.370 --> 00:02:13.460
when I'm coming in and saying, hey,
look we are gonna make our network secure.

41
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:16.000
These are tools that I'm
gonna use to help do that,

00:02:16.000 --> 00:02:18.710
to help keep my network secure
before bad things happen.

43
00:02:18.710 --> 00:02:20.530
So what kinds of things
are we looking at here?

44
00:02:20.530 --> 00:02:25.820
One would be intrusion detection systems
and intrusion prevention systems.

45
00:02:25.820 --> 00:02:32.900
IDS, Intrusion Detection System and
then IPS, Intrusion Prevention Systems.

46
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:38.430
The difference is subtle, but at the same
time, a very big difference, right?

47
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:39.795
Cuz they sound similar, right?

48
00:02:39.795 --> 00:02:40.880
>> Yeah.
>> Intrusion detection,

49
00:02:40.880 --> 00:02:42.610
intrusion prevention?

50
00:02:42.610 --> 00:02:46.437
>> It's interesting because they both have
the same engine in which to identify that

51
00:02:46.437 --> 00:02:48.090
the threat has occurred, right.

52
00:02:48.090 --> 00:02:52.120
But one is just gonna go, you can set
it up for an email or a messages,

53
00:02:52.120 --> 00:02:55.500
SMS message maybe, something like that,
typically email, to let you know,

54
00:02:55.500 --> 00:02:58.450
hey, an event has occurred,
you may want to check that out.

55
00:02:58.450 --> 00:03:00.600
And there's gonna be logs
associated with that.

56
00:03:00.600 --> 00:03:05.230
But when it comes to IPS,
it says I see what you are doing there and

57
00:03:05.230 --> 00:03:09.040
I don't like it and it actually tries
to stop the threat from occurring.

58
00:03:09.040 --> 00:03:12.020
>> Yeah, absolutely it's almost
like having another person working

59
00:03:12.020 --> 00:03:12.540
for you on staff.

60
00:03:12.540 --> 00:03:15.390
>> Right
>> Somebody that can react before you get

61
00:03:15.390 --> 00:03:17.819
a chance to so that's it,
Daniel nailed it on the head there.

62
00:03:18.960 --> 00:03:23.270
Intrusion detection detects intrusions but
it doesn't do anything about it.

63
00:03:23.270 --> 00:03:26.210
It's considered a passive system and

64
00:03:26.210 --> 00:03:28.090
really, that's what we started with,
right?

65
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:31.578
If you go way back in the day before
the tools were being developed,

66
00:03:31.578 --> 00:03:33.244
that was the first thing we had, was hey,

67
00:03:33.244 --> 00:03:36.130
we need something that can
alert me of anomalous behavior.

68
00:03:36.130 --> 00:03:40.720
Strange behavior of behavior
that indicates or is indicative

69
00:03:40.720 --> 00:03:44.260
of some type of attack, right,
that was our intrusion detection systems.

70
00:03:44.260 --> 00:03:44.930
And that was great,

71
00:03:44.930 --> 00:03:48.400
because at least we wold be made aware
of something that was happening.

72
00:03:48.400 --> 00:03:49.970
And then we could go check it out.

73
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:53.730
But as Daniel said, it was in the form
usually of an alert sent to you,

74
00:03:53.730 --> 00:03:55.550
maybe a pop up on your screen.

75
00:03:55.550 --> 00:03:59.180
Maybe an email, a text,
an SMS, something like that.

76
00:03:59.180 --> 00:04:02.860
To alert you or
a group of people about an event.

77
00:04:02.860 --> 00:04:05.180
And then you'd have to go and find out.

78
00:04:05.180 --> 00:04:10.010
But it was very, it was after-the-fact.

79
00:04:10.010 --> 00:04:14.760
The activity had already occurred and
now we gonna go check it out.

80
00:04:14.760 --> 00:04:18.400
Whereas in intrusion prevention,
as Daniel said, Is active.

81
00:04:18.400 --> 00:04:21.780
It does something about it or it can
be configured to do something about it.

82
00:04:21.780 --> 00:04:24.240
And like Daniel said,
it is basically the same detection.

83
00:04:24.240 --> 00:04:27.520
It's just what happens after we detected
that intrusion detection, I'm sorry,

84
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:30.670
the intrusion prevention,
can shut down ports.

85
00:04:30.670 --> 00:04:34.710
Follow band width, depending on what
product you're using, it can do a lot of

86
00:04:34.710 --> 00:04:37.880
cool things to try to mitigate
the effectiveness of the attack or

87
00:04:37.880 --> 00:04:41.810
whatever the malicious activity that's
occurring to try to slow that down and

88
00:04:41.810 --> 00:04:44.100
keep it from,
at least keep it from spreading.

89
00:04:44.100 --> 00:04:47.680
It might have detected it as it
was infecting in the system.

90
00:04:47.680 --> 00:04:51.060
And that system started
the CPU cycles on that system

91
00:04:51.060 --> 00:04:54.060
sky rocketed well above the baseline.

92
00:04:54.060 --> 00:04:58.530
Network bandwidth coming out of that
machine was well out of the normal range.

93
00:04:58.530 --> 00:05:01.840
And then my intrusion prevention system
said, something's going on here,

94
00:05:01.840 --> 00:05:03.120
this isn't right.

95
00:05:03.120 --> 00:05:04.420
Let me shut the switch down and

96
00:05:04.420 --> 00:05:07.050
prevent that node from communicating
with the rest of the network.

97
00:05:07.050 --> 00:05:09.290
That node's already infected but

98
00:05:09.290 --> 00:05:12.040
it keeps the rest of the network
from getting infected, all right?

99
00:05:12.040 --> 00:05:14.600
Some of the ones you would see here,

100
00:05:14.600 --> 00:05:16.410
I guess some other terminology
we should throw in.

101
00:05:16.410 --> 00:05:20.100
It's not actually on this list but
part of it is, part of it is and

102
00:05:20.100 --> 00:05:21.065
I don't understand.

103
00:05:21.065 --> 00:05:23.879
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we do need to make sure we

104
00:05:23.879 --> 00:05:30.130
understand that there are NIDSs,
NIPSs, HIPSS and HIDSS, right.

105
00:05:30.130 --> 00:05:31.740
What's that gonna throw at you.

106
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:33.350
It's straight forward though.

107
00:05:33.350 --> 00:05:35.247
You've got host-based
intrusion detection and

108
00:05:35.247 --> 00:05:38.040
you've got network-based
intrusion detection systems.

109
00:05:38.040 --> 00:05:40.591
You've got host-based intrusion
prevention systems and

110
00:05:40.591 --> 00:05:43.180
network-based intrusion prevention system.

111
00:05:43.180 --> 00:05:47.380
And a host-based is designed
to protect a single machine.

112
00:05:47.380 --> 00:05:51.748
You run it all on a host and to protect
that machine and that machine only.

113
00:05:51.748 --> 00:05:55.340
Whereas a network-based would be
put typically in line somewhere in

114
00:05:55.340 --> 00:05:58.440
the network, usually out towards
the front of your network where it can

115
00:05:58.440 --> 00:06:00.230
see all the traffic coming in.

116
00:06:00.230 --> 00:06:03.780
But it definitely can have more
than one sensor hooked up to it for

117
00:06:03.780 --> 00:06:10.310
different locations and it monitors
the entire network for malicious behavior.

118
00:06:10.310 --> 00:06:13.670
So that's the difference between
network-based and host-based.

119
00:06:13.670 --> 00:06:17.300
Some examples, intrusion prevention
system you have Sourcefire,

120
00:06:17.300 --> 00:06:19.670
its one that's been around for
a long time.

121
00:06:19.670 --> 00:06:25.740
In fact, the gentleman that develop
Snort which is also on our list,

122
00:06:25.740 --> 00:06:26.820
develop Sourcefire.

123
00:06:26.820 --> 00:06:29.520
It's gotta a long history,
I don't have it memorized.

124
00:06:29.520 --> 00:06:31.340
If you're really curious,
you could go out to Wikipedia, but

125
00:06:31.340 --> 00:06:33.150
it's not gonna be on the exam.

126
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:38.830
But Snort was free, developed by,
and I can't remember the guy's name.

127
00:06:38.830 --> 00:06:43.845
But he developed Sourcefire, who then
was bought out by Cisco in 2013 for

128
00:06:43.845 --> 00:06:46.120
$2.7 billion.

129
00:06:47.160 --> 00:06:47.960
>> With the b?

130
00:06:47.960 --> 00:06:50.260
>> With the B.

131
00:06:50.260 --> 00:06:50.900
>> Yeah.
So

132
00:06:50.900 --> 00:06:54.400
you can see they plan of making
a lot of money with that.

133
00:06:54.400 --> 00:06:58.085
So back in 2013, Cisco acquire sourcefire.

134
00:06:58.085 --> 00:07:00.685
And some of you might be running
this now in your network.

135
00:07:00.685 --> 00:07:01.265
If you look at your,

00:07:01.265 --> 00:07:05.655
what they call the next generation

00:07:05.655 --> 00:07:08.960
The Cisco created was called firepower.

138
00:07:08.960 --> 00:07:12.000
If we now here we can actually
go out to their website and

00:07:12.000 --> 00:07:13.473

00:07:13.473 --> 00:07:15.555
I will try to pull up
some of these as we go,

141
00:07:15.555 --> 00:07:19.556
but, again this is just really
not gonna be a testable thing.

142
00:07:19.556 --> 00:07:23.720
But Cisco has their Next-Generation
Intrusion Prevention Systems.We

143
00:07:23.720 --> 00:07:27.350
take a look here at some of their
firepowers and these are again,

144
00:07:27.350 --> 00:07:30.790
what sourcefire kind of evolved into.

145
00:07:30.790 --> 00:07:31.290
Right.

146
00:07:32.350 --> 00:07:34.590
Snort, we've actually already seen.

147
00:07:35.800 --> 00:07:38.450
I think we've done a demo of Snort.

148
00:07:38.450 --> 00:07:39.270
If not, we will.

149
00:07:40.840 --> 00:07:42.400
Snort is open source.

150
00:07:42.400 --> 00:07:42.910
It's free.

151
00:07:42.910 --> 00:07:45.240
It is another, it can be either.

152
00:07:45.240 --> 00:07:49.260
And a lot of these can, keep that in mind

153
00:07:49.260 --> 00:07:50.700
Like Snort, for example.

154
00:07:50.700 --> 00:07:52.105
You can set this up as intrusion
detection or intrusion prevention.

155
00:07:52.105 --> 00:07:57.521
If you remember in our little exercise

were coming in to that particular host,

157
00:08:03.480 --> 00:08:09.270
we're basically using as a host-based
intrusion detection system.

158
00:08:09.270 --> 00:08:10.690
But you could configure it as either.

159
00:08:10.690 --> 00:08:14.540
Is it going to be active or
is it going to be passive?

160
00:08:14.540 --> 00:08:16.480
Bro is another one.

00:08:16.480 --> 00:08:18.000
Got a great name, right?

00:08:18.000 --> 00:08:19.460
What's up, Bro?

00:08:19.460 --> 00:08:22.010
Let's go to
the Bro Network Security Monitor.

00:08:23.870 --> 00:08:25.460
And this is just www.bro.org.

165
00:08:25.460 --> 00:08:29.070
This is another network analysis
framework, as they like to put it there.

166
00:08:29.070 --> 00:08:30.160
It does a lot.

167
00:08:30.160 --> 00:08:34.390
It actually can do some forensics and
that's really what I'm seeing lately,

168
00:08:34.390 --> 00:08:38.495
Daniel, is these tools they're
becoming multipurpose.

169
00:08:38.495 --> 00:08:39.760
>> Mm-hm.
>> Unified threat management

170
00:08:39.760 --> 00:08:44.110
type systems where it's no longer I have
>> And intrusion detection system.

171
00:08:44.110 --> 00:08:47.930
And I have a sys log system and
I have something else.

172
00:08:47.930 --> 00:08:50.830
They're all kind of
combined into one nowadays.

173
00:08:50.830 --> 00:08:52.400
>> They're making the game too easy Mike.

174
00:08:52.400 --> 00:08:53.280
>> They are.

175
00:08:53.280 --> 00:08:55.060
And that has its pros and cons.

176
00:08:55.060 --> 00:08:56.340
>> Yeah.
>> I think we've talked about that.

177
00:08:56.340 --> 00:09:00.300
We've said how these unified systems
are great because you've got one user

178
00:09:00.300 --> 00:09:02.510
interface to deal with.

179
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:07.680
You learn that console and you can
manage of all of your security systems.

180
00:09:07.680 --> 00:09:11.630
Which is good the bad downside is if that
ever goes down or is unavailable for

181
00:09:11.630 --> 00:09:14.840
some reason you can lose a lot
more then just one system.

182
00:09:14.840 --> 00:09:18.040
So it can end up we talk
about layers of defense but

183
00:09:18.040 --> 00:09:21.370
if all those layers are tied
to one appliance and

184
00:09:21.370 --> 00:09:25.360
that appliance fails I didn't lose one
layer I've lost several layers of defense.

185
00:09:25.360 --> 00:09:29.040
So that is something to consider but
of course we're gonna put fault

186
00:09:30.320 --> 00:09:34.060
tolerance in there So
those are just some general examples, or

187
00:09:34.060 --> 00:09:37.270
some examples of intrusion
prevention systems.

188
00:09:37.270 --> 00:09:40.940
Image and host based intrusion prevention,
just be familiar with that term as well.

189
00:09:40.940 --> 00:09:44.410
One or the other, do I run one or
the other, do I choose network based vs.

190
00:09:44.410 --> 00:09:45.310
host based?

191
00:09:45.310 --> 00:09:48.270
No, in fact a lot of
organizations will run

192
00:09:48.270 --> 00:09:51.250
never faced intrusion prevention
systems to protect the entire network.

193
00:09:51.250 --> 00:09:56.500
But then, on the sensitive hosts, the ones
that have data that I have to protect for

194
00:09:56.500 --> 00:09:58.630
regulatory reasons, or
just super sensitive,

195
00:09:58.630 --> 00:10:02.970
or if this kind of data is the crown
jewels of the organization.

196
00:10:02.970 --> 00:10:05.620
If it gets out,
our business could go under.

197
00:10:05.620 --> 00:10:07.470
Intellectual properties, stuff like that.

198
00:10:07.470 --> 00:10:11.280
Maybe I run host based intrusion
prevention on that individual host.

199
00:10:11.280 --> 00:10:13.190
So, another layer of defense, right?

200
00:10:13.190 --> 00:10:16.080
If anything was to make it past
my network intrusion prevention,

201
00:10:16.080 --> 00:10:22.310
the alarms on the system itself would kick
off and warn me of the attack, right?

202
00:10:22.310 --> 00:10:27.340
Other types of preventative tools we need
to be familiar with, firewalls, right?

203
00:10:28.620 --> 00:10:30.320
Firewalls are a,

204
00:10:30.320 --> 00:10:33.770
I don't know of any network that doesn't
run a firewall I can't think of any.

205
00:10:33.770 --> 00:10:35.560
I don't know why they would.

continuing on with our tools, right?

type tools in that last episode.

jump categories and

we want to talk about

Again, just need to be familiar with

21
00:00:56.620 --> 00:00:59.590
Understand it if your asked what

about events on your network.

23
00:01:03.470 --> 00:01:06.640

tool to pick from a list.

24

25
00:01:07.830 --> 00:01:10.465
The first thing we'll talk about
when it comes to collective tools,

26
00:01:10.465 --> 00:01:14.220
I think the name pretty much tells you

27
00:01:14.220 --> 00:01:16.328

28

depending on what the tool

29
00:01:18.691 --> 00:01:21.062
It might be collecting up log events.

30
00:01:21.062 --> 00:01:23.740

31

33

where we're talking about centralizing

really large amounts of data

36

Trying to think of
a better way to say that.

37
00:01:48.290 --> 00:01:50.930

really SIEM stands for

38
00:01:50.930 --> 00:01:53.890
my security information and
event management.

39
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:59.500

than just log files, but it is a way

40
00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:04.500

than look at log files in one place.

41
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:09.820
And look at network performance
information in another place.

42
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:12.520
Start bringing all this together under one

00:02:12.520 --> 00:02:17.230
interface where we can make sense out of

44
00:02:17.230 --> 00:02:20.090

45
00:02:20.090 --> 00:02:24.530
And that's not so much what you know,
it's what can you do with what you know.

46
00:02:24.530 --> 00:02:27.560
And information on its own
is really hard to interpret.

47
00:02:27.560 --> 00:02:30.561
We need context to go
with that information.

48
00:02:30.561 --> 00:02:33.615
And when we start pulling information
from multiple sources and

49
00:02:33.615 --> 00:02:37.290
we start putting it together, we start

50
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:39.170
just looking at that one piece of data.

51
00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:42.690
And that's SIEMs really
help us do as well as just

00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:45.840
go through the massive

00:02:45.840 --> 00:02:49.510

00:02:51.320 --> 00:02:54.600

00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:59.220

57
00:02:59.220 --> 00:03:03.300
And we've got to monitor all the activity
on our network, different branches,

58
00:03:03.300 --> 00:03:04.790
different locations.

59
00:03:04.790 --> 00:03:07.210
So pulling all that together
with our SIEM systems.

60
00:03:07.210 --> 00:03:09.110
Now some of them we
should be familiar with.

61
