00:03:27.364 --> 00:03:29.864
although a lot of these
can be virtualized.

67
00:03:29.864 --> 00:03:32.716
It could be a virtual appliance,
could be a physical appliance.

68
00:03:32.716 --> 00:03:37.507

see there is your ArcSight all-in-one

69
00:03:37.507 --> 00:03:40.710
SIEM application or
ArcSight Express I should say.

70
00:03:40.710 --> 00:03:43.130

71
00:03:43.130 --> 00:03:44.170
That's just one.

75
00:03:55.140 --> 00:04:00.260

76
00:04:00.260 --> 00:04:04.180
And this is not general web information,
this is information about your network,

77
00:04:04.180 --> 00:04:09.220
and it's giving you a way to look
at it that's a lot easier than

78
00:04:09.220 --> 00:04:10.690
thumbing through log files, right?

79
00:04:10.690 --> 00:04:12.060
It's doing that work for you.

80
00:04:12.060 --> 00:04:15.780
It's taking all that log information,

81
00:04:15.780 --> 00:04:16.980

82
00:04:16.980 --> 00:04:20.210

83
00:04:20.210 --> 00:04:23.900

84
00:04:23.900 --> 00:04:25.560
make decisions based on that.

85
00:04:25.560 --> 00:04:28.096
So that's really what these

86
00:04:28.096 --> 00:04:31.760
Again that's ArcSight

>> I'm kidding, IBM, I kid you.

00:04:49.600 --> 00:04:52.410

00:30:17.235 --> 00:30:20.535
Yeah, so NetScout Systems founded
in 1984 as Network General.

548
00:30:20.535 --> 00:30:24.185
Network General developed the original
network packet sniffer in 86,

549
00:30:24.185 --> 00:30:26.860
merged with McAfee in 1997.

550
00:30:26.860 --> 00:30:31.267
Form Network Associates also created
the first ethernet probe and then

551
00:30:31.267 --> 00:30:36.189
Network Associates sold off the sniffer
technology to Silverlake Partners and

552
00:30:36.189 --> 00:30:41.037
take a specific group to form Network
General which is what they were called way

553
00:30:41.037 --> 00:30:41.938
back in 84.

554
00:30:41.938 --> 00:30:46.546
But then Network General acquired
Fidela Technology adding to the Net Vigil

555
00:30:46.546 --> 00:30:48.204
business system monitor.

556
00:30:48.204 --> 00:30:51.488
Network generally be agree to be
required by NetScout systems for

557
00:30:51.488 --> 00:30:52.940
$205 million dollars.

558
00:30:52.940 --> 00:30:56.670
Anyway, I don't point that out for any
real particular reason other than the fact

559
00:30:56.670 --> 00:30:59.720
that Network General, over the years
has changed its name several times,

560
00:30:59.720 --> 00:31:04.640
has been bought, acquired, sold, bought
acquired, it is now NetScout Systems.

561
00:31:04.640 --> 00:31:07.270
But evidently on the Compte,
they're still calling it Network General.

562
00:31:07.270 --> 00:31:09.638
So I just wanted to make sure that
If you're doing your studying and

563
00:31:09.638 --> 00:31:12.454
you're doing your research and
you're like, what is this network general?

564
00:31:12.454 --> 00:31:16.440
Go out and look out NetScout systems,
and you can find some information.

565
00:31:16.440 --> 00:31:19.470
But it is a packet capture technology.

566
00:31:19.470 --> 00:31:24.086
So in the end, it is a sniffing technology
that's going to allow me to capture

567
00:31:24.086 --> 00:31:27.850
the raw packet data that's
travelling across the network, so

568
00:31:27.850 --> 00:31:30.974
that I can do packet analysis,
protocol analysis,

569
00:31:30.974 --> 00:31:34.476
and look and
see what's going on on our system, right?.

570
00:31:34.476 --> 00:31:37.570
Let's see what else, where did we
get off on that packet capture.

571
00:31:37.570 --> 00:31:41.359
The last one I want to talk about for

572
00:31:41.359 --> 00:31:46.984
this one is another goodie and
that is Aircrack ng.

573
00:31:46.984 --> 00:31:51.905
And Aircrack ng you can probably infer
from the name this is gonna have something

574
00:31:51.905 --> 00:31:53.895
to do with wireless and it does.

575
00:31:53.895 --> 00:31:59.082
Complete suite of tools to assess
the wi-fi network security.

576
00:31:59.082 --> 00:32:02.154
And it's in this section
because it does monitoring.

577
00:32:02.154 --> 00:32:06.578
Packet capture and export data
of our wireless traffic, right?

578
00:32:06.578 --> 00:32:08.600
But it can also do a lot more.

579
00:32:08.600 --> 00:32:13.424
You can do attacking, you can do
password attacks, replay attacks,

580
00:32:13.424 --> 00:32:16.299
fake access points, packet injection.

581
00:32:16.299 --> 00:32:21.929
We can test Wi-Fi systems, crack WPA, WEP.

582
00:32:21.929 --> 00:32:24.974
So it's a very, very powerful tool and

583
00:32:24.974 --> 00:32:29.600
it actually has a Windows port as well,
which is very cool.

584
00:32:29.600 --> 00:32:32.010
But again,
just another packet capture utility.

585
00:32:32.010 --> 00:32:34.270
This one really is focused on Wi-Fi,

586
00:32:34.270 --> 00:32:38.530
but don't infer from that that
the other ones don't do Wi-Fi, right?

587
00:32:38.530 --> 00:32:39.490
It's all about whether or

588
00:32:39.490 --> 00:32:44.120
not the program has a driver that can talk
to that network adapter that you're using.

589
00:32:45.360 --> 00:32:49.046
I know, for example, Wire Socket,
really when it was Ether Reel,

590
00:32:49.046 --> 00:32:52.475
at first I had trouble with
certain wireless adapters of mine,

591
00:32:52.475 --> 00:32:56.809
you had to make sure had the, it was
looking for a particular Orangeco chipset,

592
00:32:56.809 --> 00:32:58.897
so you had to research-
>> I remember that, yeah.

593
00:32:58.897 --> 00:33:00.820
>> On what wireless network
adapter you were buying.

594
00:33:00.820 --> 00:33:05.040
It's like, I couldn't just go out and buy
a Linksys or this I had to do research on

595
00:33:05.040 --> 00:33:10.810
what chipset that manufacturer was using,
to see if it was going to work with this.

596
00:33:10.810 --> 00:33:14.850
But now, Wireshark has picked up every
network I've had, every network adapter

597
00:33:14.850 --> 00:33:20.180
I've had thrown at it in the last
few years, I haven't had any issues.

598
00:33:20.180 --> 00:33:22.370
Whether it's wired or
wireless network adapters.

599
00:33:22.370 --> 00:33:24.890
So I just wanted to bring that
up because when you see this,

600
00:33:24.890 --> 00:33:29.120
you're like, I've gotta get a different
pack of CAPTCHA utility for wireless.

601
00:33:29.120 --> 00:33:31.770
Not necessarily,
it really depends on what you're using.

602
00:33:31.770 --> 00:33:35.471
Some programs might not recognize
those wireless cards but

603
00:33:35.471 --> 00:33:37.469
really when it comes down to it,

604
00:33:37.469 --> 00:33:42.443
once it gets to your network adapter
it's just like any other traffic, right?

605
00:33:42.443 --> 00:33:44.438
I mean it's not like it's,
well, I shouldn't say.

606
00:33:44.438 --> 00:33:46.520
But it's not like it's flagged,
hey, this is a wireless packet.

607
00:33:46.520 --> 00:33:47.440
You're not gonna understand that.

608
00:33:47.440 --> 00:33:51.340
It's not a different language per se,
as far as the TCP/IP goes.

609
00:33:52.383 --> 00:33:57.285
Anyhow, so
Aircrack-ng is a good one to play with if

610
00:33:57.285 --> 00:34:01.815
you want to do a little Wi-Fi sniffing,
as well as go a little bit beyond there.

611
00:34:01.815 --> 00:34:04.885
It kinda gets in some of the other
categories because it will do some

612
00:34:04.885 --> 00:34:06.665
attacking as well.

613
00:34:06.665 --> 00:34:10.535
>> All right Mike,
I know we have more to talk about.

614
00:34:10.535 --> 00:34:12.970
We have a laundry list to
continue to go through.

615
00:34:12.970 --> 00:34:14.690
But, we are well out of time for
this episode.

616
00:34:14.690 --> 00:34:18.350
So, we'll have to roll this into
a part three, maybe even a part four.

617
00:34:18.350 --> 00:34:19.196
You never know, right?

618
00:34:19.196 --> 00:34:20.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> You never know with us.

619
00:34:20.490 --> 00:34:22.100
We might get crazy and go for a part four.

00:34:22.100 --> 00:34:25.530
But that would mean we're definitely gonna

621
00:34:25.530 --> 00:34:26.790
Mike, thanks for joining us today.

622
00:34:26.790 --> 00:34:30.920
And continuing down our list of
different cyber security tools

623
00:34:30.920 --> 00:34:34.880
that we need to be aware of for CSA+ exam.

624
00:34:34.880 --> 00:34:38.950
That being said, it is time for
us to sign off for ITProTV.

625
00:34:38.950 --> 00:34:40.720
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

00:34:40.720 --> 00:34:41.570

00:34:41.570 --> 00:34:44.059

1

6

7

8

9
00:00:27.280 --> 00:00:29.060
Our good friend and

10
00:00:29.060 --> 00:00:30.190
Mike, welcome back, man.

11

12
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:32.280
>> It's going great.
Thanks for having me back,

13
00:00:32.280 --> 00:00:33.810
excited as always.

14
00:00:33.810 --> 00:00:38.750
All right, so we left off, we were
talking about the collective category,

15
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:41.970
tools that collect information up for
us we talked about seam systems,

16
00:00:41.970 --> 00:00:43.830
we talked about network scanners,

17

we talked about vulnerability scanners,
impact and capture utilities.

command line and IP utilities.

19
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:55.170
So again, these are things at this
point if you're studying this exam you

20
00:00:55.170 --> 00:00:55.980
should be familiar with.

21
00:00:55.980 --> 00:00:58.580
So we're basically refreshing our memory,
right?

22
00:00:58.580 --> 00:00:59.910
On these guys.

23
00:00:59.910 --> 00:01:02.710
First one I mentioned there is netstat.

24
00:01:02.710 --> 00:01:06.700
Netstat is, I always think of it
your network statistics, right?

25
00:01:06.700 --> 00:01:12.910
This is what I use to look at the ports
that my machine is listening on,

26
00:01:12.910 --> 00:01:18.270
see what connections had been
established to my machine.

27
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:23.140
Or what connections I've made outbound,
again, command line utility.

28
00:01:23.140 --> 00:01:25.460
We should,
I won't do a full on demonstration, but

29
00:01:25.460 --> 00:01:32.355
let's at least just take a peak, I'll show
you one here just on my Windows machine.

30
00:01:32.355 --> 00:01:34.762
NetStat, we'll do a switch question mark.

31
00:01:36.763 --> 00:01:40.660
And I can see all the different switches
that come with, or that are available.

32
00:01:40.660 --> 00:01:41.200
With NetStat.

33
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:46.640
NetStat's not just a Microsoft thing,
we can do this on Linux systems as well.

34
00:01:46.640 --> 00:01:51.711
I can do something like in NetStat-AN,
for example.

35
00:01:51.711 --> 00:01:53.970
And you can see that,
that's probably really small.

36
00:01:53.970 --> 00:01:59.430
This is not set up for,
this is not what I normally use to do my

37
00:01:59.430 --> 00:02:03.350
demonstrations, so let me just bump
that up a wee bit there you go.

38
00:02:03.350 --> 00:02:04.590
For everybody.

39
00:02:04.590 --> 00:02:09.237
So, the command I ran in
this case was netstat -AN.

40
00:02:09.237 --> 00:02:13.270
You can see the N, display address and
port numbers in numerical form.

41
00:02:13.270 --> 00:02:16.520
The A, all connections and
listening ports.

42
00:02:16.520 --> 00:02:20.950
Just one that I use but there
are obviously several switches there.

43
00:02:20.950 --> 00:02:24.410
And so, I can see the different
ports that my system's listening on.

44
00:02:24.410 --> 00:02:28.140
Some of them say LISTENING, so
this is a port that's open and

45
00:02:28.140 --> 00:02:30.110

46
00:02:30.110 --> 00:02:35.560
Some of them say ESTABLISHED, so now I
can see that my machine has a connection.

47
00:02:35.560 --> 00:02:36.400
With another machine.

48
00:02:36.400 --> 00:02:40.810
I can see what port numbers are associated
with that connection, right?

49
00:02:40.810 --> 00:02:45.210
So this is where I would go to look,
if I had suspected maybe some malware,

50
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:48.440
like a trojan horse, some kind of
backdoor was listening on this system,

51
00:02:48.440 --> 00:02:49.770
or was installed in the system.

52
00:02:49.770 --> 00:02:52.490
I might be able to get
some information from here

53
00:02:52.490 --> 00:02:55.890
If I knew what port should
be there already, right?

54
00:02:55.890 --> 00:02:56.770
I see these ports and

55
00:02:56.770 --> 00:02:58.940
I'm like whoa, I don't know if
those should be there or not.

56
00:02:58.940 --> 00:03:02.660
I don't have a good baseline,
to compare it to.

57
00:03:02.660 --> 00:03:06.870
It's not gonna do me as much good,
but it'll still be beneficial.

58
00:03:06.870 --> 00:03:08.130
So netstat for looking for

59
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:12.590
your network statistics or
what connections you have on that machine.

60
00:03:12.590 --> 00:03:13.370
What ports are open?

61
00:03:13.370 --> 00:03:14.250
What ports are listening?

62
00:03:15.480 --> 00:03:16.980
What's another one they mention here,

63
00:03:16.980 --> 00:03:21.200
ping, hopefully we all
are familiar with ping.

64
00:03:21.200 --> 00:03:22.520
>> What's that?

65
00:03:22.520 --> 00:03:25.580
>> It's part of the game,
ping pong, it's the first half.

66
00:03:25.580 --> 00:03:30.260
But it's a network utility,
it allows me to send ICMP or

67
00:03:30.260 --> 00:03:34.920
Internet Control Message Protocol packets,
we use it typically to test.

68
00:03:34.920 --> 00:03:37.000
Connectivity between a machine.

69
00:03:37.000 --> 00:03:40.390
We almost of our scanners
used pings to test for

70
00:03:40.390 --> 00:03:44.100
live host before they do a thorough
inspection on that IP address.

71
00:03:44.100 --> 00:03:47.290
Either to make sure that address is
responding before I start go up port by

72
00:03:47.290 --> 00:03:52.220
port through 365000 ports,
right, so it's used for a lot

73
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:57.390
can also be used maliciously as some,
you will see, do not respond to pings.

74
00:03:57.390 --> 00:04:00.961
If I ping www.google.com.

75
00:04:00.961 --> 00:04:02.630
>> Ping, ping.

76
00:04:02.630 --> 00:04:03.300
>> Did I ping ping?

77
00:04:03.300 --> 00:04:03.920
>> You did.

78
00:04:03.920 --> 00:04:05.270
>> Ping ping will not work.

79
00:04:05.270 --> 00:04:06.450
That is not the same thing.

80
00:04:06.450 --> 00:04:07.915
That is actually an attack, no.

81
00:04:07.915 --> 00:04:11.775
[LAUGH]
>> There we go we can see Google is

82
00:04:11.775 --> 00:04:12.980
responding.

83
00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:16.600
But if I try to ping somebody
like Microsoft.com we'll

84
00:04:17.900 --> 00:04:20.760
see that that doesn't respond
because they've chosen not to.

85
00:04:20.760 --> 00:04:24.100
Because there are several different
types of attacks that can be used,

86
00:04:24.100 --> 00:04:27.020
ping with pings from
simple denial service.

87
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:28.190
Pings actually carry a payload.

88
00:04:28.190 --> 00:04:30.610
A lot of people don't realize there's
about 53 bytes, or something,

89
00:04:30.610 --> 00:04:33.980
in a ping packet that I could use to
shuttle information into a network if you

90
00:04:33.980 --> 00:04:36.020
are allowing those ping packets.

91
00:04:36.020 --> 00:04:39.470
A lot of times we use ping
just to test connectivity.

92
00:04:39.470 --> 00:04:41.770
I use it to test name resolution,
many times.

93
00:04:41.770 --> 00:04:46.100
Like the fact that Microsoft
didn't respond is.

94
00:04:46.100 --> 00:04:46.940
Information.

95
00:04:46.940 --> 00:04:48.840
But, the fact that it was
able to take the name.

96
00:04:48.840 --> 00:04:50.610
Cuz I pinged a name.

97
00:04:50.610 --> 00:04:52.370
Well we know computers cannot talk names,

98
00:04:52.370 --> 00:04:54.680
they have to have an IP
address to communicate.

99
00:04:54.680 --> 00:04:59.340
So the first thing Ping does, is it
resolves that name into an IP address.

100
00:05:00.400 --> 00:05:05.090
And even though Microsoft didn't respond,
I know my DNS is working.

101
00:05:05.090 --> 00:05:07.010
Right, so there's a test in and of itself.

102
00:05:07.010 --> 00:05:08.680
And so, again, this is Network+ stuff,

103
00:05:08.680 --> 00:05:12.250
hopefully you guys are familiar
with just doing a quick rehash.

104
00:05:12.250 --> 00:05:15.154
Another one, Tracert, I say Tracert.

105
00:05:15.154 --> 00:05:17.210
>> I say Tracer-T.

106
00:05:17.210 --> 00:05:19.470
>> I don't know if that's the way.

107
00:05:19.470 --> 00:05:20.812
You say Trace-RT?

108
00:05:20.812 --> 00:05:24.426
>> Tracer-T, like tracer then T.

109
00:05:24.426 --> 00:05:27.582
>> Okay, so Tracer-T, gotcha.

110
00:05:29.944 --> 00:05:33.450
Oops, I'll just do a quick one
while I'm talking about it here.

111
00:05:33.450 --> 00:05:39.480
Traceroute is kind of a combination
of path ping and ping.

112
00:05:39.480 --> 00:05:41.470
It'll go out, actually I take that back,

113
00:05:41.470 --> 00:05:44.240
path ping is actually a combination
of traceroute and ping.

114
00:05:44.240 --> 00:05:47.440
But traceroute looks at each
hop in the path, right?

115
00:05:47.440 --> 00:05:52.460
When I'm sending a packet out to Google It
doesn't go from my computer to Google,

116
00:05:52.460 --> 00:05:56.160
it goes from my computer to
our default gateway here which

117
00:05:56.160 --> 00:05:57.780
goes to our ISP's gateway.

118
00:05:57.780 --> 00:06:00.020
Which gets out there
eventually to the backbone and

119
00:06:00.020 --> 00:06:01.500
bounces through a couple other routers.

120
00:06:01.500 --> 00:06:03.940
It gets close to wherever
Google is located,

121
00:06:03.940 --> 00:06:06.020
it starts getting to the closer network.

122
00:06:06.020 --> 00:06:07.270
And then it gets into Google's network.

123
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:09.110
It finally hits them and
then it comes back and

124
00:06:09.110 --> 00:06:12.580
what this is doing is it's giving
me information about each hop.

125
00:06:12.580 --> 00:06:13.790
In that path.

126
00:06:13.790 --> 00:06:14.420
Right?

127
00:06:14.420 --> 00:06:17.450
So I can see that it
left our network here,

128
00:06:17.450 --> 00:06:23.250
then it went to GRU which is one of our,
actually I think that's our gateway there.

129
00:06:23.250 --> 00:06:25.170
Then it bounced up into Atlanta.

130
00:06:25.170 --> 00:06:27.020
A couple more IP address here.

131
00:06:27.020 --> 00:06:28.810
And then looks like somewhere
along the line they're

132
00:06:28.810 --> 00:06:30.270
not given any information back.

133
00:06:31.510 --> 00:06:36.090
The idea is that with TRACERT, I can
see the path that the packet is taking.

134
00:06:36.090 --> 00:06:40.230
And if I'm doing something like this to
Google, really the only information I'm

135
00:06:40.230 --> 00:06:44.360
gonna get is I might figure out,
wow, it's really slowing down here.

136
00:06:44.360 --> 00:06:48.730
I see 1,000 milliseconds delay time,
something's going on.

137
00:06:48.730 --> 00:06:51.170
But this is probably beyond my control.

138
00:06:51.170 --> 00:06:53.180
This is not anything that I can control.

139
00:06:53.180 --> 00:06:59.100
But in a heavily routed environment
If your network is heavily routed

140
00:06:59.100 --> 00:07:03.530
this can be very helpful because now there
are devices that are under my control.

141
00:07:03.530 --> 00:07:05.710
Let's say each one of your
floors is it's own subnet and

142
00:07:05.710 --> 00:07:08.885
you've got a router on each one and
people on the first,

143
00:07:08.885 --> 00:07:13.065
tenth floor are having trouble printing or
sending something down to the first floor.

144
00:07:13.065 --> 00:07:16.205
And as you could figure out which router

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate the venerable packet capture and/or packet analyzer known as Wireshark. They begin by showing you how to launch Wireshark and connect to a network interface to quickly capture data. They also show you how to work with Profiles and employ Filters to more finely control Wireshark's output.
